name: Der Präsident. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Danuta Maria Hübner and Pedro Silva Pereira, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the composition of the European Parliament (2017/2054 (INL) (A8-0007/2018).

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, today we will vote on the composition of the European Parliament for the European elections of 2019. In times when democracy as a system is called into question by some, elections are the most important expression of citizens’ democratic will. The European Parliament directly represents its citizens in the European Union, so we as Members of Parliament form the direct link between citizens and the Union, and it is the prerogative of the European Parliament to propose its composition to the European Council and to have a final say on the European Council decision for each legislative period. A distribution of Parliament’s seats that is fair, that follows subjective principles and that respects the EU Treaties was the objective that we as co-rapporteurs set ourselves when we were entrusted with this task. We listened to the concerns of our colleagues in the House and the Member States and proposed a composition that fully respects the principle of digressive proportionality, as required by the Treaty. This principle ensures a fair and balanced representation of citizens by Member State. Observance of this principle, in combination with the distribution of some of the UK’s vacated seats, allows us to address the under-representation of some Member States in the House. Brexit has undoubtedly created a new situation for the Union that affects the composition of our House. One of the most populous Member States is leaving the Union, and we believe that this should be reflected in the future distribution of seats. We have the opportunity here not only to address the problem of under-representation of some Member States but also to leave a number of seats available for future enlargements and, depending on the creation of the proper legal basis, for the creation of transnational lists for European elections. By reducing the size of Parliament from 751 to 705 Members, we would also allow for savings, thereby freeing up resources that can be used for other purposes. I think these are the right signals to send to our citizens. Brexit has also made our task more challenging due to legal uncertainties as to the precise date and terms on which the EU acquis will cease to apply to the UK. That is why we have also envisaged a fall-back option in case the UK has not formally withdrawn from the Union by the time of the next elections. In conclusion, I would like to highlight that this report garnered 80% support in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. I hope that we will manage to achieve a large majority in today’s vote in plenary as well, in order to ensure fair representation of our citizens. I call, in this regard, on the European Council to take heed of the European Parliament’s position with regard to its composition. (Applause)

name: Pedro Silva Pereira
text: rapporteur. — (PT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report on the composition of Parliament, which I am presenting with my colleague, Danuta Hübner, aims to achieve what has never been done: to secure a Parliament with fairer representation and at the same time to ensure that no country loses seats. This seems simple, but it's never been done. Whenever it was necessary in the past to adjust the composition of Parliament, some had to lose so that others could win. And we know why it is different now: we have discussed the recomposition of Parliament in the context of Brexit and therefore have the opportunity to distribute at least some of the seats in the United Kingdom. Naturally, in the past tensions between winners and losers have always prevented deviations from the status quo and led to pragmatic solutions in which possible political commitments have always fallen short of fairer representation. None of that happens now in this proposal, because we have the fantastic opportunity to finally have a fairer Parliament that represents more faithfully the population of the Member States and at the same time ensuring that no Member State loses seats in Parliament. This is indeed possible now and we must not miss this opportunity. Of course, the redistribution of seats in the United Kingdom must be limited because citizens would not understand if a large country should leave the European Union and the size of Parliament should not be reduced. But some distribution is necessary if we do not want to miss this opportunity. Therefore, after listening carefully to the experts, after listening to this Parliament, starting with the shadow rapporteurs, the proposal that I and my colleague Danuta Hübner are putting forward is this: firstly, that all countries keep the number of Members they have now. It's, I'd say, the basic principle, no one loses seats. Second, that in addition, 27 of the 73 seats in the United Kingdom, which will be left vacant, are distributed to those States that are underrepresented today. It is a fair, balanced, politically viable proposal, which has already been approved by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and which I hope will also be adopted by this House today. Our distribution key is not the application of any of the many mathematical formulas that have been discussed and which have achieved neither political nor technical consensus. But it is also not a simple pragmatic solution like the one that has been in force until now. What we are proposing is a solution based on principles, the principle of degressive proportionality and the principle that no state loses seats. By redistributing only 27 out of 73 posts, we are of course also proposing a reduction in Parliament and leaving a margin of 46 seats available for future enlargements or for the possible creation of transnational lists. And let me say just two words to you about transnational lists. And the first is to undo a misunderstanding. This report is about the composition of Parliament, it is not about transnational lists. Through this report, Parliament, as it did in 2015, recognises that it is up to the Council, in the context of reform of electoral legislation, to decide unanimously on the creation of a possible common European constituency. That is why the report says that this Council decision is a precondition. This is what is at stake and not more than this. I hope that no one-off disagreement will prevent this Parliament from sending a clear message to the Council and proposing a parliament... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: György Schöpflin
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I congratulate the two co—rapporteurs. I think they have done an excellent job on a very difficult file. I, for my part, want to focus on the transnational list. I have made no secret of my view that, as far as I am concerned, the transnational list is a bad idea. Here are my reasons. There are several. First, the transnational list (TNL) is based on an idea that out there somewhere there is a European demos just waiting to be represented, and that the TNL will do just this. This is an error. There is no European demos and to claim the contrary is an illusion. Have European citizens ever been asked if they want to be represented by a transnational list? Again, the answer is no. So, in real terms, what we are looking at is a top—down, elite—driven project, presumably starting from the belief that, if the transnational list comes into being, so will the European demos. Why on earth should it? It is a fatal assumption that the TNL will generate a supranational European consciousness. If anything, those putatively elected on the TNL will be remote from the electorate, and that will not do the reputation of this Parliament any good. It’s magical thinking that the transnational list will somehow produce the European demos. If the transnational list does happen, then this Parliament will have 27 free—floating MEPs answerable to none. They will have power without an electorate, they will have power without accountability and power without responsibility. So where are the checks and balances? I shouldn’t have to say that power without responsibility is the high road to arbitrariness. That, if you ask me, is about as undemocratic as it gets.

name: Mercedes Bresso
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, meanwhile, I too want to thank the rapporteurs and I hope that this more balanced organisation of Parliament can also be approved by the Council. I also hope that the part of transnational lists can be approved by the Council, which I also hope will be approved by Parliament as it was approved in committee. To my colleague Schöplin and the many who have spoken out against transnational lists these days, I remember that we already represent all European citizens today. So I am very far away when I am in Brussels from a Greek voter who I also represent, as I am far from my constituents I represent, but I am not just representing the electors of my college. Having a transnational list with candidates, if possible, from all European countries — and the amendment would allow — led by the candidates Presidents of the Commission, would in effect create an area of European political debate. It is pointless for us to continue to say that we are talking only about national issues in the European elections. We say it continually. The way to talk about European elections is to have real European candidates, who somehow lead the debate at European level. It is not true that there is no European demos, today it is all full of movements — Pulse of Europe, Stand Up for Europe, Wake Up Europe, Civic Europe — that are independently moving to create this space European debate politician. So does Parliament want to do it, too? Do you want to hear the voice of the citizens of Europe who are asking to be able to speak about Europe with their own Members, including those who represent them and not just among themselves? I think this is the time. I do not understand how Mr Schöplin, who has so much been involved in the initiative of European citizens, does not understand that this is another instrument to give space and voice to those who want, on occasion of the European elections, talking about Europe and not their own national problems.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! I respect the rapporteurs, but I cannot support this report as it stands. First, I think we may have thought through not distributing places after the British. This would be a chance for Parliament to be more efficient, frugal and I think it would be met with a very good reception from the people. And the other issue is a special transnational constituency. Also here the ECR has a critical stance. There is an argument raised by Mr Schöpflin about properly forcible building of a political entity. Yesterday, Prime Minister Plenković rightly pointed out that, in such a constituency, an election campaign would be a sham. Once again, the idea of the Federalists, and actually the Federalists in a dogmatic variant, will be counterproductive. Instead of increasing the bond between MPs and citizens, it will weaken it and will, as a result, foster populism and Euroscepticism. Members of the European Parliament should be elected in Member States, they should be closer to citizens. Even if they represent all the people of the European Union, it should be a place of close union.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I want to thank the rapporteurs for their work, for their wisdom and for their patience in this long discussion. You may remember the former president of the European People’s Party who was my predecessor as Prime Minister of Belgium and who was, I can say quite easily, a very dedicated European, Wilfried Martens. Wilfried Martens was a true believer in and defender of transnational lists and he understood what was at stake: he understood that without a strong link between the citizens and Europe, eurosceptics and populists would in the end always win the game. And he understood that transnational lists will not alienate the citizen: quite the contrary. Why? Because, in the proposal that you have before you, people will have two votes. One vote is for a national candidate, for a national list, to keep the link between the citizen and his or her MEP; and a second vote is for transnational candidates, to strengthen the link between the citizen and the European Union. In my view, this is the only way to create what I call a European demos – which cannot arrive by accident, or spontaneously of itself – and I think it is also needed to make the Spitzenkandidaten process really democratic. Today the Spitzenkandidaten process is still undemocratic and non-transparent, a backroom deal within political parties or between political parties. What Spitzenkandidaten alone will not deliver, and what transnational lists will deliver because they complement the Spitzenkandidaten process, it is that it becomes a democratic process. It will be the people, the citizens, who will decide on the Spitzenkandidaten and the President of the Commission. I have not heard any serious arguments against it. People say federal states don’t have it: wrong! Federal states want it. My country, Belgium, is a federal state and many want a federal constituency. It is separatists who make war against it. A second example is the United States of America: a federal state. It’s because there is no single constituency that it is Mr Trump who is President and not Hilary Clinton, who received three million votes more than Donald Trump. Secondly, another argument I hear is that transnational lists are good for populists. I have to tell you that is also wrong. You could argue that democracy is only good for populists, so let’s abolish democracy and let’s abolish elections. I can tell you one thing: that’s nonsense. You have to beat the populists, not to fear them, and to do that you need transnational lists. The third argument, that transnational lists are only good for big Member States, is also wrong. No political party can afford to participate in elections without putting all the countries on the transnational list. What counts is not size, Mr Rangel, what counts is the vision, the passion, the commitment of all of us. That is what counts. And let us be honest about big Member States. Our colleagues from Spain, Poland, France, Italy and Germany today need at least double the number of votes received by us representatives of small and medium-sized Member States, but I nevertheless tabled, together with Pascal, an amendment to ensure that small and medium-sized Member States will be represented on the list. I am concluding. I know you’re a very tough President, Mr Wieland. Let’s not waste this historic opportunity. Brexit will never come back. Never again will we see half of the Member States in favour of this European constituency. And finally, Mr President, Altiero Spinelli, the father of this European Parliament, would turn in his grave if we missed this unique opportunity. (Applause)

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. On Monday, the Group of the European People's Party informed the press that the agreement it negotiated to reduce parliamentary seats after 2019 was a priority this week. This is called fake news. In reality, as is well known, the power of the disputed EPP was only enough to prevent the permanent system that was urgently needed for future seat distribution. This report also does not follow the widespread squint of Brexit's savings potential, but focuses on correcting the ongoing breach of law in the distribution of seats. I think that is right, and here I would also like to thank the two co-rapporteurs. Equity of distribution among Member States, transnational lists of political parties and movements, and future enlargement are the political keywords for which the potentially vacant British seats are to be used or parked, but not returned. That's right for me. For us as GUE/NGL, however, it was clear that the report had to take Brexit legally seriously, but the political process should be kept open. History is open, including to the people of the UK, including respect for the Good Friday Agreement. The compromise reached is pragmatic and politically sensible. But let us be honest: there would also have been an urgent need for a debate on the need to strengthen the democratic support of European policy, that is, on the possibility of how populations can make their voice heard with their interests and needs, and perhaps also on how the European Parliament — for example strengthened by the right of initiative — as an institution directly elected by citizens — can take over the organisation of its daily lives. But that was with the political... (The President withdrew the speaker.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have the responsibility to defend the general European interest. Yet each of us is elected in our national or even regional constituency, which may lead us to prioritize national or regional interests over that general interest. To take a concrete example, our common currency, the euro, in order to be viable, needs strong financial solidarity mechanisms between states, which obviously cannot go without responsible management of public affairs and expenditure. It is very easy today for a German candidate to defend responsibility in the German constituency as it is very easy for a Greek candidate to defend solidarity in the Greek constituency. The opposite is much more difficult, but that is what candidates running at European level will have to do. They will have to formulate and defend a project that can speak and convince not only in one country of the Union, but throughout the Union. This is the condition for a genuine democratic debate in Europe. The departure of British elected officials is an opportunity to give the debate this truly European dimension without abolishing seats at the national level, with transnational seats being added to and not substitute for national seats. Ladies and gentlemen, five years ago we also innovated by referring to the idea of “leading figures” candidates, the Spitzenkandidaten. Let us dare to innovate, once again, with this transnational constituency. Of course, these two swallows will not make the European democratic spring, but I am convinced that they will make a significant contribution to it.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are today called to perform a very delicate work and we must feel the full burden of responsibility that comes with The European Parliament is the only institution in the Union directly elected by the citizens. So let's talk about the direct representation of the latter. Britain's exit will leave 73 seats vacant within Parliament and my fellow rapporteurs, whom I thank, have made a proposal in the report to redistribute some of them, which appears to me fairly balanced judgment. But the great novelty introduced by the report is another. This is the allocation of some seats to a single constituency coinciding with the whole territory of the Union. Candidates divided into transnational lists would compete for these. As a 5 Star Movement we have always had puzzlement that the peoples of Europe are ready for a similar step, but we have decided to accept the challenge. Accept it yes, but provided that both this project and the Spitzenkandidaten make it possible to create true platforms for the aggregation of experiences from movements, including from civil society, and they are not exclusive party pannage. These lists cannot and should not become a parachute available to parties to make elected politicians no longer able to gather acclaim, but on the contrary they must constitute an opportunity for enlarging and strengthening democratic debate and citizens' ties with the European institutions and the integration process. This and nothing else must be for us the only real guiding beacon of the implementation of this reform, inescapably.

name: Georg Mayer
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party. I think you're holding it with George Orwell: all animals are the same, but some animals are more equal. So, for letting Mr Verhofstadt talk about the time for 50 seconds, I find quite remarkable when you turn others off after five seconds. In this context, there is always talk of proximity to the citizen. Colleagues, do you know what real proximity would have meant in this case? True proximity to the citizens would have meant saving the 73 seats that will be released after Brexit. That would have really done European citizens. Now, therefore, the plan — at least if the committee is concerned — is that 27 seats will be distributed among Member States and the other 46 seats vacant or vacant will be distributed on transnational lists. I am very curious to see how the Council sees the initiative of this House. I find it very difficult to imagine that this will be accepted there. Good, you can argue about the distribution of seats well and gladly. But if so, it would have been logical and right to allocate these vacant seats to all Member States as a whole. 46 seats on transnational lists — what does that mean? What do you mean brings you closer to the citizens? I think you're so mistaken when you come up with this. The consequence will be that these supposed 'top candidates' will ultimately only come from the large Member States, where there will then be de facto votes, with the result that these top candidates will be relatively unknown in the small Member States. Mr President, I think you're going to give me a few seconds now. But I do know which way this is going. This is heading towards the state. But I can tell you that: you could have learned that from Brexit — that is what the citizens do not want.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Mayer. Mr. Mayer, you approached me directly. If you were there more often, instead of just talking and then disappearing again, then you would notice that I have a fairly uniform practice and that everyone with me has a few seconds to the extent that he has speaking time. You can follow this very closely in the European Parliament archives. I am occasionally inattentive myself — nor am I perfect — and Mr Verhofstadt has been interrupted. In the first round of the debate — including you — I am somewhat milder anyway. At the end you have to get there by 12.00. The Presidents who follow me should also not be in shortness of breath and should be particularly strict in order to keep to the timetable. Feel free to go to the archives or have your employees check this!

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, the democratic decision to leave the European Union will be implemented in every region of the United Kingdom, including Northern Ireland. The Committee on Constitutional Affairs recommends that following the UK’s exit a number of parliamentary seats will be redistributed. This is, of course, a matter for the European Union. However, if, as some believe, Brexit was driven by a democratic deficit, then the inclusion of transnational lists in this report will only entrench that position further. Despite all of its grandstanding, Sinn Féin’s attempts to allocate three more seats to the Irish Republic to directly replace the seats lost when Northern Ireland leaves was rightly rejected in committee. That people living in Northern Ireland have a right to Irish citizenship, and therefore EU citizenship, is effectively a statement of fact, but to infer that this confers voting rights is a political stunt with no basis in law or reality. The EU Treaties make it clear that the rights of those holding an Irish passport do not include voting rights unless ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we fully support the composition and allocation of seats designed by the co—rapporteurs, but we are very worried about the transnational list political recommendations in this report. We have managed to build a sound and trustworthy democracy here in the European Union, where there is an equilibrium and balance between majorities and states. If we accept the constitutional Frankenstein monster that is the transnational list, we accept something that does not exist in any federal state, as Mr Verhofstadt has proved here today because he cannot give one example of it, not even in Belgium that has quite a similar system. If we are not a federation, why should we have a joint constituency that not even federations have? Do we really need, in order to build a democracy in the European Union, to have a top—down elite selected and co-opted by European parties, or – what is really very dangerous – put forward by European movements of national parties that can divide, even in regional terms, the European Union’s public sphere? Please think about it and vote against the transnational lists paragraph. (Applause)

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Today we have a chance to take a major step towards more European democracy. We want to give citizens two votes in the European elections: one for the existing national lists and then — new — a second vote for the transnational European lists. The European elections have a fundamental problem: they are not European elections. They are in prison for national election campaigns, national electoral lists, national electoral laws. We have witnessed it, Europe is second-class; it often does not happen at all because it is about domestic conflicts. I believe that 40 years after the introduction of direct elections, it is high time to take the next step and really to realise the European in the European elections. We now have European parties, but what can they do? - Nothing. You can't fight for mandates. That's why they're not real parties. We have a top candidate process where people can't even choose it. You can only choose it in your own country. The missing link is indeed the European list that the European parties can establish democratically and that citizens throughout the Union can elect their top candidates for the post of President of the Commission. It is astonishing that this Parliament took a decision on the European lists in 1998 — 20 years ago — by a very large majority, including across political families. It is somewhat sobering to see that 20 years later we do not take a step forward, but stagnate with arguments that were already there at the time, and at best take a step backwards. I believe that the Eurosceptics and opponents of Europe are right to oppose it because they smell that we are making a breakthrough here for European public, European election campaigns, the formation of a see political demos at European level. But the fact that the proponents of Europe here are against this irritates me. Mainly because I heard the small-minded argument that Macron would make a list of Europe en Marche and they didn't want that in 2019. How small and short-sighted!

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Mr President! It often happens when we have important votes in this Chamber that we are stormed with inquiries from citizens in the form of emails and letters and with all sorts of expressions from citizens who are concerned about the environment or the economy or whatever it may be. But right on this issue — the issue of transnational lists — there has been remarkably quiet. There are not yet, well, let's say many citizens who have found the inconvenience worth finding into the chamber here to follow this exciting debate. It must be said: the desire from the citizen side, from civil society is hardly overwhelming. That is why I must say: the argument made by several people in the Chamber that it should be a demand from Europeans to get the transnational lists, I find rather bizarre! The transnational lists are fundamentally un-European and undemocratic: unEuropean, because Europe is all the Member States of ours, where we have a lot that collects and something that divides. But where what collects is so much more! Where we know each other! Where we speak the same language! Where we might disagree! But where we have the prerequisites to be together to make tough decisions as well. And that is undemocratic, partly because it will lead to an A and a B membership here in the Parliament Hall, since the members who have to be elected on transnational lists will not have a member country, a national parliament to answer to, partly because it confronts the whole myth, narrative and identity that Europe is. That is why I hope, in the name of Europe, that this proposal will fall.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: Mr President, society will be very interested if transnational lists are implemented because many of the political things we know will change. Today we call again on the importance of a permanent system for the fair and transparent distribution of seats in the European Parliament. We do not have a system, and we leave the matter again for the future incomprehensively. This is the only bad news of this report because, at last, this proposal complies with the principle of decreasing proportionality and, of course, there is the question of transnational lists. To vote in favour of them is to vote in favour of restoring the spirit of European integration. To move towards a greater rapprochement of citizens to the institutions with Europeanism, I think, if it comes out, very active. It means moving towards overcoming the sum of national legislation. It's thinking big. I would like to congratulate those responsible for the report, and it does not have risks; we can carry out this operation, evaluate it, and only fear would paralyze us.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – The joint report on Brexit from December says that the people of the North of Ireland ‘who are Irish citizens will continue to enjoy rights as EU citizens where they reside’. It also states there will be ‘no diminution of rights’, recognising that ‘rights, safeguards and equality of opportunity’ are important provisions of the Good Friday Agreement and our peace process. Only 50 years ago, the Civil Rights Association in the North was campaigning for the right to vote. The Brexit DUP/Tory agenda will result in the fundamental denial of people’s right to vote. In my lifetime, our rights have been denied by Unionism and by the British government, and only recently the Taoiseach said that we in the North will never again be left behind. So, the Dublin government and the EU must stand up for, and with, the people of the North of Ireland and make sure that the North of Ireland has seats in the European elections.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE).
text: — Mr President, we have two issues of democracy today in order to change the functioning of Europe. The first is that of a fairer representation of States. I believe that we all agree to ensure that States are better represented in Parliament. But a second topic is open to us today. It is that of the single European constituency, that of the concrete implementation, here and now, of the common destiny of 500 million Europeans and Europeans. That Europe of walls, barbed wire, far-right nations opposes this modification is coherent and logical. But I turn to my pro-European colleagues, those who defend a Europe without borders for goods, goods, finance, flows, and those who want a free Europe. How can it be that, in front of this Europe, they do not want to create a Europe of democracy, a Europe of citizens, a Europe of the general European interest that goes beyond the Europe of national interests. We must build for the millions of people who elect us here this area of general European interest that goes beyond national interests, that is that of a common destiny beyond a hymn, beyond a flag, which is that of a democratic space that wants to proudly live its values, proudly its ability to carry in the world the strength of a united Europe. No, it is not Paris, Berlin or Warsaw that should lead the European Union, it is Europe itself that has to take control of itself. Do not be afraid, do not be afraid, make sure that we are proud to have a united and diverse Europe.

name: Jörg Meuthen (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. We are talking here about the future distribution of the 73 seats of British MEPs after their departure from the European Parliament. I note three points about this: First, this is where the bear's fur is distributed before it even shot. Secondly, if a Member State leaves, it is logical that the number of seats in the European Parliament must be reduced accordingly. There is nothing to redistribute, it is to be deleted. But this is explicitly rejected, the self-service mentality here is limitless. Thirdly, Germany will run empty with the planned redistribution of vacant seats. This means that German citizens remain the worst represented citizens in the Strasbourg Assembly. This European Parliament is constantly teaching lessons in democracy, but it is clear that it does not meet the demands it places on others. I call on the German Government not to accept the non-deletion of all British seats or the distribution key chosen, and to block both in the Council. The systematic disadvantage of German citizens in the European Parliament must end. There is no time to address the mischief of transnational lists here. It is centralist and citizen-distant noncreuity. point.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: — Mr President, everyone knows that Europe needs to be reformed, but we are talking about something else here, we are not discussing how to reform. Instead, we are concerned about dividing the prey after Brexit. With all due respect, we find ourselves in a situation which, in Romania, would be characterized as “putting the cart before the horses”. Therefore, the first criticism I want to bring is that this is about reversing priorities. So I do not think that the seats of the United Kingdom need to be filled before deciding the future of the European Union. It is simpler, more economical and more honest towards our citizens. Secondly, the proposal of the AFCO committee is very similar to the apple offered to Eve by the biblical serpent. Combining the redistribution of places with so-called transnational lists may seduce under-represented Member States, but it is, in reality, a manoeuvre that severely deters democracy and representation of citizens.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, welcome to the European Union’s 2018 incarnation of Georgia Orwell’s 1984. This proposal completes the end-stage of the European Union project – national sovereignty smothered and, finally, the first open, and equally transparent, step towards a truly federalist Europe with a political governing body, with seats given to unelected, unselected MEPs occupying those transnational seats. The goal of the United States of Europe as a concept is well documented. The extinguishing of national sovereignty is also well recognised. We now have absolute clarity, though, with this proposal and the dangerous and thoroughly anti-democratic suggestion of getting to that objective via transnational seats. The European Union openly questions and frequently questions itself, asking why there is a democratic deficit among Member States. You’ve only got to look to this report and the detail within it to answer that question.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Mr President! First of all, we are pleased that an agreement has obviously been reached for the future regular distribution of seats in the event that the British really leave. We would have liked even fewer Members, but we also see that imbalances and injustices can now be compensated. Three points for the future: firstly, we must finally adopt a formula that will make the distribution of seats predictable in the long term and which will also stand up legally. Secondly, at some point, the EU states with significant population declines will also have to accept that fewer MEPs will have to be there with a smaller population. Thirdly, transnational lists must not come. These lists are a gateway for populists like Wilders or Le Pen. I really wonder: why are we making it easier for well-known but radical opponents of Europe to enter Parliament, and why are we moving further and further away from the people and their problems? Seriously, do we seriously believe that the notables of a transnational list or radicals from the left and right, seriously believe that these rulers are concerned with the problems in the regions, about small and medium-sized enterprises, about conditions in agriculture or about how money from the Social Fund really gets to the needy ? This will only be marginally interested in these transnational superpoliticians — if at all. This is how we generate a political art world that is not interested in details and not in constituency work. That is why we should oppose the transnational lists... (The President withdraws the speaker from the speaker.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate the two rapporteurs, because I sincerely believe that a very interesting and very appropriate report has been made. First, because it reduces the number of seats; secondly, because it makes up for those countries that were badly treated; and thirdly, because no country loses. But I would like to refer to the most passionate debate — we say — on transnational lists by giving you my opinion that I sincerely believe that a European constituency, that Europeans' double vote is good. Because I'm a Europeanist. I think it is better for Europe, to do more Europe, to make Europe better and to improve European democracy. Allow me a simple historical reflection. Founding father Jean Monnet said that Europe would be done step by step. And that's how it was. When the European Union was created there was no Parliament, ladies and gentlemen. It was created later. The European Parliament was a step in European construction. Members of the national parliaments came to that Parliament. They were not elected by citizens, but Members of the national parliaments. The next step was indeed elections throughout Europe. A day to elect the European Parliament, European sovereignty. This step we are taking today, ladies and gentlemen, is a step, as Jean Monnet would say, to build Europe. It's so there's a double vote. For citizens to connect with the European idea, and hopefully a Spitzenkandidat will head every political family to elect the President of the Commission. That is building Europe. For me, the step we are taking is an extraordinarily important political signal in favour of this idea that is gradually being built. It's a long story, but it's a beautiful story. It is a wonderful story of building, upon nations, a space of peace and progress. And today we are taking a step with this political signal which calls on the Council to grant in European electoral law the possibility of Europeans to vote in the country two lists, the national and the European.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: Mr President! I very much regret that my British colleagues will no longer be in this House in the near future, and I reject Parliament's plans to redistribute some of these seats now, rather than simply omitting them completely. The new distribution of seats is increasingly distorting the weight of votes to the detriment of my country — Germany. In the future, German citizens will be the worst represented country in the EU. A Maltese citizen is worth about 12 times to the EU as much as a German. I find it even more surprising, however, that all German colleagues in committee also agreed to this disadvantage of their own country in committee. I assume that most German colleagues will do the same here today in plenary. The distribution of seats will continue to weaken the position of the Germans. With the British, therefore, not only will we lack an important voice of reason here in the European Union, we will be able to oppose all the wishes of centralisation, all wishes for European taxes, European finance ministers, a banking union, deposit insurance and so on. That is why the message for Germany must be not to provide the EU with any further competences or additional financial resources. The sling course to a new old grand coalition in my country, however, makes me fear bad here.

name: Charles Goerens (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, this time the European Parliament can approach the debate on its future composition in complete serenity, at least as regards the first part of the proposal. Indeed, the principle of degressive proportionality, as applied in this proposal, reflects the legislature's desire to have an assembly that is both fair and respectful of the imperative of the representation of the main political currents in all Member States. Let us add that the task was facilitated by this accident in the history of Brexit. At the same time, this is a unique opportunity to make progress in establishing a transnational list. I would like to wish the members of the Council of the Union to have the height of views that could make this democratic breakthrough a great success. Many of us vote in favour of this text with a view to convincing those governments which, for some reason or another, but at least not necessarily for a European reason, still express reservations about this.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, what is at stake in this debate is much more than so-called transnational lists, an artificial creation based on a federalist vision that has nothing to do with the reality of Europe and which runs counter to the need for a Europe of cooperation between sovereign states and equal rights. But you don't want to turn transnational lists into a screen to hide everything else. And everything else is a proposal for the composition of the European Parliament which prolongs existing imbalances, which reduces the possibilities for more faithful representation, because more plural, of the will of each people, which aggravates injustices relating to giving up the possibility of compensating, as was possible and fair, certain Member States. Members for the loss of Members during enlargements. The amendments we have tabled to the report aim to correct these imbalances and the unjustified discrimination against countries such as Portugal. By resuming the discussion on a fairer basis, and even within the framework of the rules laid down in the Treaty, it is possible to arrive at a fair and acceptable proposal, which is neither fair nor acceptable.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, transnational lists are an important step in the process towards a single European constituency. Having the opportunity to vote for a list with candidates from different Member States helps to create in the imagination of citizens a sense of European general interest and a feeling of belonging. Transnational lists can open the window to the creation of solidarity and a redistribution of wealth and can reinforce the idea of a European public sphere. All in all, we are debating something that can strengthen democracy. We have an opportunity to reinvigorate the European project and to rethink it, especially from a bottom-up perspective – for instance, by allowing Member States to assign seats to regions having legislative powers. This is today the case in the Åland Islands and tomorrow it could be the case in others. It is a matter of political will. Today, the European Parliament has a chance to deliver a beneficial, transformative proposal.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, we have a debate today about picking over the carcass of the folly of UK Membership of the EU. We see all sorts of solutions and ideas being put forward to split up the seats that the UK will thankfully be vacating. The real thing that should be happening here is that those seats should be left empty. The truth of the matter is that when you put forward ideas such as transnational lists what you actually do is take the semblance, the pretence, of democracy even further from the citizens. It is hard enough to get around a huge region like my own in the West Midlands and to be seen, and to let people know they have got a representative. Do you really think you can represent people in different countries on the same mandate? It is, frankly, impossible and it takes it further and further from the people. Of course, what has been achieved by the negotiations between the EU and the nest of traitors in the UK Government is a period called the transitional period where, during that time, EU rules and regulations will apply. British taxpayers’ money will still come to the EU but we will have no representation whatsoever. These seats should remain empty as a monument to the absolute betrayal of democracy and of the British people that is taking place.  This could not be further from the dream of governance for the people, by the people, of the people. It is not happening. The demos is not there. This is not democratic. You look to bring people to a parliament where, if there is any semblance of debate you have to hold up a card. It is then up to the President on the day whether or not it is accepted, and then it is up to the person to whom you are asking the question whether they are prepared to answer the question. How on earth can you kid anyone that this is democracy?  Quite frankly, the people of the United Kingdom have seen what is going on and this year we, the people, in the United Kingdom, will rise and in a democratic revolution we will say no to this, no to taxation without representation, and no to further treatment of the UK as a vassal state of the EU. The time is coming.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: — Mr President, the European Parliament currently has 751 members. Brexit will release the UK's 73 seats in 2019. I think we should avoid redistributing those 73 seats in order to save money and reduce the number to 678 Members. I am therefore opposed to the European Union's plan to redistribute some of these 73 seats to the 27 Member States. While this project plans to give France five more seats, I am not prepared to sacrifice my principles for such a dish of lentils, because this project deeply strikes my nationalist convictions by planning, on the other hand, to create transnational lists. However, I am against transnational lists because they would be another step towards transforming the European Union into a federal state disconnected from national realities. It is a Europe of nations that we need, not a supranational Europe.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think we should actually acknowledge that today is a sad day for the European Parliament. I want to say on the record that I, for one, will miss the constructive engagement with many colleagues from the United Kingdom, who are in the ECR Group, the S&D Group, the ALDE Group and the Greens. We will miss their efforts to do good by the European Union and we should acknowledge that today. Mr Etheridge, I am not so sure I will weep tears for your departure. It may well be the opposite. But let me say something much more directly to you, as you have stayed in the Chamber. You were questioning how Members from one Member State could talk for citizens in another country. Well, if we did not have the support in Ireland from colleagues across this House on the Northern Ireland hard border issue, we would be in a difficult place. You were not thinking of the possibility of a hard border when you voted and pushed for Brexit. We needed the support of Members of this House from all Member States – not UKIP. You are creating problems for my country.  Let me be calm again. I welcome that we will get two extra seats for Ireland in the redistribution of seats. On transnational lists, I have listened to this debate and my God it is passionate on either side. My Taoiseach last month supported the transnational list and perhaps it comes down to this: it is a concept, but maybe it is not of its time now. However, Mr Etheridge, I like the idea that colleagues from one country will speak up for citizens in other Member States. (Applause)

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: — Mr President, dear colleagues, after months of tough and complicated negotiations in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, here we are in the plenum of the European Parliament for the final vote. Congratulations to my fellow rapporteurs! Colleagues, with the UK leaving the European Union, it has become a priority for us to find a fair and representative redistribution of mandates for a European Union of 27 Member States. Therefore, the proposal put forward for the vote today represents a pragmatic compromise, a compromise that can compensate for the imbalances in the current voting system, whereby 14 countries are underrepresented. Speaking now as a Romanian MEP, I think it is natural for Romania to receive an additional mandate. As one of the most important countries in the Eastern European region, Romania deserves a representation in relation to its status, the sixth most important demographically country in the European Union after the exit of Great Britain. Last but not least, this is a repair for the loss suffered in 2014, with the accession of Croatia. Colleagues, if we want this parliamentary term to be remembered by its achievements and achievements, then we must give European citizens a viable solution, which will also bring legal certainty about the conduct of elections. I therefore urge all national delegations to support this new mandate redistribution formula with a positive vote in order to avoid possible bottlenecks or ad hoc solutions ahead of the 2019 elections. We will have a European Parliament of 705 members, based on the principle that no country will lose a mandate, but also on the principle that certain repairs must be made for states that did not have a representation directly proportional to their size and importance. Yes, Mr. President, I have two minutes. Let us not forget, however, that this report is about the composition of Parliament European and not exclusively about transnational lists, and I regret that the debate has been overtaken by this issue. So, colleagues, I urge you to go home and guide your governments to make the right decision at the negotiating table that will take place later at the level of the Council of the European Union.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: Mr President, I find it incomprehensible that we are having this discussion here today. The British are leaving the European Union. A smaller Union therefore also means a smaller European Parliament. It's as simple as that. But no, apparently 27 of these seats have to go to a transnational electoral list. If we were to remove all seats, we would save EUR 30 million in taxpayers' money a year. Thirty million euros that we can spend on jobs, security and tackling migration. I also hear say here that this European electoral list would bring Europe closer to its citizens. I have my doubts about that. People now hardly know who is on their own electoral lists, let alone that they would vote for a Frenchman, a Bulgarian or an Est. Finally, I would like to speak to Mr Guy Verhofstadt. I hear him say that Belgium would want a federal constituency, but only the separatists are opposed. Well, Koen Geens of CD&V — hardly to be called a separatist — is not willing to take the idea either. (The speaker answered a blue card question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: the question of the blue card. — Mr President, the recent speaker suggested that as the number of Member States of the Union decreases, this Parliament will decrease, and that is what this proposal at the bottom will do. Not all places are allocated here, so savings can also be made. My country Finland has been a member now for just over 20 years, and when we started, there were 17 of us and now there are 13 of us. This division of seats would give us one more seat, and yet it is perfectly logical also still in terms of how many people one mep represents. It was just suggested from the same political group that Germany does not get more seats here and Malta has double the number of representation. I hope your group's position is not so that there should only be half a representative or zero representatives from Malta. I think it's important that this kind of proportionality is maintained here. The presentation is entirely logical on its basis.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: “blue card” -answer. — Thank you very much for your question. This is about the whole system of degressive proportionality. In my opinion, we can perfectly apply a correction mechanism based on the current number minus the 73 seats. We can look at that number again in order to adjust the errors in degressive proportionality in this way. But I don't think we should use those British seats for that.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: - Mr President! When Finland became independent 100 years ago, there was a problem concerning the cultural autonomy of Åland. It was resolved in 1921 by the League of Nations, perhaps one of the few things the League of Nations managed to solve at all, and it has guaranteed the Autonomy of Ålandic and its development. When Finland then became a member of the European Union, some of the powers were transferred from the Ålandic self-government to the EU, which meant that the dependents had fewer chances and less opportunity to influence the decision-making process. For that reason, we are now calling for an electoral system that would give these self-governing regions a better opportunity to defend their interests. At the same time, we would like to remind all Members present that in Europe there are around 50 minorities, most of them ill-treated by their central states. It is, therefore, really about creating a more functional and orderly democracy within the European Union.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, we welcome the fact that steps have been made towards a more proportional allocation of seats between different countries and we are therefore voting in favour of this report. However, we believe that we must be much more ambitious, that the main problems facing this Parliament and citizenship are not the number of seats or how these seats are elected, but the lack of real democracy in the European institutions. We need more powers for the European Parliament, which is the only body directly elected by Europeans and Europeans. If we want to combat citizens' disaffection towards the European project, what we really need are social and economic proposals that improve people's lives, such as fiscal harmonisation, European basic income, effective combat tax havens or putting the European Central Bank under social control. Today marks the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Maastricht Treaty. A real neoliberal sabotage of the European project. There is an urgent need to take a 180-degree shift in European policies and not simply be content with cosmetic reforms.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: — Mr President, our Committee on Constitutional Affairs has proposed that a quota of 27 seats be reserved for transnational lists. This innovation seems to me to be scum, but it can allow Europe to progress in democracy under three conditions. The first is to take advantage of this number to specify in the electoral law that each list must include one citizen of each Member State, and only one. The second is that each European political family commits itself to putting its top candidate (Spitzenkandidat) at the head of its transnational list — this seems obvious. The third, finally, that each government undertakes to propose as a first choice as Commissioner from its own country the citizen on the list who will win the most votes at home. Basically, the transnational list would thus be the list of commissioner candidates and it was the popular vote that would designate the composition of the executive body rather than the governments in place. The governments proposing the transnational list swear to us that it is for the good of Europe, but is their democratic commitment ready to go so far?

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: — Mr President, dear co-rapporteurs, congratulations, because you are proposing to this House a report that allows us to have a new, fairer balance between the Member States, which means more legitimacy for our institution. You are reducing the overall number of members, which is normal since unfortunately we lose the UK. You also allow no Member State to lose seats, you are planning a reservation for future enlargements, and you confirm Parliament's position in favour of a transnational list, which we can finally implement on the occasion of the regretted departure of the United Kingdom. My regret is that we have once again missed the appointment of a permanent seat allocation mechanism. It will be for our successors. With this report, it seems to me that the European Parliament is sending the Council a twofold message that is extremely strong. I invite us to look at the result of the roll-call to be made on Article 3 of the Annex, the one which allocates seats among Member States. The proposal of our co-rapporteurs is not an outbid, it is balanced, and the Council would have every interest in keeping it as it is, without reopening bargaining between boyfriends. Then, the other strong message is the issue of transnational lists. Everyone has in their mouth the idea of more European democracy. The beating heart of this European democracy is here. What better translation of this democracy than transnational lists? However, I urge the Member States that support this idea of transnational lists to a minimum of consistency. Transnational lists go hand in hand with candidates for commissioners or presidential candidates, the famous top candidates (Spitzenkandidaten). I hope that this message will be strongly supported by this House and heard by the Council.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: — Mr President, if a country accedes to the European Union, the number of Members automatically increases. If a country leaves the European Union, it turns out that public spending knows only one direction. And that's upwards. This is because most politicians like to spend strangers' money. And since these politicians are the majority, even the greatest stupidity will be approved on a regular basis. There will be a €9 billion shortfall in the EU budget after Brexit. It is therefore logical and correct for the number of MPs to drop by 73. These are the ones who represent Great Britain today. As far as those common European candidates are concerned, it is not possible to represent the interests of citizens of Portugal and Finland at the same time. Just as it is impossible to do a single monetary policy for Greece and for Germany.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I will first of all congratulate Mr Hübner and Mr Silva Pereira on their report. We see that the composition of the European Parliament is a somewhat delicate operation, especially since we are confronted with this regrettable exit from the United Kingdom, which also poses a constitutional problem. First of all, I would like to welcome the fact that the redistribution of some of the UK mandates will take into account what I have requested by amendments in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, that is, to take into account the Member States that lost mandates in 2014. I am glad to see that, in accordance with this report, my country, Romania, will return to 33 mandates. Secondly, I would like to say that, unlike some of my colleagues, I am in favour of transnational lists. I think this gives meaning to European citizenship. Basically, the parties that currently exist are not real European parties. We can have real European parties if we have lists that are not only made up of candidates from a single Member State. In a parliament, parties exist before elections. We have made the idea — as at the beginning of politics in the 19th century — that parties exist only at the level of parliamentary groups. Let us go beyond that threshold, do what national policy did in the 19th century for Europe, that is the meaning of our commitments.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. The report is pragmatic, it is democratic, it is European and, above all, it takes concerns seriously. I am glad that the distribution of seats will be fairer in the future. Austria will have one more seat and the representation relationship is right again. We are all citizens of the European Union. We have common European interests: social, economic, fiscal and foreign policy — that can be continued. In order to safeguard these common European interests, we must also think and act at European level; the transnational list of European interests contributes to this. Article 14 (2) of the EU Treaty states that the European Parliament is a body representing the citizens of the Union. A pan-European constituency, cross-border European electoral programmes can help to revive this concept of European citizenship — and thus European democracy.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, my fellow Members. I have five points. We welcome the new distribution of seats proposed in the report after the UK's departure. Fewer citizens in the EU mean fewer mandataries and fairer distribution. Secondly, we say yes to the top candidate model. It has the President of the Commission, it has the Commission, it has strengthened the European Parliament, and it has increased the influence of citizens on the President of the Commission. We all benefited from this. There must be no step backwards from the 2014 decisions. Thirdly, the report continues the path of strengthening European democracy through the creation of a European electoral area and through the European List Initiative. European democracy is much more than the sum of local, regional and national democracies. There is a separate model of democracy. I therefore welcome the supplementary introduction of European lists, basic mandates on national lists, additional remaining votes and second votes on European lists. Fourthly, however, the European lists should be linked to the creation of European parties — we are a European party and parliamentary democracy. Fifthly and finally, I regret that we are discussing the model of European lists only theoretically because the legal basis is still lacking and there is no clear model on the table. (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Monika Beňová (S&D).
text: — Mr President, colleagues and colleagues, there is such a saying that we are cutting a bear that is still running up the mountain. I am very sorry if it comes to the fact that the UK will actually leave the European Union, and I will be sorry for all my colleagues, including those who have not always had positive attitudes on common European topics. I am also looking forward to the fact that one of the 27 posts will be received by the Slovak Republic. We had thirteen deputies, we will have fourteen. Although I personally do not see much progress on whether the country has one more or less MP. It is more about the quality and readiness of Members to discuss and address the problems that we have together in the European Union. Let me briefly comment on the transnational or common European candidate. Colleagues, in an EU in which we are unwilling to accept that Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia are full members if we are unable to admit them to the common Schengen area, in the European Union, where employees in the same businesses in other countries earn one third less , it is absolutely pointless and virtual to talk about a common candidate for the European Parliament.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start my remarks with a number, a symbolic figure which, for you, does not mean much, but which for me means a lot. That figure is 589, my place in the Chamber. This place, I didn't choose it. Indeed, in this House we are elected each in our country, but we do not sit by country. We sit by political affinity and, within our political groups, we also do not sit by national delegation, we sit alphabetically. If each Member has their own nationality, each of us is also the representative of all the citizens of our Union. That is why I defend the transnational lists, which are in the genes of the EPP, to which I belong. I am so that our fellow citizens, during the European elections, can both vote for a national list brought by a national party and, at the same time, vote for a European list carried by a European party on European political guidelines. To give our fellow citizens two ballots is not to take them out of power, it means giving them twice as much. It's more democratic. As for the idea that transnational lists would favour extremes, it reminds me of those doctors who would try to cure the fever by breaking the thermometer. No, it is by talking to our fellow citizens, trying to convince them and getting results that we will bring down the fever, not by preventing them from using two ballots.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in the interests of public support for the European Union, it is essential that the EU becomes more democratic and more political, and breaks away from the old combination of legalistic bureaucracy and backroom deals. To be fair, the report under discussion has this in mind, but it is limited in its opportunities: it only addresses the British seats. Should one really start a discussion on European democracy with the implementation of degressive proportionality or with the reserving of a handful of seats? I would say no. Should one start a discussion on the consequences of Brexit, keeping in mind that the UK is a net contributor, with a claim for more seats in the European Parliament? I have to say no again. Despite all good intentions, this report does not help us in the discussion on European democracy or on Brexit. For the Dutch delegation of Socialists and Democrats, the Spitzenkandidat process is far more important. Having said all that, I very much appreciate the efforts by the rapporteurs, Ms Hübner and Mr Pereira.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: — Mr. President, I want to thank Mrs. Danuta Hübner and Silva Pereira for this report because it was very delicate. I am glad that, given there are fewer citizens, there are also fewer MPs and that is just and fairer. This time Croatia returned to number 12, which it had in 2013, and that's why I want to thank the creators of this report. However, the debate goes in the direction of transnational lists. Personally, I consider the concept good, however, at the moment I do not see that we are ready for this concept neither politically nor financially nor organizationally. Likewise, I would be right up for this concept today if all countries were in the Eurozone and all countries were in the Schengen zone. Since this is not a situation, then I think that we should wait until we all get the same rights in some way and thus become transnationally recognizable so that we can run as well as those from large countries that are recognizable.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Mr President, my one question concerning the making of adjustments to the seating arrangements in this Parliament is this: as a result of these adjustments, will European citizens feel more committed to this Parliament? At present, they are not. This Parliament and its Members project too distant an image among our constituents. Participation in the last three elections dropped to close to 43%. Given Brexit and the openings for EU enlargement, the proposal to maintain national entitlements for seats is the right thing, but then the proposal also is to create new transnational constituencies in order to bring Parliament closer to the voters. This approach will have the opposite effect. It will continue to dislocate perceptions about the European Parliament away from the daily concerns of citizens, especially in smaller Member States. Being asked to vote for people they do not know or care about on party lists that cross country borders will sound like a gimmick. Chosen by political groups, these MEPs will only be accountable to their party chiefs, generating a greater distance between voters and elected MEPs. This distance can probably only be eliminated if Members of this House are directly elected and not through their position on party lists whether national or – least of all – transnational.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Mr President, after Brexit we need to adjust the composition of the European Parliament and I agree with the reduction of seats to 705 and the redistribution of 27 mandates among those Member States that have so far had a lower number of seats than they would fairly care for. But what I fundamentally disagree with is multinational candidate lists. It looks tempting. Citizens will have two votes. But I consider it a dangerous game that we are not prepared for. It is already difficult for our citizens to identify with elected representatives in the European Parliament. Moreover, it is obvious that multinational charters favor big countries. Campaigning for multinational candidates could lead to manipulation and simplification. We experienced this in the last presidential campaign. Colleagues and colleagues, four words on billboards were enough to close victory for the populist candidate. If our aim is to bring the European Union closer to citizens, transnational charters lead in quite the opposite direction. I'm sorry. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: 'Blue Card' question. — (NL) Mr President, I have heard very few substantive arguments from the opponents here today why they are opposed to these transnational lists. All I hear is that there may be deception, the voter is not involved. I think that the electorate is a little more involved in these transnational lists. The arguments you quoted are equally valid. Let us be honest, if we are to do our work properly in this Parliament and to find genuine European solutions to European challenges, then we need a European constituency. You're afraid of change. Fear is a bad counselor, my father taught me. Let us take our work seriously and go for those transnational lists.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by picking up the blue card. — I didn't hear the question, I heard there that we were afraid. Madam colleague, I am not afraid, I am in no way afraid and do not consider myself your opponent, because I want the European Parliament to be elected democratically. To get everyone involved. So that all citizens know who and why they are voting. And that's the problem. If I'm worried about anything, then it's populism, then it's simplification, then it's those campaigns that unfortunately we're experiencing. One Brexit was enough for me, lady colleague.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the creation of transnational lists would be a sign of a more united Europe, but let us not stick to appearances. First, we need a pan-European social policy, a pan-European fiscal policy and a pan-European vision of our foreign policy. Do we want to show our citizens that the European Parliament has a real European dimension? Yes, we do, but in order to be credible we must show a European dimension in their everyday lives. Look at the turnout at the last European elections. There was a decrease of 20% compared with the first elections in 1979. Last time it was only 42% across the EU. Will transnational lists change that figure? Will they give our citizens more trust in the EU as a whole? That is what we have to ask ourselves before we work for the new electoral proposal. We have to ask ourselves another question too, colleagues. How will the electoral campaigns of this new pan-European constituency be financed and are we really sure we are able to guarantee democratic oversight of this financing? When we have sensibly answered these questions, and when we start a real discussion, we will also have to start the discussion in our national parliaments.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. Transnational lists are a fall against federalism. It is not for nothing that all federal states do not have national lists because they do not want to express centralism because they want to be close to the citizens. I do not want to be included on a list from Helsinki to Lisbon, where no citizen sees me as his point of contact. I want to be in East Westphalia-Lippe, I want to be elected at home. Legitimation comes from proximity to the citizens and not remotely, and this is the crucial point for any Parliament. We need to make it clear that the top candidate process is the way to support European ideas in a campaign across Europe; this needs to be strengthened. The leading candidate leads the citizen to see the European head of government through the European elections. This cannot be done by the 27 people on the transnational list, but this must be decided by the 705 Members elected by the local citizen. This is, I believe, a matter of great legitimacy, and if I bear in mind that a number of heads of government who are in favour of transnational lists are, however, opposed to the top candidate, then it means that in this way the transnational lists are an alibi event on the weakness of Europe and to the disenfranchisation of the Citizens lead to focus on the 27 people who do not matter here. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – The European Parliament is probably the most important democratic institution of the European Union. Don’t you think that, through these elections, we ought to send the important message that we need more cohesion inside the European Union? Then we could make the switch to transnational lists. We can see currently that the eurozone represents a hard core of the European Union, while there are still countries that are not members of the eurozone, not members of Schengen, and so on and so forth. Don’t you think that we ought to wait a bit for more cohesion, and then move on to the next step?

name: Elmar Brok (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — I believe that citizens must vote in their constituencies, in their regions, and that this brings us together in this House, in the group, in order to safeguard common European interests. And that we must make sure that the citizens' decision on the ground helps us to have a Commission President, a head of government, who comes from the will of these citizens on the ground and not from an artificial event of 27 people from collection movements so that the President and Prine Ministers here can this House can manipulate and give us alibi events.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to start with a note of work, because behind these 73 seats are the faces of so many colleagues, friends of the United Kingdom. This is a sad side of Brexit. The balanced report reduces Parliament's seats and improves proportionality and above all paves the way for the introduction of transnational lists that will help strengthen the quality of democracy European. Today we have a gap, we measure it, between the European dimension of policies needed to address our problems and the national segmentation of the politics debate, politics. Spitzenkandidat helps to reduce this gap, but if it is not supported by a genuine Europeanisation of the electoral debate in this house, it will be insufficient, because we know that the citizens then do not have voted as much knowing who the Spitzenkandidat was, whether it was Juncker or if it was Schulz, but they voted based on a national political discussion. Thus, a transnational list that adds to local ones will strengthen the European dimension of our common area. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: Question under the blue card procedure. — (PT) Madam President, briefly, just to ask how the quality of European Union democracy is strengthened by transnational lists where only the representatives of a few countries will be elected, invariably the largest who, as it is human nature and the the size of the countries, they therefore control the essence of the political groups. The first of these lists will be elected on a transnational list. Do you really believe that the representatives of the small and medium countries of the European Union will be at the top of these lists? That's the question I leave you.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D)
text: answer to a “blue card” question. — It is not written anywhere what the order of the lists will be and it would be wise and intelligent of all European political parties to have a representation balanced. Today we have a President of the Commission who comes from Luxembourg and so frankly this does not seem to me to be a sensible subject. It is what an Italian philosopher called “fear of dangers”, always seeing the risk more than the opportunity for change, which, moreover, is added to a very limited extent, an electoral mechanism based on degressive proportionality, which currently and rightly overrepresents minor countries.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (S&D).
text: Madam President! I support the report and, above all, I hope that the proposal to introduce transnational lists will receive a majority today, because I am convinced that transnational lists are good for European democracy. I very much regret that my colleague Elmar Brok, whom I very much appreciate, is no longer in the Chamber at the moment. I must say that his arguments, as well as those of others here today, did not convince me at all. I heard a radio interview this morning where Mr Brok says that citizens need to know who to call and who they could write emails or letters to. That would be the reference, so to speak, to the Member of Parliament on the ground, and he would only like to be elected in Westphalia-Lippe. I get letters, citizens call me not only from Berlin, but from all over Germany. I also get emails and letters from all over Europe because citizens know our addresses. They know that we decide their concerns here, and they write to us and contact us. I think that in the case of transnational lists, Mr Brok could just as much continue to run on the national list, namely in the East Westphalian lip, or on the transnational list. That's his decision.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: — Today we have heard a lot of good arguments for and against transnational lists, “spicencandidates”, as well as about constituencies.
