I would like to point out that this direct contact between the elected and the electoral body is extremely important. I come from a relatively small municipality, from the east of Slovenia, with about 2500 people. And even this small local community is not a single constituency, but for the sake of keeping MPs in touch with their voters split into three constituencies. That logic seems very important to me. Such a unitaristic view of democracy, assuming that democracy is merely a contest of political elites for votes, doesn't seem right to me. Democracy is a significantly broader notion, but it is primarily based on a responsible commitment, a link between the one who is elected and the one who is elected.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, of course, it was a very complicated report. I want to congratulate the rapporteurs on the balance they have brought, but I cannot fail to refer to two things. The one related to the assignment: we wish it wasn't a Brexit and we didn't have the opportunity to distribute it. It is difficult to explain that the principle of degressive proportionality has been fully respected, if we look that countries like Greece, the Czech Republic have not received one and other countries of close size have received three. But there has been a lot of talk about transnational lists, although the rapporteurs say very explicitly here that we do not have a legal basis yet. I believe that we need to go back home to ourselves, to discuss in our national parliaments, with our citizens, because, yes, it is a good vision, perhaps, of the future, but are the citizens ready? And I have another question for the rapporteur, I may answer when they conclude: will there be two categories of MEPs? Because I now know that I represent all European citizens, not just those in my country. Will we have first-degree and second-degree MEPs?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: — Madam President, first of all, if we are to have transnational ballots, there must be a single European public space. This does not exist, at least at the moment, especially since there is no common language. Secondly, we are talking about a huge constituency, which is supposed to vote for candidates who - I am sure - will not even know them, and the ones who are supported will of course be the big parties; those who can finance. So, in practice, interests will also enforce regulation. Thirdly, this is not a transnational ballot, but a transnational list, that is, a list to be drawn up by whom? From the European political parties. From what parties? From bureaucracy, from leaders, from party bosses. They will create them, because there are no members of the European political parties; they are party parties; they are bureaucracy. So it will be an undemocratic choice.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: Madam President, building the European Union, making it a global actor, requires movements in two directions. Upward we need to strengthen the European demos that exists, which unites us. And transnational lists are a good idea, because they convey and represent the spirit of what we are building. A Union in which there are policies that need a global approach, actions that will gain in cohesion by strengthening political organisations at European level, perceived and acting as such. That is why we support this proposal and the principle that each of these lists should be headed by a candidate from each political family without a national name. It's the best way to turn a problem like brexit into an opportunity. But similarly, that integration must be inspired by our Union's motto — 'United in Diversity' — and built from the bottom up from the institutions closest to its citizens. That is why the amendment signed by the chairman of our group, Guy Verhofstadt, is a good idea, which opens the door to ensuring the presence, also here, of regions with legislative powers.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: — Madam President, the European Parliament is the only European body, the only institution that is elected directly by the citizens and proportionately, and I believe that it should continue to be. We already have enough disproportion with regard to the other European institutions, particularly in relation to the European Council, where six countries hold 70% of the votes, and that is why I am not in favour of transnational lists. I do not think they add democracy, I believe they subtract democracy. But I must say, Madam President, that, as regards the composition of Parliament, the proposal presented by the rapporteurs is a serious and fairest proposal of all that we have seen to date. It is the only proposal where small and medium-sized countries do not lose representation, and I know that it is very popular to say that we should all win and that our countries should be more represented, but I also know that, by saying that, we would have to have a Parliament far above the threshold laid down in the treaties and that Obviously, you'd have to take someone out, you just don't tell who's gonna take it. It's not satisfactory... (The President withdraws the speaker)

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, transnational lists are a magnet that will draw power away from citizens and their parties in the Member States and give it to the leadership of European parties. That is why some people like them, but this is not going to be good for democracy. The European parties will decide who gets on the list. The European parties will decide what manifesto they run on, and the national parties will be under enormous pressure to align their policies with the policies of their European party. This will alienate the voters, who will no longer be able to vote for a party in the Member State that represents their policies and their preferences. Instead, they will have to vote for someone who in reality represents a European party. Let’s oppose it: let’s learn something from Brexit.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Madam President, the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union creates a gap of 73 places. With the exception of a minimal redistribution among the other Member States, the European Parliament is trying to commit 46 of these posts to a common pan-European list. Although, in theory, one could find negative and positive in this proposal, the reality is somewhat different. In fact, if the proposed change is adopted, it will simply widen the difference in the influence of the larger states within the Union. Moreover, the already enormous distance between European institutions and European citizens will be further extended. Now the MEPs elected from these supranational lists will be completely unknown to the vast majority of citizens, and it is completely vague who exactly they will represent and to whom they will answer. Finally, recent experience has shown us that the Union does not treat parties of all political hues equally, but - on the contrary - is trying to stifle patriotic and nationalist voices, a phenomenon that is expected to intensify after the adoption of supranational lists.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, when Brexit occurred and we started discussing the redistribution of seats, I felt we were moving a bit hastily. This was confirmed for me a month ago when both Donald Tusk and Jean-Claude Juncker said that the door was open for the British to change their minds. But if they change their minds, their seats will have gone – thankfully not all, but some – and I welcome Ireland being given two extra seats because of its growing population, etcetera. So, what do we do? In relation to the transnational lists, many people, our Taoiseach included, have outlined many good reasons why we should consider them but, as Othmar Karas said, this is theoretical at this stage. Before the theory can become practice, we have to see how, in practice, these elite MEPs would operate. Will they be elected by everybody and accountable to no one? That needs to be answered before theory becomes practice.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, yes, I agree to give more seats to under-represented countries. I agree on degressive proportionality. At the same time, we should have to take into consideration the number of citizens of each and every country: citizens some of whom – in the case of Romania about three million – live in other European Union countries. I believe that the proposal to create transnational lists aims to define European direct representation while respecting the degressive principal, as required by Article 14 of the Treaty. But we are not yet ready for this. I agree that we can apply the system starting in 2024 but not in 2019.  At the same time I would ask all of you: what are we going to do about the extremist parties, the political parties in Europe that are against the European Union? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would first of all like to congratulate the rapporteurs of this report on the justice that it embodies in the distribution of Members' seats between the various Member States. Finally, the principle of regressive proportionality has been fully realized. But this relative justice, which has been achieved here, will always be incomplete if we are unable, at this stage in the process of European integration, to take the decisive step towards greater integration and to actually get the institutions of the Union to discuss European problems in electoral campaigns. Electoral campaigns in the various Member States for the European Parliament focus on national problems, they are a remake of national elections. We must therefore take the decisive step, to discuss Europe in the elections to the European Parliament. Let this Parliament be the representative of the European people and not of national results.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, transnational ballots do not serve the needs of the peoples of Europe. They seek to create a limited European elite made up of prominent MEPs who will, in fact, obey the mandates of the leadership of the European Union and cut off from their voters whose interests will not be able to serve. Moreover, they do not comply with the principle of proportionality and, together with the lists for the Commissioners, the Spitzenkandidaten, they are against small parties and small countries and they are promoting the interests of large countries and large parties. That is why this proposal must be voted against. It does not respond to democratic needs and, moreover, prevents citizens from dealing with European issues.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, Brexit creates a historic opportunity for us to reduce the size of the European Parliament, to create more efficient and responsible decision-making. I don't support supranational lists because I think they don't increase democracy, on the contrary, they alienate voters from meps. I justify this by the fact that the essence of democracy is that we Europarliamentarians and the Euro-Parliament have a connection with the citizens. The supranational lists distance the public and Parliament from each other, and this is no one's interest. It could also create two layers of people among us meps. When you listen to the debate here, we who oppose supranational lists are supposedly afraid or not good Europeans. What then, if the division has been implemented, then this... (The Speaker interrupted.)

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would just like to raise a few issues. As we heard during the debate, there are very different opinions on some issues, such as transnational lists, but I would say that very few colleagues questioned the core of this report, which is the composition of our House as of 2019. I believe that the proposal which we put forward is the middle ground between all points of view on the matter, and in the light of all the special – I would say extraordinary – circumstances we are facing this time around, this is the best solution available with regard to the composition of Parliament for the forthcoming term. I would also like to reiterate my request to the European Council to heed Parliament’s wishes in relation to its own composition, and I hope that the report will be approved by the European Council in the version that will, hopefully, pass through Parliament today. I would also like to make it clear to colleagues that the bigger the majority with which we adopt the composition proposal, the more likely it is that the Council will not change it. I am confident that, with this report, Parliament is sending a strong signal to citizens that it will remain efficient, while managing to reduce its size by 46 seats owing to the withdrawal of the UK from the Union. I hope that the European Council will support us in this proposal because it is fair, equitable and in full compliance with Treaty principles. It is, above all, also in the interests of European citizens.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira
text: rapporteur. — (PT) Madam President, two points mark our debate. Firstly, as would be expected, the discussion on transnational lists, but I would like to insist that what this report does is to leave a number of posts available which can be used in future, both for enlargements or in the possible creation of transnational lists. Because, moreover, this report recognises, as Parliament already recognised in 2015, that the creation of transnational lists is the subject of electoral law and therefore depends, as a precondition, on a unanimous decision by the Council. More importantly, this debate has shown a very broad consensus on the rapporteurs' proposal for the distribution of seats and that is very important. I believe that there are good reasons for very broad support for this proposal, not only from those who see their unfair underrepresentation finally corrected, but also from those small or medium states that have left for this debate in fear of losing seats once again and which see three times. guaranteed their representation. Firstly, because the proposal does not reduce seats to any Member State, secondly, because it does not enshrink any mathematical formula that entails loss in the future, and thirdly, because it gives the assurance that even in the event of enlargement and even in the case of transnational lists, this distribution of posts will not be affected. I therefore hope that we can have a clear message from this Parliament to the Council for a proposal that allows for a fairer Parliament and which strengthens European democracy.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — On 11 November 2015, the European Parliament (EP) adopted its proposal to amend the 1976 Act on the election of MEPs by direct universal suffrage, introducing a series of measures aimed at strengthening the European dimension of elections and ensuring greater electoral equality for the elections citizens of the Union. Unfortunately, since then five Council Presidencies (Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Malta and now Estonia) have worked on Parliament's proposal (exercised in accordance with Article 223 (1) TFEU), but none have forwarded to the EP any formal or informal results of the Council's deliberations. highlighting the unwillingness of Member States to harmonize the current rule dating back to 1976. That is why we once again call on the Council not to continue to block the improvement of the rules on the election of MEPs and, bearing in mind that the dossier must be completed by next spring at the latest, to submit a decision to the EP as soon as possible.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – This report states that the ‘distribution of the European Parliament’s seats must follow the general provisions of Article 14 of the Treaty on European Union’ and makes some useful suggestions as to how the allocation of seats might be improved in future. I represent Scotland, where a majority voted to remain in the EU, and I regret that much of this report is based upon the likelihood that the UK will leave, thereby making 73 seats available for redistribution. Considering the proposals on their merits, I support in principle the Committee’s suggested redistribution of seats, which will correct some of the current distortions and improve on the degressive proportionality principle. I also support the idea of reserving the remaining seats for potential future enlargements of the EU. Indeed I very much hope that Scotland will choose to become a normal independent nation again, and perhaps make use of such an arrangement when we return as a fully-fledged EU Member State. I am totally opposed to the notion of using some EP seats to create a transnational list, and I will vote in favour of the various amendments which seek to delete that principle from the report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — In anticipation of the 2019 European elections, I support this proposal to create European transnational lists which, in practice, should allow citizens to vote, alongside MEPs elected on national lists, for the same MEPs throughout Europe. In my vision of Europe, which combines federalism and realism, I believe that the establishment of these unique constituencies will help to create a stronger link with the European citizen and, in this sense, will foster more European democracy. These transnational lists will indeed make it possible to “export Europe” better, to have more debate and, I hope, to strengthen the sense of European belonging. Finally, they will make it possible to give the European elections a true European character. The problem of European elections — beyond low turnout — is that they are the sum of national electoral laws. Having transnational lists that go beyond geographical divides can give these elections a real European dimension, beyond the borders of the Member States. The establishment of single constituencies must, however, be part of a much broader project and should be followed by other measures that will enable the European project to be revived, which, more than ever, needs a new impetus.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Following the UK's departure from the EU, the EP will have 73 fewer MEPs. Discussions over whether these vacant seats to redistribute all, or leave vacant, have been underway on the floor of the EP since Brexit. There were opinions among our fellow MEPs to redistribute them all, but there were also those who had the same view as I did, so that we would not share anything, to invest the money saved in development projects for young people or to protect the external borders, or to support less developed regions. Following the accession of new countries to the EU, they would gradually be allocated vacancies. Uniting has not been easy, so it is necessary to thank the rapporteurs for a sensible compromise that redistributes 27 seats and leaves 46 free for future EU members. I am pleased that Slovakia will receive one more mandate with this proposal, which will give us fourteen MEPs after 2019. I have quite a different view of the creation of a transnational electoral list, because I consider it unrealistic for anyone to campaign before the EP elections across the EU so that they can not be held accountable to their constituents for their work. An MP must know who his constituents are, he must be in contact with them and he must be able to communicate with them during the parliamentary term.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - Brexit has created a forced decision for the functioning of the European institutions, in this case the future composition of Parliament, which also offers new opportunities for making our operations more efficient and legal. I believe it is important that this correction process, from legislation to implementation, is controlled by the EP and I welcome the report's intention to do so. The current proposals are made in the spirit of a practical compromise and will serve to enhance the democratic functioning of the European institutions and the Union as a whole and strengthen the role of the EP. In particular, I also support a reduction in the number of EP staff and a better application of degressive proportionality in the area of representation per Member State, with no extra seat for my own Member State. However, it is important that the change does not mean a reduction in any Member State, which I believe should be enforced in the event of any future change. For me, the pan-European list, direct European representation and the perspective of the common list are the most important elements of the package of proposals for the further development of European integration. Contrary to skeptical opinions, I believe that they can be introduced at the time of the next parliament's mandate, and the necessary legal basis can be established in time if there is sufficient political will. In addition to strengthening the democratic content and citizenship of EU decision-making, such a historic change can also contribute to the suppression of nationalist pressure and anti-Europeanism in several EU Member States, unfortunately, most in my own country.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. — (PT) The report establishing the composition of the European Parliament following the departure of the United Kingdom sets out an appropriate model for correcting certain imbalances in representation, ensuring that no Member State loses mandates and leaves slack for possible future enlargements or implementation of the principle approved earlier by Parliament of transnational lists. I stress the excellent work done by the rapporteurs and those who worked with them most directly, who, among other things, have managed to ensure that no country will lose representatives, a fact that if it happens, it would be very difficult to explain to national public opinion in a framework of vacancies resulting from the exit of British deputies. The report also highlights the Council's exclusive competence to, if it so wishes and unanimously, promote the legal framework for the introduction of transnational lists. I believe that these can be a positive step in the deepening of European democracy, provided that distortions in the democratic representation of the various Member States and the various political groups and movements within the Union's institutional framework are avoided.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Esteban González Pons, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on revision of the Framework Agreement on relations between the European Parliament and the European Commission (N8—0065/2017 – C8-0366/2017 – 2017/2233(ACI)) (A8-0006/2018).

name: Esteban González Pons
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, in this report, in addition to the amendments, what is being discussed is whether the Commission is a body with political responsibility that is accountable to Parliament and to the voters — a real European government as this Parliament wants — or just an administrative body that speaks in Parliament but responds to the Council, that is, a puppet from the European governments. If you vote in favour of this report, you will vote for a European government; if you vote against, you will vote for a Commission of the governments of the countries of Europe. They are two very different models. Yesterday, President Juncker warned us that there are voices within the Council that want to eliminate the figure of the candidate for President of the Commission. Let me tell you that, in my opinion, that would be a step backwards for European democracy. I am not saying a step backwards for European construction, which, too, I say that European elections without a candidate for President of the Commission are less democratic elections, almost a failed election. The figure of the candidate for president of the Commission allows citizens to go to the polls knowing what the programme of each party is and what is the candidate of each party. Normal. Because in the European elections not only a Parliament is elected, a European government is also elected, and it would be a democratic abnormality for citizens to not be able to elect that government or even know who the candidates are to lead that government. This European Union is still a democracy under construction and therefore vulnerable. It is enough for Europe's enemies to oppose European democracy. You cannot be a friend of Europe and contrary to European democracy. For nationalpopulists, it is easier to attack a European Union with a democratic deficit than a European Union that is built and supported by the citizens' vote. National populists come to the European institutions to destroy them, disguise themselves as democrats to attack democracy and use the rule of law to end the rule of law. Only real democracy unmasks false democrats. That is why our biggest problem is that every day more and more citizens buy populist discourse because they feel that the Community institutions are far from normal people; because they feel that the Community institutions live in the universe of statistics and big figures rather than in the real world of supermarket prices and because they feel that the European institutions are accountable to the Council but not to the people. This growing disaffection can only end if the possibilities for political participation are increased: that citizens can choose with more European democracy, not with less. When we say only 'we need more Europe' instead of saying 'we need more European democracy', what is understood is that we are looking for more European bureaucracy and not more European politics. If we do not build a democratic Europe, if Europe remains just another historic alliance between European nations, all the effort that the European Democrats have made after World War II and after the Eastern and Southern dictatorships of Europe will have been of no use. That citizens know and be able to vote for candidates for President of the Commission is not a whim, it is not even a democratic demand; knowing the face of the candidate is normal and the rare thing would be for us to insist that a president of the European government can be elected without citizens knowing what face he has or what face he has nationality is not what its name is, not even what is its gender. That is why in my report I propose that the European Parliament be prepared to reject any candidate for President of the Commission proposed by the Council who has not been previously appointed as the main candidate in the European elections. This is not a conflict between the Council and Parliament. This is a conflict between power and democracy. And this cannot be the first Parliament in history that, between power and democracy, chooses power.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by saying that the Code of Conduct is here to hold Members of the Commission to the highest levels of integrity. I believe that we have a strong Code of Conduct, strengthened over the years as we have learned from our mistakes. To paraphrase Alexander Hamilton, if people were angels, we would not need rules. It is in this vein that on 13 September last year we proposed to improve transparency, strengthen democratic legitimacy and enforce our collective high standards through a renewed statute for the funding of political parties and movements. We are doing this in order to close loopholes that are clearly prone to abuse. I believe Parliament and the Council are not that far apart, and I look forward to the swift adoption of that proposal so as to be in time for the next parliamentary elections in 2019. But let me now turn to the Code of Conduct again. The Commission would welcome support for allowing Commissioners to stand in, and campaign for, European elections without having to take leave; and for revising the framework agreements between the European Parliament and the Commission accordingly. Article 10 of the new Code of Conduct makes the safeguards in relation to Commissioners participating in elections very clear. In line with paragraph 4 of this article, Parliament will be informed of the measures taken to ensure respect for the principles of independence, integrity and discretion. Present Juncker has tasked the Commission secretariat-general with preparing guidance on this matter in time for the next European election. Parliament’s reply to the consultation on the new Code of Conduct came in time to allow most of its provisions to enter into force on 1 February this year as planned. At the same time, it is clear that the provisions governing participation in European elections will enter into force only once the amendments to the Framework Agreement have been formally adopted by Parliament. The Commission addresses in the new Code of Conduct as many of the concerns expressed by Parliament as possible. President Tajani has written a letter to President Juncker regarding the areas where Parliament would deem further changes desirable. The Commission has analysed these carefully and I know that President Juncker will respond in a letter which he will send out shortly. You also take the opportunity in your report to restate Parliament’s support for the process of ‘lead candidates’ or Spitzenkandidaten. Yesterday morning President Juncker spoke clearly about the lead candidate system, as well as the question of transnational lists. He noted that both issues, in their own way, generate political debate between EU institutions. The Commission will contribute constructively to that debate in the form of a contribution to the leaders’ meeting on the 23rd of this month, and in that context I will listen carefully to your contributions to this debate today.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first I want to thank Esteban González Pons for his work on this dossier. This morning we are discussing the fundamental question of how we can organise democracy on a European level. The EU is not a state, but it’s already a key decision—maker in a lot of important areas in the daily life of citizens. That’s why it’s important to discuss this issue. The Lisbon Treaty was already a big step: today, the European Parliament, now directly elected, is powerful, and we decide together with the Council. People and states are deciding – that is Europe.  Now it’s a question of whether there is a need for another approach at European level to practising democracy. I would say not. There is no need for an innovative approach on this. In my small village, where my home is in Bavaria, when we elect a mayor, we have a candidate and we have a programme. When in October of this year we hold an election in Bavaria for the Prime Minister of Bavaria, we will have candidates from the different parties and each candidate will have a programme, a profile.  When people in France vote in the presidential elections for a President of France, they have a candidate and this candidate has a programme. Sorry, dear friends, but I am fed up of asking for the same procedure, which is established at all other levels, to be allowed at European level, too – to present people, before we go to vote, with a candidate and with a programme. That is democratic and that is what we should also do in 2019. Dear friends, Churchill said once that it is the people who control the government, not the government the people. This sentence is also true for the heads of states and governments around Europe. President Macron, for example, is making a lot of effort to strengthen the European Union, but on the top candidate concept, we need a clear answer from him, too. If Macron wants to stick to a democratic Europe then he has to agree to the lead candidate process. I hope that the President is listening to our debate here today. He can read our lips when we say very clearly that the EPP Group will not accept a candidate for Commission President who was not presented during the campaign as lead candidate of a democratic party and cannot bring together a qualified majority in the newly—elected European Parliament. We need a President of the European Commission who is elected, and not selected behind closed doors. I appeal to the European Council: let’s not now start a power game among the institutions; let’s simply practise democracy. I’m very, very pleased that LeoVaradkar, Andrej Plenković and Sebastian Kurz – who gave his support in an interview on Saturday – and now finally Jean—Claude Juncker, the current Commission President, were absolutely clear that they support the concept. So there is growing support for this idea, even in the Council. Let’s make Europe democratic, let’s fight for the top candidate concept. (Applause)

name: Pedro Silva Pereira
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr González Pons, on his proposal and the cooperation we have maintained over the last few weeks. This proposal is not limited to regulating the possible candidacy of Commissioners to the European Parliament, while safeguarding the principles of transparency and independence. That's important, but it's not enough. This Parliament should seize the opportunity to reaffirm its political support for the process of the leading candidates or Spitzenkandidaten successfully initiated in the last European elections. We cannot go back on this mechanism if we want to tackle the democratic deficit in order to give citizens' choice a consequence and to strengthen the democratic legitimacy of the Commission. This is an opportunity to send out a message from Parliament in favour of closer rapprochement between the European institutions and the citizens. For our part, we will not miss that opportunity.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! Colleagues and Colleagues! The European Union needs, above all, mutual trust, rather than a radical institutional transition, trust between the European level and the Member States. My impression is that Mr. Pons' report is taking away trust from the states and trying to move it elsewhere. And these are not citizens of the European Union, they are elected European political parties. I adhere very much before this solution, also because of respect for the spirit of the European treaties. According to the treaties, the European Commission is not a strictly political body. It is intended to be a body of high competence, especially responsible for guarding the common interest. The head of the European Commission must enjoy the confidence of the Member States in the Council and indeed the approval of the European Parliament. Let's not violate the delicate balance that existed and exists to this day. Let's not shift confidence from member states to European political parties. Radicalism is the enemy of good.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, this parliamentary term has been historic because we proceeded to inaugurate the Spitzenkandidaten process, as the rapporteur has rightly said. And, in this way, 500 million European citizens will have a much more democratic intervention in the election of the President of the European Commission. Indeed, there is a question of democracy and there is a question of power, as the rapporteur has pointed out. This change in democratic reinforcement will also increase the European Parliament's control capacity. And that is also a matter of democracy. The process makes the political component of the Commission more real, which is not a choir of archangels. They're not technicians: they're politicians. And therefore, the rules of the game must be clearly regulated so that they can be presented, under what conditions, but they must be able to do so easily. I would like to highlight the good cooperation we have had with the rapporteur, with Mr Esteban González Pons. The result has been very fast and very effective, in our opinion. Thank you very much, to all those who have collaborated. Thank you very much, rapporteur.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I read Article 17 (3) of the Treaty: “The Commission shall exercise its responsibilities in full independence. Members of the Commission shall not solicit or accept instructions from any government, institution, body or body. ' The report under consideration recalls this precept but at the same time endorse its explicit derogation, allowing Commissioners to continue to perform their duties, even if they are candidates for the European elections under the umbrella of a party, therefore as bearers of particularistic political interests. It is clear in a 2014 Parliament study that the regulatory prediction of unpaid electoral leave is a best practice to extend to other EU institutions. I find it paradoxical that abolition is discussed today. The fact that the Commissioners' new Code of Conduct has removed this provision does not represent an alibi for Parliament to seal its disappearance even in the framework agreement. The 2011 code of conduct provided for leave in any type of election campaign. It stands out now: Commissioners must take leave if candidates in national elections, they must not if they run in Europe. This is completely incomprehensible to me.

name: Pascal Durand
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Madam President, I too wish to pay tribute to the work done by the rapporteur, Mr Gonzáez Pons. At the same time, if the subject was not as serious, the debate we had this morning would laughter, because although we are flexible, the big gap is difficult to keep. However, for an hour and a half we heard here the representatives of the right in this House explain to us that transnational lists would be a regression for European democracy, and you have just rightly explained to us that the fact that there is a top candidate for Europe on a European programme that exceeds national interests, would be a great and great step forward for Europe! I agree with your opinion, Mr Gonzárez Pons, but it cannot be said at the same time that we have a general European interest which is not the sum of national interests, as the Commission undertakes and does, and, at the same time, oppose the fact that a European democracy is finally coming to light, with candidates elected on the a common European programme that goes beyond national logic. So I turn again to you. The vote has not yet taken place. Defend, Mr González-Pons — in the same logic as the one that makes you defend today a European top candidate — defend the transnational lists! They are the democratic response to the fact that we have abolished borders for goods, goods and services.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with this decision on the Framework Agreement on relations between the European Parliament and the Commission, it is a standardisation of the European Parliament and the Commission. possibility for the European Commissioners to participate in the European elections without having to resign first. I personally have strong misgivings about this, especially with regard to conflict of interest. The Commissioners have, undoubtedly, the highest quality and quantity of resources, which give them a potential competitive advantage that is before everyone. In addition, situations could easily occur during the election campaign that undermine precisely the independence which, according to the Treaties, characterizes the Commissioner. Denying the problem certainly doesn't solve it. In our view, the only way to address the problems exposed is precisely for members of the Commission to resign once they have decided to participate in the electoral competition. We therefore believe that Parliament should reject the request for an amendment to the interinstitutional agreement. On the issue of Spitzenkandidat, we believe that a clear shaping of this figure could actually promote greater closeness of European citizens to the institutions, but this is not possible if the The new identification procedure remains exclusive to European political parties. In this way, all those movements that represent civil society and do not want to turn themselves in and do not call themselves up to the form of party would be cut off from the competition. Parties are part of democracy, but democracy is much more than just parties. That's the message our citizens want to hear.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, the draft framework agreement before us today is an infamy. By accepting it, the European Parliament would emphasize the federal character of the Union by strengthening the Commission to the detriment of the European Council. First, it wants to allow commissioners to participate in the 2019 election campaign while continuing to perform their duties. This will distort electoral competition because, by their duties, they will be able to make decisions to influence voters. On the other hand, the draft forces the European political parties to each submit a Spitzenkandidat, that is, a candidate for the presidency of the Commission. The word used betrays the origin, German of course, of this smoky idea. Officially, it is a question of giving the Commission a democratic varnish, as if it was enough to turn iron into gold. In fact, the Commission will never be equivalent to the government of a democratic state, for democracy requires a nation. However, there is not a European nation, but European nations. Only European states are based on a genuine democratic basis. The European Union, for its part, is based on a sham. Rather than persisting in error in this way, it would be better to rethink the construction of Europe. It is a nation-friendly Europe that people need, not a supranational monster dominated by oligarchs and lobbies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Madam President, I wonder what exactly the Commission and the European Parliament are trying to achieve with this proposal, because I see no real meaning, no substance. I have only two things to make and I think they are of particular interest to European citizens. Firstly, the election of the President of the Commission only in name is democratic, whereas in practice it is merely an approval of his appointment. Worse is even worse as far as the other Commissioners are concerned, since they do not even have to be candidates or have any other connection with democratic processes, which the Union is passionately defending. So let us not mock the Europeans; some appointed will continue to influence their lives to a great extent. Finally, a further point, indicative of the logic prevailing in the institutions of the European Union, is the fact that you are hurrying to abolish compulsory unpaid leave for any Commissioner who wishes, paradoxically, to come to the crisis of the citizens at least once and to be a candidate in the European elections. You are thus ensuring that he continues to enjoy his salary and, at the same time, you are indifferent to the obvious conflict of interest, since he will continue to perform his executive duties in the middle of an election period. Congratulations!

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Madam President, let me start by emphasising that no way back can be accepted by this Parliament with regard to the democratisation of the procedure for electing the President of the Commission. This crystal clear message was delivered by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs when adopting, by a large majority, the report endorsing the revision of the Framework Agreement on relations between the European Parliament and the European Commission, two weeks ago. The Spitzenkandidaten process is, for us, a matter of democracy and transparency. It is a matter of connecting Europe and its citizens, of building a bottom-up Europe. The European Parliament wants European citizens to have a say on the choice of the Commission President and this decision can no longer be made behind closed doors. The Spitzenkandidaten process, launched in 2014, reinforces the political accountability of the Commission and gives a stronger role the European political parties. The political tradition of these parties has always been to stand for a European approach in dealing with the challenges the European Union is facing. We have been through this process once already. The practice is already there, but we need a shared commitment on the part of the European institutions.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: Madam President, we have been discussing how citizens' consent, interests and preferences are best expressed through the election of their representatives and we are now debating how the democratic bond is strengthened, how the political relationship between the institutions is intensified, while respecting the initial confidence that this Parliament must give the President of the Commission and continuous accountability to the body elected by citizens. The tone of the report, yesterday's debate with President Juncker, the rapporteur's own expression alert us that there are warning signs. Alarm signs of a turning back in relation to the Spitzenkandidat and other democratic elements. And I wonder: if we are betting on a more global European Union in its foreign policy, more ambitious in economic and monetary union, with more commitment to defence and security, will we accept a step back in the democratic and parliamentary dimension? This Parliament must be prepared to reject interference from the Council.

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President. Mr Pons's report focuses in particular on Parliament's position on the leading candidate procedure, in the political context of preventing any legal basis for such a legal basis in the Council. The report on the future composition of Parliament, which has just been discussed, is an influence on this procedure because it addresses the issue of transnational lists and, consequently, the position of top candidate. We will hopefully learn something about the Council's position this afternoon, and yes, the vote here in the House on the composition of the EP has not yet taken place. This raises another question for me, namely the problem of the participation of Commissioners in the election campaign. In the country from which I come, is political competition in the context of elections constitutionally incompatible with any partial action by state bodies or their officials? Voters should be able to freely form their opinions, and this leads to a neutrality requirement for us. Now the EU is not a state, nor do we have a constitution. But the neutrality requirement should be analogous. This raises the question: when is a Commissioner acting with the authority of the Office and is using the resources associated with it, and when is he only on the move in party politics? This can only be done without conflict, interpretation and publicly traceable by means of an unpaid release of Commissioners from their duties. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the 'blue card' procedure. — (DE) Madam President. My question is this: how do you actually see that the political groups and the European parties are giving the chance to nominate different candidates and that they will then be elected accordingly? Will your group also be able to provide top candidates for a transparent selection of the best candidates?

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — Mr Rübig! As you know, we have various left-wing structures and parties in our group, including Members of the European Left Party. We have had a top candidate in the current parliamentary term, that is today's Prime Minister Tsipras. In this respect, we will also be setting up such a candidate in the next European elections, perhaps several.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, today you can mark a before and after for Europe. With the pan-European list head and transnational lists we can break down democratic borders a little further. Because these two proposals are complementary. And they are a powerful way, first, to move into the electoral space what European citizens already do: to european the debate. Mr Pons, whatever our positions on glyphosate or CETA are, these debates and mobilizations are no longer only national, but also European. That is why it is a matter of giving greater political legitimacy to the pan-European list, thanks to a list, to a transnational campaign against all European citizens. This can also make it possible, in turn, to consolidate the feeling of European belonging for greater pan-European solidarity. Colleagues, after Brexit is time to make this qualitative leap. It is time to deepen European democracy and european democracy.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first I would like to underline the fact that the so-called Spitzenkandidaten procedure has nothing to do with transnational lists. Back in 2014 we had this procedure of Spitzenkandidaten and it was embraced at European level without any joint European constituency. So, one thing is totally different from the other. Then, let me tell you something that is very important. We fully support this idea of the Spitzenkandidaten procedure but if the Council says ‘no we are not going to change our view’, we are not dependent on any regulation of the Council, because this is our interpretation of the Treaties. The Treaty says that the outcome of the elections should be considered and that a vote in Parliament is required. This is sufficient to give a constitutional basis to the Spitzenkandidaten process. So we prefer a clear and transparent Council regulation, but if we don’t have that we will have the same position, because this is our interpretation, our reading of the constitutional solution in accordance with the Treaties.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: Madam President, I want to be clear: transnational lists are an undemocratic mechanism. They mean learning nothing from mistakes. They are equivalent to giving as a recipe for solving problems more than what caused these problems. Without a mandate from the national parliaments, they want to approve in the European Parliament a proposal which will radically change the way the representatives of their respective countries are elected. Also be clear: Portugal is a country, not a European region at the behest of Mr Verhofstadt. It is considered normal or acceptable for candidates from small and medium-sized countries to be chosen by leaders of the large countries controlling European parties and who, of course, will benefit from starting their own interests. A European party which is part of more than one party from the same country is allowed to exclude some parties from the lists in favour of others who have more influence in the direction of those parties. They do not even want to make it easier for radical candidates from some countries to spread their message to all other countries where they will also gain votes and influence. I have to say that these radicals have not yet arrived in Portugal and I did not like to see them being voted on there. Finally, they do not even consider, as has been abundantly said, that the national parliament of the federal states is voted on state lists and not on national lists. I will finish, Madam President. Transnational lists are nonsense. Worse than that, they're dangerous nonsense.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: — Madam President, on the principle of headings, yes, it is a democratic step forward to ensure that candidates for the chairmanship of the Commission are not nominated behind closed doors by Heads of State or Government, but by political parties. I believe that this is a step in the right direction and that we must take another step in order for the heads of the list to be nominated by all the peoples of Europe. That is why it is consistent in my opinion to proceed with the election of transnational lists that will be in this direction. This is a first step towards democracy, dear Mr Gonzáez Pons. Let us go further and, in a forthcoming term, let us ensure that it is the people, not just the political parties in their neighbourhood, who can designate, through transnational lists, the person who will be responsible for leading the European Commission.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: — Madam President, from the outset, I want to say that I support the report. It seems to me that we would be doing backward work if, after having had elections in 2014 with a top list, we now come to confuse European citizens, to come up with another method. I believe that we need to strengthen this method, on the one hand, and, on the other, we need to come up with very clear messages to our citizens. What is the relationship between the three institutions: Commission, Parliament, Council? From my point of view, I think the Council is a blocker, although they are not elected members. Because there are governments there in the Council and, very often, we, Parliament, who are the most representative institution, have problems in the Council with what we decide here, and I think that this is where we still need to work. I am pleased that the Commission is reminded that it has that three-year period of incompatibility after they are no longer members of the Commission. Of course, the dilemma remains: what will the Commissioner who is still in operation and will run? On the other hand, we cannot let him resign and have an empty six-month period until the new Commission is sworn in. I will therefore vote on this report and support the report in plenary.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, there is a lot of bilingualism and beautification of the process of nominating the top candidate. Because, in practice, what will happen? How will this top candidate be nominated? From European political parties, such as the European People's Party or the Party of European Socialists. But are you a party? Do you have members? You don't have citizens. You have national parties. Therefore, you are a bureaucracy, you are not a real party. If you want to be a real party, be a member party. And since you're going to be a member party, your members democratically, voting in a referendum, choose this top candidate. So, what's it gonna be? Your bureaucracy and “party bosses” will designate the candidate. So, you're gonna be in control of who this candidate is. So this is not a democracy. Create democratic parties first, and then have the requirement to nominate the lead candidates.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to congratulate Mr González Pons on the work he has done to manage this complex report which we need and support all those who really believe in the idea of Europe. The experience of the past European elections led to election debates focusing on Community issues for the first time for the first time, and we elected from among them. We have to go on like this. Because we need European citizens to know the proposals, characteristics, trajectories, virtues and shortcomings of the candidates who aspire to chair the European Commission. Let him feel, know and see what he chooses. I wish all Spitzenkandidaten are also heads of a transnational list. After the elections, we are going to elect here the head of the European Commission as in any parliament that controls a government, ensuring that he has sufficient support to be able to govern. Returning to the dynamics of the dark room refers this Union project to the image of a clandestine souk of national interests which it neither needs nor deserves nor can we afford. Citizenship wouldn't forgive him.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Madam President, the process of leading candidates that the European political parties will propose for staffing the Commission does not strengthen the parliamentary dimension of the Union. A political legitimacy of the institutions is sought, through a sufficient parliamentary majority. In practice, however, the principle of proportionality is abolished. Samples of this parliamentary authoritarianism have been experienced by political groups, such as the EFDD, the ENF and the non-attached MPs, with their exclusion from a series of parliamentary procedures. Unfortunately for the so-called 'democracy', there is a vague of intentions in this report which basically cancels any attempt to open and transparent procedures. In all this I would suggest that the citizens of the Member States directly select Commissioners and their final election by Members of the European Parliament.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I just want to thank the Members for their contributions to this debate. We are very much looking forward to the vote on this and we hope that we can amend the Framework Agreement in such a way that Commissioners could be allowed to stand in European elections without having to take leave. I have also listened carefully to the discussion on the process of lead candidates (Spitzenkandidaten) and, as I said earlier, we will take this into careful consideration when completing our contribution on this and other interinstitutional-related issues, and also in preparing for the leaders’ meeting later this month.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, I would simply like to thank all my colleagues for their support for the report, because they have been able to understand that this is a cross-cutting report that does not affect a political group, but an entire Parliament. In normal elections voters have candidates, have programs and elect governments, and then in those governments ministers can be candidates in elections. That was not happening in Europe until now. From now on, it will happen: there will be a candidate, there will be a programme, and the Commissioners, who are like ministers, will be able to attend the elections and the parties will have something to say. The more European democracy looks like normal democracy, the more we will normalise the European Union and make it less distant from the citizens. I just want to end, Madam President, with a warning. On 23 February the Council introduced among the topics to be discussed by Spitzenkandidat, the main candidate. It is a constitutional practice that we thought was already established, which leads me to wonder whether the Council intends to suggest that there should be no main candidate for President of the Commission in the forthcoming European elections. If that is the case, for this Parliament it should be an offense, and a serious offense. It should create an institutional conflict. I, therefore — thanking all those who from different perspectives have coincided with the report, of my heart — would like to end with the same plea with which Manfred Weber's speech ended. My President Weber said that the People's Party will not accept any candidate for chairman of the Commission who has not been voted by the voters. I would like us to be able to make that compromise by the PP today a whole House commitment. Let this Parliament not accept any candidate for President of the Commission who has not faced those who have to vote for it, to all Europeans.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Colleagues, the sitting is now suspended briefly, but I would remind you that today, before the votes, we will listen to an address by a representative of the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN), Nobel Peace Prize winners of last year. (from 11.47 to 12.18, Members gathered for the address by a representative of the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN), 2017 Nobel Peace Prize winner)

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the round of voting. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Presidente. –
text: The first point in the voting is the early termination of the office of a Vice-President of the European Parliament. Please be careful. We will now vote on the proposal from the Conference of Presidents on the withdrawal of the office of a Vice-President of the European Parliament, Mr Ryszard Czarnecki. In accordance with Article 21 of the Rules of Procedure, in order to be approved, the proposal must obtain the vote in favour of a two-thirds majority of the votes cast, for and against, representing the majority of the Members who make up Parliament, or 376. In accordance with Article 178 (3) of the Regulation, for the purpose of achieving the necessary two-thirds majority, only votes cast for and against the proposal shall be calculated. Please note that the total displayed at the top of the screen will include abstentions, but that the votes taken into account will only be those marked by the “+” sign and the “-” sign. In accordance with Rule 180a (2) of the Rules of Procedure, the political groups that have reached the high threshold have requested that voting take place by secret ballot. We can now move on to the vote.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I rise under Rule 184a to query the procedure for the vote we are about to take, which will disregard the rights of those Members who wish to abstain. In the Communication to Members last night, your services advised that abstentions will be discounted. I strongly protest. Rule 21 is not analogous to the election of Vice—Presidents. The vote of a Member who wishes to abstain is as valid as a vote cast by any other Member. It is the established practice of this Parliament that abstentions are taken into account.  Mr President, I insist that out of respect for parliamentary democracy you take due consideration of abstentions in determining whether or not the condition of two—thirds of votes cast has been satisfied. Mr Czarnecki was prevented from defending himself in the plenary, which is most irregular, and now we have this discounting of abstentions, which is also irregular, to say the least. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: As far as the interpretation of the regulation is concerned, since the first time a vote has been taken on the basis of Article 21, the general interpretation of the vote must be taken into account in all matters similar to that vote. For elections to the President, Vice-Presidents and Quaestors abstention votes do not count. As regards the approval of the rejection of any text, and therefore any proposal, shall enter into the calculation of the votes cast, says Article 178, only votes for and against, except in cases for which the Treaties provide for a specific majority. No treaty provides for anything about this and therefore I intend to interpret in an extensive way Article 178 and all the other rules that have always governed the election of people. So, since this is the revocation of an election, I intend to interpret the regulation in this direction. So I confirm that the votes counted will only be those for and those against.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I was the rapporteur that introduced this particular rule into the Rules of Procedure many years ago. It has never been used before and I can confirm that your interpretation is exactly what was intended. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: We can now move on to the secret ballot vote. I repeat that we need a two-thirds majority of the votes cast. Only votes for and votes against will be counted. (Parliament approved the proposal for an early termination of office)

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: 'You created a huge confusion, you didn't explain what was happening and so people didn't know what they were voting for. You look at it. We have voting lists. You didn't explain what we were voting for.

name: Presidente. –
text: Hon. Bresso, if you listen to me, I'll answer you.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: – Mr President, you did not explain that the Article 4(2) and Article 4(3) amendments would fall. You did not say that, so we thought we were voting on those, and not on Article 5. Non lo ha detto, quindi non l'abbiamo capito.

name: Presidente. –
text: In the voting lists it is indicated that, if the amendment is passed, paragraphs 2 and 3 lapse. In all voting lists it is written like that. I was very clear, I spoke of votes of proposals for decisions followed by vote. I'm sorry, Mr Bresso, I have been clear, I speak in Italian which is also your native language, I think you should understand it better than others.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, you have obviously put the cat amongst the pigeons among colleagues. Perhaps a simple solution to this is that we actually take a vote on the proposal for a decision again.

name: Presidente. –
text: It has already been checked, let's move on to the motion for a resolution. Hon. Gualtieri, please.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Article 5 was put to the vote immediately after the adoption of the amendment on Article 4(1), but many of us were actually voting contrary to what was on our voting list because we were not aware that we were voting on Article 5. The screen was indicating something else. So we are simply asking you to repeat the vote on Article 5 and to continue on. A lot of colleagues and I have voted as if it was for the previous text.

name: Presidente. –
text: But the voting was carried out. I didn't understand this beating on the tables what it means. I was very clear with regard to the amendment. Please, Mr Reid.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the board said ‘four’.

name: Presidente. –
text: Wait, I get it. I don't see the screen behind and they told me there was an error on the screen regarding article 4 and article 5. So let's upvote from article 5. Let's vote on Article 5, the original roll-call text.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we all share the responsibility in the fight against money laundering and terrorism financing. This Parliament has fought particularly hard with each upgrade of the Anti—Money Laundering Directive consistently to improve our legal framework in this respect. The delegated act you will vote on now concerns Tunisia, a recognised, close and privileged partner of the European Union. I want to stress that this act will not undermine any political or financial commitments by the EU in respect of Tunisia. We recognise the progress Tunisians have made in recent weeks and the Commission will be very supportive of Tunisia to help to deliver the action plan agreed between Tunisia and the Financial Action Task Force in December. We are in close and intense contact with our Tunisian friends in this regard. The Commission stands ready to provide support so that Tunisia removes the remaining deficiencies swiftly. Once we see the work done, we will initiate the delisting process, with the aim of Tunisia being delisted by the Financial Action Task Force and subsequently by the EU. I am convinced that, at the end of this process, Tunisia will serve as a benchmark for other countries and I praise its efforts and engagement. Lastly, let me confirm that the Commission is working intensively on a systemic solution, so that the EU has its own autonomous analysis and list of high-risk third countries in order better to protect the EU and its citizens.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: — Madam President, I am the author of the objection and the Commissioner has just taken the floor. I would just like to say to our colleagues that the Commissioner did not add anything to what the Commission told us in the LIBE-ECON joint meeting and in plenary on Monday evening. I would like to add that the question is not sanctions... (The President cut off the speaker's microphone) This is an unacceptable pressure from the Commission on the vote! (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: We cannot repeat the debate that has already taken place. That is why I would like to put it to the vote now, recalling that a majority of Members of Parliament is required to vote. I'll put it to the vote now. (In the electronic vote, 357 members vote in favour of the proposal, which is therefore not adopted.)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: That closes the voting time.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the question of what to do with 73 seats in this Chamber after the UK has left has been discussed and I have argued in my Member State that these seats should be re-allocated to the Member States, especially those who have been disadvantaged in the last composition. Some of the seats should be saved for the next EU enlargement, especially to the Western Balkans. But I want as well to express my support for the idea of joint constituencies as of the European elections in 2019. It is a way to enhance the direct link between citizens and EU policymakers. I strongly believe that EU citizens should be able to vote for candidates that express ideas and visions for the whole European Union. It will allow the first candidate on each list to be considered for the European Commission, thus acknowledging the irreversibility of the Spitzenkandidaten process.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: — Madam President, I voted against the proposed mandate for the composition of the European Parliament for the next term because I believe that the text as it stands is a cause for concern because of many of the vague aspects surrounding its innovation. I consider it discriminatory and the proposed allocation of seats in the new Parliament, although the number of populations in certain Member States such as the Netherlands, France and Spain is growing, but this is largely thanks to net migration from countries like my Bulgaria. Nor should we ignore the fact that the number of voting rights from each Member State is actually relatively constant, and if there are changes in the number of Members of the European Parliament, there must be a proportionate increase for everyone, including my country Bulgaria. I call on the European Commission and the Council to take these factors into account when discussing a proposal for the future composition of the European Parliament.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: — Madam President, when it comes to the shape of the European Parliament after the UK leaves, I am very surprised that the European Parliament does not simply cut those places. I don't understand why they are being redistributed among other member countries here, and I don't understand why only part of them are even redistributed while the other part is supposed to remain in a kind of reserve. The most sensible thing would be to cut them, to reduce the number of MEPs. Nothing would have happened. Money would be saved. Secondly, I must nevertheless commend the European Parliament today for not at least advancing the idea of transnational, that is, pan-European candidate lists in the 2019 elections. Finally, perhaps some people here have understood that there is no pan-European people or pan-European nation, that we do not need pan-European candidate lists and that MEPs should be bound to their nation-states and these states are to represent.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I rarely agree with my pre-speaker, but I think he was simply right on some things. I think that creating a multinational candidate at a time when we're always responsible in our own states and an MP actually comes out of the country with some experience is just nonsense and I I totally agree that the way seats are distributed and distributed today after MPs from the UK is another nonsense too. I have included myself in these debates several times and I think that the division is simply not fair and there will be a number of states and MPs who feel unlawfully discriminated against by this decision . So I could not vote for this report, even though I am a federalist and although I wish we would work more together in Europe.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, this report is absolutely none of my business. The whole basis of the report is that by the time any of this actually happens, the United Kingdom will not be in the European Union. I believe that it would be unethical for me to cast any affirmative vote on this subject because it would be just as wrong for me to tell the European Union what to do post-Brexit as it would be for the European Union to tell the UK what to do post-Brexit. For that reason the record will therefore show that I abstained on everything throughout this report.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President! After Brexit, 73 seats will be empty in the European Parliament, and the easiest practical solution for this would have been to have had so many fewer Members after 2019. This will also provide substantial financial savings and will allow representatives of the new Member States to get the right mandate following possible enlargement, for example in the Western Balkans. What I think is positive in this final report format is that the amendments have removed the possibility of using the released mandates on a common pan-European list. Let us note that the United States of Europe has not developed, we hope it will not, and such a solution, which is very far from voters, this transnational list, would have been completely unacceptable. In view of all this, I abstained from the final vote.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I finally refrained from this report, felt like cleaner vacancies after the UK left. Such partial redistribution and partial blocking of places strikes me as a compromise that is hard to explain to citizens. Otherwise, I'll confess I'm glad he hasn't passed a multinational constituency since 2019. I am a big supporter of the idea of European integration, the European Union, but I feel the need to strengthen the relationship between European politicians and among their constituents, among citizens. In short, a citizen should know his MP, he should know who to turn to if he misses with a specific directive or regulation. We saw this at the firearms directive debate. And the moment it's going to be one multinational electoral roll, then that relationship between a European politician and a citizen is rather diminished and threatened. That is, those multinational districts, I think, go real against the idea of European integration.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, most supporters of the transnational list argue that with its introduction, elections would be more European. Also, many hope that it would favour more integration as opposed to the system we have in place now. I would argue to the contrary. Being European is the sum of our national and subnational regional identities. Our European-ness is what unites us in our differences; imposing from the top a transnational list instead of making our citizens more European might, on the contrary, drive a wedge between electorates and the people supposed to represent them in the EU. All politics are local, and there is a good reason why. People need to feel that their particular problems are well understood and conveyed. Also, there is no contradiction between favouring national lists and favouring more integration. Integration is stronger if it is rooted in the local, and if it is a natural, bottom-up construction. Lastly, I strongly believe that most anti-EU populists feed from local dissatisfactions rather than discontent with the EU as such. This is why the best place to fight is there where it occurs, by those representatives who know their electorate best.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, I voted against the report on the new composition of the European Parliament. First of all because the way in which it distributes or distributes seats is unfair. It certainly favours certain states. It does wrong other states, such as Greece, which previously had 22 seats and then its seats in the European Parliament were reduced to 21. I think that Greece should have received at least one more seat. Secondly, the distribution method does not take into account the populations of certain states that have been forced to migrate, such as the thousands of Greeks who have migrated due to the memoranda and the troika. In our view, Greek citizens who live outside Greece and who are registered on the electoral roll should also be taken into account. This is the way in which seats are allocated should have been distributed. In relation to the transnational ballot, I spoke in detail in my speech here in the European Parliament a moment ago.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Madam President, this resolution is really about how seats occupied by colleagues in the UK will be distributed after Brexit. I have considered how to stand up on the matter, and to some extent I accept that there has been some damage on the part of some Member States in the past, so it would probably be easy to cut those parliamentary seats, so I have taken to the fact that it is good to leave here, firstly, a reserve for the newly accession Member States, which, I strongly hope, will approach the European Union. And secondly to address these detriments from the past. So I finally voted in favour of this report on the grounds that the single pan-European candidate has been rejected for 2019 so far. In my opinion that system would be very complex at the moment. It requires even greater knowledge and familiarity of the electorate, and I think it's important to inform voters very thoroughly and have the debate with them first. So this is what I welcomed very much that it was rejected. That's why I supported the report.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - I voted against. Firstly because I think it was necessary to simply reduce Parliament by these 73 Members. But secondly, I wanted to remind people that there were Fronts of the Unity of the Nation in the old communist countries. It didn't vote for the party, it voted for the Nation Unity Front, where the regime parties were connected, and that's exactly what Parliament wants to do, following in the footsteps of the Communists. Altiero Spinelli's shadow is visible every day in Brussels, and I am not surprised that Mrs Danuta Hübner — a communist child after all — wanted to introduce such a method in the European Parliament. And besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Yeah. We have the free speech, so everyone is allowed to speak.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, in 1946 Winston Churchill made a speech at the University of Zurich, one bit of which is always quoted in this House. The section where he says that he wants something – ‘a kind of United States of Europe’ is how he puts it. Very few people quote what he goes on to say, which is that he hopes that Britain and America, and maybe one day even the Soviet Union, will look on as friends and sponsors. I suspect he would rather approve of the proposal we have just voted on.
