The change, which means that Britain is leaving, but that there is a more federal view of how European democracy happens after that. The two things indeed being linked, because the withdrawal of the British veto facilitates a number of these federalist measures. A year ago, this would have really bothered me. I would have railed against the idea and I would have talked about the national Parliament being the focus of people’s loyalty. Now, I wish our friends and neighbours every possible success. More than 70 years on, we are belatedly realising that great vision of a united Europe with Britain as a friend and sponsor.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, for precisely the same reasons as on the previous report, I believe it would be wrong for me to cast any affirmative vote on this issue. I abstained on this throughout because this is none of my business as it will affect only the EU 27 and only post—Brexit. I believe it is, of course, perfectly reasonable to hold an opinion on it, just not for my opinion to be foisted upon others. So, in that spirit of an opinion, I just have one brief word of caution regarding Spitzenkandidaten. That is that this never worked well in the UK, not least because it could not be an issue because the UK has no meaningful voice from the largest political group in this place. There is a danger, therefore, that it ends up marginalising certain Member States and I would urge Parliament to consider carefully in future whether the current direction could end up having unintended consequences. Again, I say this in that same spirit of cooperation and friendliness.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: — Madam President, I voted against the report and, following on from what I said during the debate, I would like to highlight a number of issues for the lead candidate, which many have presented as a great democratic achievement. Who's the one to nominate the lead candidate? Parties at European level, such as the European People's Party or the Socialist Party. And I ask: are these parties or a set of bureaucracy? Because their members are not the citizens of the European Union themselves; their members are other parties. These are party parties. In fact, they are run by party bureaucracy and, above all, the most important reason is the Heads of State or Government, because they themselves are part of the top institutions of these European political parties. So the leaders and party bureaucracy will choose the lead candidate. Is this a democracy? It would be a democracy if these parties had members of the citizens themselves.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I supported this report, I consider the direction of greater awareness of the European elections to be correct in the electorate and, of course, the highlighting of the subject thanks to top candidates. It is undoubtedly important for voters to see who is running so they can support so that there can obviously be a very sharp but fair electoral contest. I understand that, and in that sense, I like to support. On the other hand, I would be a little wary of completely weakening the right of the European Council to propose that candidate. I think it may not be absolutely a given that the winner of the European elections from the point of view of the top candidates must automatically be nominated by the European Council. That's why I would be so that we would exercise caution in some way. And the second reason is also clear. There may be marginalisation of certain Member States. It is therefore important that everyone finds their application and their say precisely within the decision-making of the European Council.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the problem with the democratic deficit in Europe is a simple one. I vote in the European elections and, before 2014, the party I was voting for, even if it held the majority here, was not assured that it would get the position of European Commission President. The position was attributed through backroom deals among the EU leaders, in secrecy, and in this regard for European democracy the link between my vote and the outcome of the election was blurred. I am a strong supporter of the Spitzenkandidaten process because it diminished the democratic deficit. It gives citizens the right to directly influence how the Commission will lead. I voted for this report since its repeats the simple truth that the Spitzenkandidat is necessary for our European democracy.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Despite some controversial records, I voted in favour of the resolution because the scale of the devastating ritual mutilation of women coming mainly — but not only — from African countries is too great and requires prevention by all possible means. In Union countries, these kinds of practices are usually penalized. Similarly, in Poland — lawfully causing severe health prejudice is a crime, and this is the FGM procedure. This procedure is also intentional, therefore it has the stigmas indicated in the law of prohibited and criminal acts. In addition, it is performed in non-sterile conditions, without anesthesia, causing, beyond the pain and suffering of women, numerous complications, mainly bacterial infections, urinary tract infections, dyzuric symptoms, complications and perinatal infections, threatening not only the health, but even the lives of children and women.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I sincerely welcome the resolution drafted by our colleague Vilija Blinkevičiūtė. According to estimations, every year 180 000 girls and women are at risk of female genital mutilation (FGM) in the EU. I underline, colleagues: in the EU. Unfortunately, from the legal point of view, FGM still remains in a grey zone. The crime is under—reported, under—investigated and under—prosecuted in Europe. FGM is a serious human rights violation. We are used to reporting and condemning similar human rights abuses in foreign countries, but now we are faced with it in our home in Europe, and our national legislation must accept this challenge and finally adopt efficient legal ways of combating this crime. Parliament has already adopted several resolutions and I sincerely hope that this new report will make a change and bring new impetus to combating all forms of this violence. For this reason, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I supported this motion for a resolution because I view this practice as a truly inadmissible, completely undignified position of women in our society. Therefore, it should be maximally condemned, of course it is an interference with human rights, there is no doubt about that. No consent is given in any way fully freely and fully informed way. If any of the women undergo this kind of procedure purely voluntarily and freely, that's probably her business, but those unfree consents, that is, I think, a completely inadmissible practice. However, what I would like to point out: in that report, I suspect in point 13, that undergoing this practice is to result in, where appropriate, automatically granting the right to asylum. That I think is too radical and simplistic an approach. I did not support this amendment.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I believe that female genital mutilation is an abhorrent evil in our society, and indeed it is an evil wherever in the world it is practised. There are some words in this report which are not phrased in the way that I personally would have liked, but surely we can all agree that this evil must be stopped. Wherever it happens in the United Kingdom it must be prosecuted. Those who are responsible for allowing something so appalling to happen must face justice. Where parents fail to protect their children or if children are sent overseas for this to happen to them, there must be prosecutions. The law is the law, and the law must be enforced. Too often, we have seen police forces turn effectively a blind eye to this, and that must be stopped. *****

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Madam President! We have been out of reckoning with the votes to protect and counter discrimination against European Union citizens belonging to minorities in the EU Member States. You received such submissions as well, and it seems to me that we should carry out an explanation procedure for the position taken in the vote on this issue as well.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: There were no official speeches on the subject, so I did not call this. As you know, according to the rules, it is necessary to indicate in advance if it is intended to give an explanation of vote.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: — The submission has been accepted and I do not understand why the President did not get it. As such, I would like to find out where I can submit my remark on the subject.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I'm sorry, we didn't arrive. However, you still have the option of submitting your explanation of vote in writing, as the rules state. We actually didn't register. I'm sorry, I can't discuss with you now. I have to follow the rules as they are written. I am happy to give the floor to Mr Arnott. You've been talking several times today.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I rise to place on record my objection to what happened today under Rule 21 of the Rules of Procedure, which states that early termination of the office of a Vice-President may ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Die Präsidentin.
text: — No, no explanation of vote is possible. Declarations of vote are possible under the Rules of Procedure only on the texts on which the vote is taken.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the current debate (Rule 153a of the Rules of Procedure) on the consequences of increasing socio-economic inequalities for European citizens (2018/2558 (RSP)). Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to inform you that there will be no speeches on request or “blue card” questions during this debate.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D)
text: author. – Madam President, inequality has reached shocking new levels and is threatening to tear our societies apart, not only globally, but also in Europe. In the European Union, some 120 million people are poor; 28 million children live in households that cannot provide for their basic needs – food, health care, education or housing. It is absolutely shameful that the richest continent of the world does not take proper care of its own children. Even though the European economy is on the mend again and unemployment is going down, income and wealth inequality is on the rise, and an alarming 40% of wealth is in the hands of only 1% of the richest Europeans. Clearly the neo-liberal myth of the invisible hand and trickle-down economics is not going to sort out the situation, nor are today’s insufficient policy efforts. The election of Trump, and Brexit, which also stemmed from a growing disappointment with the status quo, must be the wake-up call for the last sleep-walkers. The growing gap between the rich and the poor is undermining the social and democratic fabric of our societies. It is high time to act now. Big challenges require strong political answers. We Socialists and Democrats fight side by side with an alliance of NGOs and social partners for strong policy responses that will work. We will campaign for an equitable and sustainable society of shared prosperity, opportunity and dignity. We call on the Commission to rapidly act and introduce an inequality reduction strategy within the European Semester to achieve income growth, especially for the bottom 40%. We are working for a poverty eradication road map to halve the number of people living in poverty by 2030, and for a directive on decent working conditions. We wish to create a living wage index to help define appropriate minimum wages in each Member State. If we know how devastating the consequences of inequalities are, why do we not use the remaining time in this mandate to improve the lives of the most needy Europeans? Let us introduce a child guarantee that ensures that each and every child in every country is able to access proper health care, good schooling and a healthy diet. Let us introduce a framework directive for decent working conditions that ensures that workers are no longer at risk of exploitation. Let us have protection against poor pay and have proper social rights, regardless of whether people work in industry or in digital platforms. And let us end the rhetoric of free trade that tries to convince people that trade only needs to be free to work for the people, because this neglects the hardship of those without jobs in deprived regions. We know that only with proper environment and sustainability provisions can trade be really progressive. A lot can be done to take this fight to the next level. The social pillar must be properly implemented, we need strong improvements on maternity and paternity leave – parenthood must not mean poverty. We must continue to fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. Digital giants have to pay proper taxes too. I would like to appeal to the whole House. My Group, the Socialists and Democrats, are willing to fight for that today, tomorrow and each and any other day of this mandate. We very much hope that you will join us.

name: Monika Panayotova
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, first of all, thank you very much for the opportunity to speak here on a topic so essential for the European Union in the current political context. Today, more than ever, the European Union needs to guarantee the prosperity and well—being of all its citizens, as well as to overcome the socio—economic inequalities in a fast-changing world. According to opinion polls, more and more citizens across Europe feel that they cannot fully profit from the benefits of globalisation. We need to make sure they see that the European Union is the solution to their concerns and that it delivers on their expectations. As a result of the effective policy response to the economic crisis by the European institutions and the Member States, the EU economy is now firmly recovering. Economic growth has returned and unemployment is at its lowest since 2008. Nevertheless, social and economic challenges persist across Europe. In 2017, 23% of our citizens remained at risk of falling into poverty and social exclusion. Young people are still especially vulnerable and we really need to focus our efforts on them as they are the future of Europe, of our economies and our societies. The consequences of leaving a whole generation without prospects would not only be morally irresponsible, but would have long—standing negative economic and political effects in the decades to come. We need to make sure that young people have better opportunities for education and training, mobility and personal development, and improved access to employment. Socio—economic stability and fairness is a pre-condition for social progress and trust in the European Union project. As Parliament rightly stated in its resolution of November 2017 on combating inequalities, the reduction of inequalities must be one of the main priorities at European level, not only in order to tackle poverty or promote convergence but also as a precondition for economic recovery, decent job creation, social cohesion and shared prosperity. The root causes of socio—economic inequalities are related to a wide range of factors. The scission between rich and poor is widening. Labour markets and societies are evolving quickly with new opportunities and new challenges arising from globalisation, the digital revolution, changing work patterns and societal and demographic developments. The industrial revolutions for zero waste and digitalisation are presenting enormous opportunities, but they are also placing extraordinary pressure on skills. In order to overcome existing inequalities based on skills, we need a comprehensive approach. We must fill the digital skills gap and prepare both our citizens and our labour market for change. For this reason, one of our Presidency’s four priorities is the digital economy and skills for the future. Discrimination and gender inequality are two further factors that contribute to inequalities. The average gender pay gap remains above 16%, and in some Member States it is above 20%. Our citizens expect us to take action: they rank unemployment and social inequality as the most important challenges the European Union has to face. This is also a commitment that we have made at national, European and international level. The leaders of 27 Member States recognised in the Rome Declaration that economic and social inequalities were unprecedented challenges for the European Union. They pledged to work towards a social Europe which promotes economic and social progress as well as cohesion and convergence. So the key tools to overcome inequalities are the new provisions for training and for the protection of our workers – vocational training helping the redistributive potential of social protection systems. As the current Presidency, we look forward to the Commission proposal on the new social fairness package expected on 7 March. I would like to express our readiness and willingness to start negotiations on it properly within the Council. We also plan to adopt the recommendation on the Framework for Quality and Effective Apprenticeships at the March Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council (EPSCO). The signature of the proclamation of the European pillar of social rights is an important step towards reinforcing the social dimension of Europe. It provides a compass for action towards better working and living conditions in the European Union, hence renewing the process of increasing social convergence. The Council has already started to work on the implementation of the pillar. The legislative elements of the package, namely the proposals on work—life balance and on transparent and predictable working conditions, are currently being discussed in the preparatory bodies of the Council. As of this year, progress in Member States is monitored in the context of the European Semester through use of the Social Scoreboard, in line with one of the recommendations expressed by Parliament in its resolution on combating inequalities. Furthermore, Employment and Social Affairs Ministers will hold a policy debate on closing the gender pay gap, at the March Council where the future of Social Europe post—2020 will also be discussed. I would also like to focus your attention on the fact that some of the roots of socio-economic inequalities lie in natural demographic or regional disadvantages, in relation to which investment in cohesion has a very positive impact. I will listen to your debate, which is also an opportunity to reflect on the consequences of the challenges in front of us. Thank you once again for inviting me and for your attention.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the topic of this debate is the consequences of rising inequalities – a topic much-talked about in international fora such as the G20 or the United Nations, and of course also in this very House. Over the years, we have gained important insights. We know that rising inequalities act as a brake on growth. Even competitiveness is reinforced by a more equal society. We also know that rising inequalities come with social by-effects – increased crime rates, decreased health, and lower participation in our democracies. And we see every day how the discontent of citizens that feel left behind, or fear being left behind, is fuelling a populist movement. These are the consequences of rising inequalities. And also for these reasons, reducing inequalities is a priority of the Commission. The drivers behind the rise in inequalities are numerous. Therefore, our policy response must be multi-dimensional. At European level our message is clear: we have to redouble efforts along the virtuous triangle of investment, structural reforms and responsible fiscal policies, with a focus firmly on social fairness and more inclusive growth. Inequalities can only be fought through a combination of good jobs, fair tax systems, and adequate social policies. Firstly, it must aim to reduce inequalities in market income, especially by focusing on work. Raising skill levels and preparing our people for the jobs of tomorrow is the first way to address inequality in earnings. Last year we adopted the New Skills Agenda. With the right skills, people are better equipped for good-quality jobs with reliable and adequate incomes. Moreover, we must create jobs. Wherever possible, the Commission takes steps to boost job creation. For example, via the Capital Markets Union and the Digital Single Market, not to forget the European Investment Plan and Fund. We also strongly push for reforms that support growth in Member States through the European Semester. Secondly, we need to look at the tax and benefit systems. Having a job is not enough to be included, we also have to look at the tax and benefit systems. The re-launch of the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base and the initiatives on tax transparency should contribute to ensuring a fair distribution of the products of growth, income and wealth in our Member States. I also want to add the decisions on state aid – I refer to certain tax rulings in certain Member States. Lastly, we must respond to the rise in inequalities by boosting our social policies. That is why we proclaimed the European Pillar of Social Rights. The Pillar’s principles range from wages to social protection systems, from minimum income to gender equality, from childcare to old-age income, and from health care to access to housing. The European Semester will play a key role in implementing the Pillar on a national level. Already in the past, as you know, country-specific recommendations have addressed inequality-related issues. Think of the need to improve the adequacy and coverage of safety nets; or think of recommendations on childcare, on education, and on the provision of supporting services. In the current semester cycle, we build on this approach. To give you a glimpse: the Country Reports will pay special attention to investing in skills and building adequate safety nets and supporting sustainable and inclusive growth. Moreover, they will include the Social Scoreboard that accompanies the European Pillar of Social Rights. The Scoreboard contains an indicator on income inequality, but also on skills, childcare, and the impact of social transfers. This is our method of keeping track of Member States’ performance on the implementation of the principles of the Pillar, making clear that effective social policies are a priority for Europe. But we also have something to do, and for its part the Commission is also implementing the European Pillar of Social Rights. To increase the rights for the most vulnerable workers, we recently presented a proposal for a Directive on Transparent and Predictable Working Conditions. To tackle women’s under-representation in employment, and to create a more balanced distribution of caring responsibilities between women and men, we put forward the Work-Life Balance for Parents and Carers initiative. And we are now working on a Social Fairness Package. The package includes an initiative on improving access to social protection for people employed on non-standard contracts and in various forms of self-employment. This, I believe, is an extremely important step in fighting inequalities. The Package also includes a proposal for a European Labour Authority and a proposal for a European Social Security Number. More details will follow on 7 March. And of course we will continue to use the European Structural and Investment Funds to support the objectives of the Pillar. Tackling inequality is an imperative for the European Union, for economic, social and political reasons. Reducing inequalities is the only way to sustain growth and ensure continued competitiveness. It is the only way to ensure that our welfare systems remain sustainable. At the social level, we cannot leave anyone behind, everyone should participate in labour markets and in our societies. At the political level, rising inequalities drive disillusionment in politics and society. People no longer feel in control. The result is the rise of nationalism, protectionism and populism. We need to put the fight against inequalities at the top of our agenda, you are totally right. With the Pillar we have done that, but now of course it is time and we have to prove that we are able to implement it.

name: David Casa
text: f'isem il-grupp PPE. — Ilkoll naqblu illi l-economics tal-unjoni Ewropea qiegħda turkupra u tikber b'rata pożittiva, iżda minkejja dan, fuq in-naħa l-oħra tal-ispettru, teżisti realtà oħra; dik tal-inugwaljanza sojoekonomika tać-ittadini Ewropej. Kif qal il-kollega Bulmen, id-distakk bejn is-sinjur in l-fqir fil-pajjiżi membri qiegħed jikber in din hija sfida li aħna l-politii Ewropej għandna dmir li nagħtu kas għax it-tkabbir economiku li qed iseħaren mhux qed igawdi minnu kulħadd. L-effetti pożittivi ta' dan it-tkabbir mhuwiex qiegħed jasal għand kulħadd. Huwa essenzjali li nidentifikaw l-għodda li għandna bżonn biex nimmitigaw din il-problem. Bħalissa ninsabu f'perjodu fejn l-economics nazzjonali tal-istati membri qegħdin jikbru in s-suq tax-xogħol jitjieb, iżda minkejja dan, il-pagi ta-źittadini għadhom baxxi in mhumiex jiżdiedu b'mod proporzjonali. Dan ifisser illi ma rridux nassiguraw biss iżjed xogħol, iżda iżjed xogħol b'kundizzjonijiet aħjar; xogħol ta' kwalità, in dan flimkien ma' edukazzjoni bi standards għoljin u aess għal kura medika dienti, yn dawn flimkien jgħinu biex neliminaw il-problem tal-inugwaljanza. Diversi studji juru li soźjetà inklużiva in ġusta bejn l-irġiel in n-nisa twassal għal tkabbir ekonomiku iżjed b'saħtu u robust. Jiena ninsab kuntent ħafna bix-xogħol li qiegħed isir fuq il-proposta tal-kummissjoni, fuq il-work-life balance FL-Ewropa, li tagħha jiena responsabbli, però [rridu] naħdmu aktar biex nassiguraw li l-bżonnijiet ta--ittadini tagħna jiġu indirizzati għall-ġid ta' kulħadd. Jekk nilħqu dan l-għan kulħadd igawdi mir-riżultati pożittivi ta' inklużjoni in ugwaljanza.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, one percent of the European population now holds one third of the total wealth, while one third of the European population holds just one percent of the total wealth. So here we have something fundamentally wrong and something unacceptable, because this means having a lot of people in poor working conditions. The most shocking thing concerns young people because we have around one third of young people in Europe living in poverty. This is just unacceptable and this is something which is spreading social tension, hindering growth and undermining democracy and trust in the European Union. This is the outcome of the accumulated effects of a wrong economic policy, bringing austerity and social unfairness. We must reverse this. It is possible – just look at the Portuguese case – and now we have a powerful solution, which is to implement the European social pillar. With this pillar we want first of all to address the situation of children in Europe, to end child poverty and to address the situation of young people, paving the way for better jobs and access to skills, making sure that everybody can have a proper, decent labour contract and access to social protection. But how can we deliver all this? We need to have serious work to update social and labour law. We need to promote an economic policy focusing on investment and jobs for the future. We need to have a fiscal policy providing good public services. We need to have a tax policy addressing added value where it is, but most of all we need to make sure that the upcoming European budget will be used to promote this social pillar. I really hope that with the Commission and the Presidency we will move in this direction.  I really regret also that the first row of the EPP and ALDE Groups are not present and participating in this debate. They are absent on this.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR group. – Madam President, when we talk about socio-economic inequality, there are often two simple solutions that are offered, You either make the richer poorer, or you make the poorer richer, and I believe that actually what we should do is focus on pathways out of poverty. One of the most inspiring parts of my job in London, is meeting or helping the many local community projects tackling poverty in their local neighbourhoods. They are often inspired by local people who want to make a difference, so it is disappointing that when politicians or commentators talk about poverty, they tend to focus on what the state can or cannot do, or whether large NGOs are effective or not, too often neglecting the inspirational local community projects in the hearts of our communities. Though, in some ways, both the Left and the Right have failed the poor. While the Left believe in top-down government, taxing people more to distribute more money to the poor via more public servants, more trade unions, etc., we all know of areas where lots of money has been spent over the years and we still see deprivation in those areas. But many on the Right argue that poverty is best tackled by cutting taxes, creating more jobs with additional wealth trickling down to the poor, but they forget that the welfare state was created since private provision did not reach everyone. So while state welfare and large NGOs do have a role to play, last month the ECR Group held a global poverty summit which brought together local community projects from across the world to tell their inspiring stories of how they tackled poverty at a grass-roots level. So, whether the Left call it cooperative socialism, or the Right call it community conservatism or localist libertarianism, I hope that we can all pay more attention and champion the role of grass-roots anti-poverty projects in all our local communities, rather than top-down state or top-down wealth, and I see the Left laughing and insulting these very many community projects. Allow me on a personal note to end on that equality. I realise I am the first non-white leader of any political group in this Parliament, but I’m still shocked by the lack of racial diversity not only in this House, but across all EU institutions, and if the EU is going to have any credibility on the issues of diversity and equality, it needs to get its own house in order. Let us, across the political spectrum, reach out to young people in all our countries and tell them that whatever your colour, your gender, your religion, your orientation or your background, you should not be afraid to put yourself forward for public office. The EU is often accused of being a rich white man’s club. It is time to take action if the EU really wishes to live up to its motto of ‘United in Diversity’.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon
text: au nom du group ALDE. — Madame la Presente, he souhaite the welcome to Madame la Commissaire, c'est toujours a plaisir. Je poursuis in the language of Cervantes. It is already a source of satisfaction, on such a sad day for Europe, that we are finally considering ourselves — and that is why I fought from the beginning in this Parliament — the problem of inequalities and their very serious consequences, which are obvious, and therefore we will give the title of this debate an answer immediately: the consequences on citizens is that the economy is growing less, there is more unemployment because of the lack of cohesion of societies, and policies are evident, as everyone has said: the birth of detachment from political systems, detachment to democracy, detachment from European institutions, using them as turkheads. So what I want to say to the Commissioner is that there are three essential ways to combat this. The first way is to go to structures and change the inequality dynamics in the medium term, and that is why economic policies are essential, but much more than just, of course, taxes, investment is important: investments that favour human capital can be made, which favor infrastructures for the improvement of the society, or not. Trade is too. Also energy policy, to combat energy poverty. Large macroeconomic policies, which we have now managed to get to address the Gini index, are important. The second pillar is what Mrs Thyssen carries: it is social policies, but above all, not those that palate inequalities, poverty, etc. — those are already there, these are indispensable patches — but those which structure a flexible but more egalitarian labour market. Thirdly and lastly — we often forget this — we must combat inequalities with more and better Europe because, without an omnicomprehensible solidarity vision of Europe, financially, we will not fight inequalities well in Europe and in the model we have chosen.

name: Rina Ronja Kari
text: on behalf of the Gue/NGL Group. — Madam President, First of all, I would like to thank the Socialists for putting this very important issue on the agenda. There is no doubt that much of what has been said here today, of course, we also agree with: there are big, serious problems. There is a great deal of social insecurity. There is a lot of unemployment. In addition, too many citizens today are worried about themselves and about the future of their children. But would it not be great if we from the European Parliament could send a positive signal that it is moving forward? Or at least about the fact that we actually take the concerns of citizens seriously? That they're being heard? Dear colleagues! If we're going to look citizens in the eye, we have to be honest. The problems have become stronger and have become more significant because of the EU single market and because of the economic cutting policy, which has been enforced by the fiscal pact. If we actually do away with the rising inequality, it also requires a break with the EU we see today. That requires a break with economic policy in the fiscal pact. If you social democrats we help to make that break, then we welcome it very welcome. It's much needed.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, from Piketty to the OECD, the IMF and Oxfam, the reports are increasing and they all converge: inequalities in income and wealth have been rising. Imagine, last year, the richest, who represent 1% of the population, siphoned 82% of the wealth created. And this is not a product of chance or I do not know what law of nature, it is the product of political choices. In order to clean up public finances and achieve greater economic efficiency — “efficiency” is fashionable — we need to flexibilize labour markets, put public services and social protection under pressure, soften any legislation that would weaken or impede our businesses, even when it comes to protecting labour markets. health or the environment. We have to go to the pension later, when young people struggle to find a job. Unemployment benefits have to be reduced, whereas in some parts of the European Union you have dozens and dozens of candidates for a job offer. Rest assured, good people, growth is back and employment with it. But the problem is that this job is getting precarious. He is getting less and less well paid, while capital holders capture an ever-increasing portion of the cake. We would like to believe that making the rich richer and multinationals more powerful would benefit everyone. Well, ladies and gentlemen, the economy of runoff exists, and it defies the laws of gravity, because money goes from the poor to the rich. All of this has very concrete consequences of course because, in our rich European Union, a quarter of our fellow citizens, including millions who are working, are at risk of poverty and social exclusion, to the point where some people have to choose between eating or treating themselves, to the point of dying on the streets of our cities. Mrs Thyssen, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that the European pillar of social rights has been born. However, if we want to reverse the inequality curve and this pillar is something other than a moral alibi, we must not only make it as binding as the European budgetary rules, but definitely change course in our economic policies to put them at the service of the greatest number of our fellow citizens.

name: Laura Agea
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, eight people in the world have the wealth of almost three billion people. These are the Oxfam data, which of course can only make us cringe. If we bring this data into our Europe, we see that little changes if we think that almost 130 million European citizens live below the poverty line. It is necessary to make a change of strategy, a change of course and allow this Titanic to reach a safe harbor. The economic policies carried out by the European Union in recent years have desertified social and employment rights, the health and well-being of citizens, sold and sacrificed on the altar of the stability of structural reforms which did not take account of what were the consequences which were only and only on defenseless citizens. To take note of this is not only a dutiful one, but must require us legislators, the Commission, the Council and us MEPs to reverse the gear. The only structural reforms that serve Europe at the mercy of itself are those that guarantee the welfare of citizens: adequate salaries, guaranteed and public health, working conditions acceptable, adequate wages, a guarantee for children living below the poverty line. Until we look after our children, we couldn't be the ones going to lecture democracy to other countries. It takes commitment, courage and immediate action.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, inequalities in society are of all times. To some extent, inequalities are also good. Because if there are no successful people, who is the role model for young people? And what should ambition be focused on? But in the Netherlands there has been no purchasing power growth for families for decades, according to Rabobank's research. Taxes have risen for an ever-growing government, for example to pay mass immigration and development aid and subsidies for anyone with a left-wing opinion, but also for the ever-increasing expenditure of the European Union. After all, political ambitions are paid by citizens as wage slaves. Such a costly political ambition is the euro. The lack of exchange rates between countries has led to mass unemployment and deranged public finances. Thanks to the euro, there are now countries where, instead of stagnation, incomes have actually fallen, namely in southern Europe. Millions of people from these countries have moved to Northern Europe in search of jobs, looking for prospects that are no longer to be found there. Mr President, this is no longer possible. What we need is lower taxes and a higher labour income ratio. Migration must be stopped and the euro dismantled. It's that simple.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President! There is much talk in this Chamber about migration, external migration, immigration to Europe, but very little is said about internal migration, labour flows from the eastern side of the Union to the western half. Prices have equalized between the two sides of the EU, but there is a gap between wages. And this is what the Jobbik Movement for Hungary recognized when it launched a European citizens' initiative, which the Commission adopted, that we are starting to close this pay gap, because if this does not happen, this could lead to the whole Union being broken up. Of course, overnight, you can not achieve results. But when we think about the budget for next seven years, it would be important to direct the resources, the cohesion funds, to these countries in a way that supports real added value businesses, who can create quality jobs and contribute to this pay gap reduction.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by addressing Mrs Maria João Rodrigues and saying that her reference to the presidency of the EPP was deeply regrettable. Firstly, because the chairman of your group is not here either; secondly, because it was a profound disrespect for all the members of this House. If the Socialist Group considers that there is only representation in the first line of this plenary on the part of the European People's Party, we are here all the Members of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs holding this debate. And your miserable speech is also deeply regrettable, Mr President. We must have European policies that translate into a real social lever. We must have European policies so that economic growth and the fight against inequalities can be guaranteed, so that a whole society can be leveraged with proportionate and differentiated policies. This implies greater attention to the middle class and the middle class in our country has low wages, very close to the minimum wage, but pays taxes, pays contributions, does not have the same support in accessing the education of their children, does not have the same support in social security, does not have the same support in access to health. It's a class that, in net terms, is gaining far below the blows and we cannot have a miserable speech that forgets the middle class because the Europe that I advocate is a Europe of equal opportunities, it is not exclusive to another class, it has to have differentiated policies applicable to everyone, so that we can pursue the European dream.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Council and the Commissioner for their response. I think this debate on rising inequality and the consequences of it is core to what we should do, as politicians, to fight these consequences, to ensure that we have policies that will change this behaviour and ensure that, instead of inequality, we have quality spread out through our societies. It has been said many times that eight men now own the same as half of the world’s population. It is a disgrace and, also, if you look at the years 2008 to 2016, we spent EUR 653 billion to save the banks in Europe, but how much effort do we spend to save young people and the people who are suffering the inequalities that are on the rise. It is economic inequality and inequality in health. It is in education and all aspects of society. I have to say to my good colleague, Mr Kamall, that fighting inequality is more than charity. Actually where we have well—functioning welfare states in Europe, that is the biggest equality machine we can create on this planet. It is proven. Come to the Nordic countries and you see that it works – and listen. What the EU can do is important. The Commissioner alluded to it. We need a strong social pillar. We need to ensure that we support our Member States so they can fight inequality and create opportunity for all of us. We need a strong social contract because our social contract is jeopardised in our societies today, with severe consequences for democracy and for extremism. So we need to rebuild our social contract and I think we also need a social contract that will ensure that the big multinational corporations and the rich individuals pay their fair tax. It is too easy for them to avoid paying their fair tax and it is undermining our welfare state and undermining the fight against inequality. So, friends, we believe in a European dream and a European dream is that all people, regardless of their background, have the chance to have a good life, good education and good work. (Applause)

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: Madam President! Mr Bullmann, Mrs Rodrigues, I am grateful to you for putting this issue on the agenda. It's really a hot topic. But I must say that I have only heard normative phrases here: we have to do, we have to introduce rights. A doctor, when doing therapies, first makes a diagnosis. I haven't heard a diagnosis here. The Eurozone is considered as a single entity. Unemployment is said to have declined in 2017. No, if you clear Germany, unemployment is still higher than in 2009, and if we see that unemployment is falling now and employment is increasing — yes, where is it increasing? In the precarious working conditions, in the low wage. This is the consequence of an internal devaluation. That's just so. If you are a monetary union, two are away from the three action parameters that are central to the competitiveness of an economy: interest rates and exchange rates. Only the labour market remains. Only wages stay there. Unemployment is rising, wages are falling, and then we become competitive again. That is the consequence of monetary union. There's so much more to scold about inequality. You have to start here. If the labour market reacts as an adjustment mechanism, we have exactly the situation you are complaining about now, and we will complain about that again in five years' time because it has not changed. What we really need to do is ensure that countries become competitive. Without competitiveness, there are no well-paid jobs. If the Economist said about Greece ten years ago: Greece's economy is hopelessly uncompetitive. This is the reason for the difficulties that Greece is experiencing. If you complain about that, you are politically accepted. If you have monetary union, it's always about the Labour market. And then I hear here: we need to make monetary union safer. No, we need to make jobs safer for people and incomes, not monetary union!

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, thank you for this debate which I hope will be fruitful. Regional policy is an important aspect of the fight against poverty. In Europe there are regions where many more people than the EU average live at or below the poverty line. However, in a particularly bad situation are those regions that suffer from poor quality of EU relations with the European neighbourhood. In my native country, Estonia, Ida-Virumaa county is an example of a territory with such problems. It is a very poor, de-industrialised region, geographically isolated on the EU-Russian border and populated by a Russian linguistic minority. In such conditions the fight against poverty is also an important security issue. In regions like Ida-Virumaa the fight against poverty must be comprehensive. For this, both economic restructuring and normalisation of relations with neighbouring Russia are needed. I support the expansion of all opportunities to support out of the European Structural Funds any national policies aimed at the reduction of poverty, and, of course, the implementation of the social pillar. For I strongly believe that poverty causes indifference, and indifference is bad support for protecting European borders.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, there is talk here today of socio-economic inequalities as if they were the result of divine will or of some natural catastrophe, but they are not, they are the result of concrete policies, many of which are imposed by this European Union. These policies are the liberalisation of the labour market, precariousness, low wages, high unemployment and unsustainable levels of poverty. The Commissioner has tabled, among other proposals, the increase in wages and also the creation of new jobs. What I ask you, Commissioner, is how this is compatible with the recommendation that the European Commission made to Portugal and Spain just this week, to say that we need to go further in reforms that reduce excessive labour protection in permanent contracts. Commissioner, it is precarious contracts that deepen inequality, it is low wages that deepen inequality. We do need to create jobs, but jobs with rights. In Portugal the minimum wage has been raised against Brussels, the cuts against Brussels have been restored and I hope that labour legislation will also be strengthened against Brussels.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, yes, colleagues are right. Social inequality should be fought by any means, and as a matter of itself, but even more so – as any history book will tell you – when there are rising inequalities in society. There are certain politicians, and we have them here in this Chamber too, who will use this – who will instrumentalise the fear and the social problems arising from it – to play the weaker against the weakest. We see this today. We see refugees being played against pensioners, we see Greek nurses being played against single mothers in Germany. And, I tell you, instead of following this divisive rhetoric and these divisive so-called proposals, we need to present something from European level to show that we are fighting for greater social equality. I agree, yes, we have a currency union so we are tied together: so we also have to work together on social matters and introduce social standards at European level, because otherwise I believe the whole European project is in danger, and we do not want that. We need to act now.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: — With regard to the growing consequences of social and economic inequalities for European citizens, the first question should be answered, what is not being done so that the inequality is constantly growing? Maybe that social exclusion is increasing constantly frightening, frightening military threats and financing the establishment of new military units and the war industry in the same Europe? While the gods of war get rich, society is increasingly in poverty. I believe that in the fight against social exclusion, only words will come a time when youth unemployment, politicians service to the capital of oligarchs, propaganda of globalism and public poverty will become a catalyst that will light up the fire of civil resistance in individual European countries.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Madam President, two days ago in this Parliament, Mr Draghi told us that the European economy had grown by 2.5% last year – his predictions were for 1.5%. We know that many of our domestic economies are growing and about the challenges to harness and to channel that growth where it can be effective, but have evidence that jobs as we know them are changing, the labour market is changing and the typical permanent pensionable job is no longer there for many. There is evidence of temporary, part—time working on a contract basis, flexible labour market and, of course, with automation, robots and globalisation, employment as we know it is changing. So we need to ensure that we have strong and effective protection measures in place for workers. Minimum income is important and tackling zero—hours contracts is very, very important to give some certainty to workers.  But it is not all about inequality in terms of income. It is also about inequality in terms of opportunity, and inequality in terms of outcomes as well. We continually need to focus on skills and education and ensure that our young people, in particular, have the necessary training, the necessary education opportunities, if we are to provide them with the skills that employers are articulating today that they do not have and cannot find on the labour market.  Some European countries have better outcomes than others, and we must work together to ensure that those differences are addressed. The forthcoming European Social Pillar is one way that we can tackle those inequalities in a European way.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we, the Socialists and Democrats, have found new, unexpected allies and I don’t mean here in the Chamber. I mean that, if the International Monetary Fund and the European Central Bank are pleading for a pay rise for employees in Europe, what more need we say? Yet can we stay silent on the consequences of rising social and economic inequalities in Europe? Let us start on a positive note. The European economy is growing, unemployment rates are falling and most economic theorists are telling us the fairytale that people will benefit from growth. But unfortunately not everybody is getting a fair share of the pie. On the one hand, we see companies still focusing on the well—being of their shareholders while the pay gap between the top chiefs and the average worker remains startling, and most multinationals are also still dodging taxes. On the other hand, we see the working-class families in Europe falling behind. Being in work reduces the risk of poverty. That is, at least, the normal theory. How is it possible then in Europe that the number of working poor is still growing and growing? I will repeat what our unexpected allies are saying, namely that a pay rise would be good for business, for jobs, for workers and therefore for the European economy: a pay rise which, in my view, cannot be achieved without strong trade unions and strong collective bargaining. That does not, of course, help to reduce child poverty. We should address that issue separately. But a pay rise is really necessary.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! In taking the floor in this debate, I want to stress very strongly that the Polish delegation in the ECR group is strongly opposed to the harmonisation of the social policies of the Member States, the creation of a single social security system or a single pension system. The countries admitted to the Union after 2004 are still shortening the distance to the most developed countries of Western Europe, but they still cannot afford the same level of social spending. In order to accelerate the development of the whole European Union, a decidedly better effect than the social inequality decision would have a discussion of removing interborder inequalities, such as the elimination of inequality in the treatment of enterprises from the countries of the new Union in the markets of the countries of the old Union, elimination of restrictions on access to the market for services in the countries of the old European Union, or the elimination of double quality standards of products depending on the country in which they are sold.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, today we have heard the headline figures on the wealth divide, but I want to look at some of the underlying figures.  Two points: employment is increasing, but the number of people working full—time in 2017 is lower than in 2008 and the number of people working part—time in 2017 is 11.9 % higher than in 2008. We also have a rise in bogus self—employment with many workers having no security whatsoever. Therefore, Commissioner, I anticipate your proposal on social fairness and hope it will deliver, regardless of the sector. Secondly, intergenerational fairness. Youth employment levels are almost twice the average unemployment levels, but even more worrying is the fact that since 2007 younger workers are significantly losing income share as opposed to older workers, and this is increasing year on year. That is an unexploded bomb in our midst.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: — Madam President, the existing data reflect the unequivocal reality of increasing and tremendous inequalities in the EU, inequalities aggravated by the European Union's austerity policies which, in countries like Portugal, have had very serious consequences. The policies of the EU and the parties that follow it blindly in Portugal have brought precariousness, the brutal increase in exploitation, labour deregulation, unemployment, poverty and the exodus of hundreds of thousands of citizens. The struggle of the workers and the people, the firm action of the Portuguese communists imposed the reversal of many serious measures, allowed the increase in income, the recovery of social rights, with a significant impact on the population, albeit of limited scope. It is the corset of economic governance and the policies of the European Union that imposes these limitations on the necessary labour and social advances, on the country's development and investment policies. This is demonstrated by the country-specific recommendations or the latest quarterly report for the euro area, which states that Portugal has excessive labour protection from endless contracts, exposing the deception that is the social pillar.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the society that puts equality before freedom ends up with neither. We’re here again, talking about the European social pillar, one of my favourite subjects. it is a do-gooders charter. it is more intervention by the state into the lives of individual people and into businesses. it is the dead hand of the state pressing down upon all of our economies, seeking to alter and change things to suit the view of the elite in rooms like this. What about giving people equality of opportunity rather than equality of outcome? The poor do not want to be treated like clients of the state; the poor want to work their way to more prosperity. The reality is that when you hear the lover of the big state talking about equality, what they want to do is take all of our levels of income and bring them closer together and level it down. The lover of freedom doesn’t mind if we’re going up, as long as we’re going up. Everyone’s level of wealth and income goes up according to their ability and their talents and their skills and their economic ability within their country. Let’s make our people wealthier. Let’s make the whole peoples of Europe wealthier – and here’s the way we do it. We free them. We free them to have free market enterprise. We free them to express their talents and skills. We free them to make money, and we free the nation states so that each and every nation state can compete according to its ability, can make the right environment for its people to trade and make money in, and can each and every one of them unleash a real entrepreneurial spirit and allow the poor to get better conditions and more wealth for their families through hard work. Free our people. Free our nations, and wealth will come with free enterprise.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, if Europe is better and the indicators go back green, there are still many inequalities. 87 million Europeans live below the poverty line, almost one in six Europeans. Combating these inequalities requires a multitude of actions, and the social pillar initiative is obviously in the right direction. For my part, I would like to stress the need to ensure everyone's access to skills, regardless of their territory or gender, in order to integrate easily and sustainably into the labour market. To acquire this background of skills and to be in line with the needs of companies, it is on learning, in initial or continuing training, that we must now focus on. Apprenticeship is the path of excellence to train in a profession and thus to integrate more easily into companies and protect themselves more sustainably from poverty. To convince young people to make it a first choice, states now need to change their image with professions and better frame it. It is also necessary to change the logic that prevails at the time of orientation. Learning must become a chosen and not undergone path. Secondly, it is necessary to support apprentices better throughout their learning journey, with a personalized approach. Finally, mobility must be opened up to apprentices.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: Madam President, a new consensus is emerging from the great recession that tells us that the current and unbearable levels of inequality and the obscene concentrations of wealth that are couched not only question us in ethical or social terms but today are undermining our democracies, putting the liberal order itself at risk international or European integration and damaging our economies and our potential economic growth. What to deal with this unbearable reality? Act, first, in the field of the labour market: precariousness, low wages, or collective bargaining, which is at the root of income inequality. Act in our welfare states to be able to update them and to play the redistribution role they had always had to play. Act to combat gender inequality, especially addressing the wage gap. Act to coordinate our tax and tax policies and give room for manoeuvre to Member States' budgets. Act to regulate and deal with digitalisation, international trade or globalization, which we know generate profits but then share them very badly. Act to rebuild solidarity between generations and thus respond to young people's lack of opportunities, or to the worst side of poverty: child poverty. And act at all levels. Also at European level, as a recent report from the European Parliament adopted this autumn. Because what made this continent unique, Europe, was its social market economy, that is, reconciling progress, democracy and growth. And the European pillar of social rights is our tool to give body to the soul of Europe.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: — Mr President, the development of inequality begins at its worst in childhood. Increasingly, children of underprivileged parents are self-deprived in their lives, without the possibility of social uplift. This makes it paramount that a level of public day care and school provide similar starting points for all children, despite the family background. The demands of self-referential for those already primary school age and the hard demands of working life later displace many. We here in the European Parliament, in the Commission and in the Member States should constantly think about how we can reduce growing inequality. Guaraning the most egalitarian starting points for all children, from advice to day care and narrowing learning disparities are the best means. This is something we can all contribute to through the development of services for families with children in our own countries and structures and policies related to education.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, unemployment, low-quality jobs, poverty, inequality, disaffection: this, Commissioner, is not a biblical plague. It is the consequence of the neoliberal, socially and environmentally predatory policies that they have implemented to take advantage of the crisis for the benefit of a few. Now they are scandalized because this generates disaffection and the far right and fascism grow. Well, correct it is easy and it's in your hand. Change policies. And not nominal, as they are doing with the social pillar. Call for the reverse of labour reforms; for collective bargaining to be restored; for quality employment to be generated; that wages be increased and the role of workers' representation should also be strengthened; for the establishment and enhancement of public mechanisms to combat poverty, such as minimum income and such as pensions; the recovery of public services, public investment, research, technologies and, above all, culture. I know your finance partners and multinationals don't like these recipes, but they would be surprised, if they went out on the street, how well they would be received by workers and citizens.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the real reason for the rising social and economic inequalities among European citizens is the EU’s open-door, uncontrolled mass migration from Asia and Africa of low-skilled and unskilled workers. This depresses wages and stresses social and health services to breaking point. Many of them are at that point now. This is one of the main reasons why Great Britain is leaving the EU. Our workers are angry. They are losing their jobs, and they are losing their health service. Thanks to Angela Merkel’s open invitation to migrants, we have been importing real poverty at a time when labour is being replaced by robotics and computers throughout Europe. This has led to violence, social disruption and racism. Look at what is happening in Sweden. The euro, which is essentially a soft deutschmark, has impoverished the people of southern Europe and created mass unemployment in Spain – as you, Ms Rodrigues, know – and in Portugal, with financial collapse and EU direct rule in Greece and the removal of their freely elected government. The European Union fears Brexit, really fears it. Britain is a free-market alternative to the EU’s economic model which is, on the other hand, an East-European-style socialist command economy that has failed miserably over the last 50 years. Why would you want to return to this? Why must so many people in this place – many of you who worked for East European totalitarian regimes – want to return to that human misery? Why? Why won’t you learn?  Britain will sit on the EU’s doorstep, and show your system up for the sham that it is. We will attract other countries, such as Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic, to come and join us and see what a real free arrangement of sovereign nations is all about.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the worrying long-term increase in inequality, both in times of growth as well as during recession, should indeed worry us. It is the least well-off who suffer most of the consequences of inequality. However, the phenomenon has already started to bite into the fortunes and social mobility of the middle class, too. More and more working families are struggling to make ends meet. Besides its impact on the individual and on social cohesion in general, income inequality raises other concerns as well: it undermines the good functioning of the economy, slows productivity and growth, and hampers innovation. The whole society suffers if we do not have a healthy, well-skilled and well-educated workforce. In my country, the richest 20% of the population have an income over eight times higher than that of the poorest 20%. This is the result not just of unequal access to education, services and the labour market, but also of the toleration of undeclared work and an ineffective tax and social transfer system, as the Commission has underlined in its Country Specific Recommendations. This is why it is so urgent that we search for effective means to reduce inequality. The solution can only lie in a coordinated and wide enough use of policy instruments, such as development of fair and effective taxation systems, creation of good jobs, and investment in quality early education that is accessible to all, as well as in continuous skill-development enabling upward mobility.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by quoting the work of Richard Wilkinson, a British researcher who has done groundbreaking work on inequality. Basically, it can be summarized as follows: societies where deep inequality prevails are societies where things are very difficult. Conversely, a society with little inequality and much equality is a society where everyone is happy. Everyone is very important. It's not just about the poor. Everyone in society is better off when there is less inequality. What is perhaps important to emphasise is that great and growing inequality is also a danger to our democracy. That actually makes sense. People who all build a society together and all contribute to it in their own way but are rewarded for it quite unfairly feel that it is very unfair. Democracy — we all know — is much more than this Parliament or the rule of law. That is a means of achieving an end. In other words, to ensure that everyone can live together freely and happily, and that can be done in a society with less inequality. That is essential. The Commission has recently — with our full support — been extremely active in the area of the rule of law. Think about what we do in Poland. Think of what we do in Hungary. That's important. That part of democracy is being defended. The question is: will we please defend that other part of democracy with the same amount of fire? My colleagues have already spoken about the social pillar and fair taxation. But let's be very clear. It is about a challenge that is much broader than tackling poverty, however important it may be. It is about an approach that ensures that our European democracy has a future.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: Madam President! The studies which have been used here for years by the European Parliament are partly questionable in terms of methodology. They are throwing post-communist countries that still have low inequality and high growth in one pot with Western states. However, inequality is the incentive in a market economy to be productive. Because yes, there is inequality. In my country, housing prices are getting out of control in many cities because internal EU migration is very high and Mario Draghi's monetary policy is creating bubbles in real estate markets. This puts millions of households under pressure — that's unfair. There are other bubbles, such as in the stock markets. Shareholders have become richer because Mario Draghi is pushing up the prices. If interest rates are no longer manipulated, they will lose that wealth. Should you punish shareholder for Draghi's monetary policy? That would not be fair, because this inequality is politically caused. The policy of this House often helps, albeit unintentionally, to exacerbate inequality.

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, for decades the European Union has believed in unbridled market forces. We all know that the market has an eye for the shareholders. We all know that the market wants to keep wages as low as possible. This leads to flex jobs and poverty. Because with a job you can't get by, your kid goes to school hungry. In the Netherlands, the food banks are no longer able to cope with the demand of 135 000 people. In Rotterdam on the market I see people looking for the last food leftovers in the evening after closing time. That's Europe. That is the Netherlands at the moment. If we continue to believe in a market that we do not regulate, exploitation continues, shareholders have a good time and most people — the 90% who do not have about two-thirds of the remaining 10% assets — have to check. I want a social protocol that submits the market to social rights and not a non-binding social pillar.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Dear ladies! We have been seeing economic recovery and recovery in the Union for some time. Unemployment is falling steadily. Investment is increasing. Unfortunately, the benefits of this situation do not spread evenly between the citizens of the European Union. We are witnessing persistent or outright deepening inequalities. I believe that for economic growth to be inclusive and encompass society as a whole, we must first and foremost take care of a well-functioning labour market. Cutting unemployment alone isn't enough. The work has to be of good quality. Provide workers with stability and safety and adequate remuneration. It is also necessary to fight against abuse with all firmness, that is, above all, undeclared work, but also with forced part-time work. Employees must also have convenient conditions for combining family and professional life in order to be able to remain active also in the situation of childcare or a dependent person. Nor can we forget the most vulnerable members of our society: the disabled, the chronically ill and the elderly. We need to provide adequate support and opportunities, while the others are worthy conditions for active ageing and participation in society. Of course, in order to preserve the competitiveness of the economy and a good economic situation, we need to maintain the right balance and support entrepreneurs as well, ensuring they have access to financing and new technologies.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the topic of this discussion – the consequences of rising socio-economic inequalities for European citizens – is central to overall European Union policies. The drastic statistics on inequalities, surpassing any imaginable degree of sustainability, are by now more than well known. But what are the driving forces and, above all, the policy responses? As for the reasons, the aim of maximising short-term profits has led to a corporate model based on price competition and avoidance of obligations, be they social or environmental. In addition, it has led to downward pressures on workers’ and producers’ pay and on labour and environmental standards, and to companies paying as little tax as possible; with ever greater political power in favour of policies preserving and safeguarding the present system. The European Union’s main tool for reducing inequalities between and within Member States is cohesion policy, which we must endow with political power, human resources and financial needs, ensuring it becomes the lead priority in the post-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). This means that European funding for cohesion policy must increase. The new cohesion policy framework needs to support, in particular but not only, the poorest European regions. Priority emphasis must be put on social investment. National co-financing should not be taken into account in deficit calculations as part of the Stability and Growth Pact, and grants ought to remain the standard form of financing. Furthermore it is crucial that citizens become actively engaged in shaping the policies that influence their daily lives. This means gaining citizens’ support for transforming the EU into a fully fledged Social Union – a Union of the people, by the people and for the people.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in this House during this debate I have heard several times the Oxfam data, which of course concern me very much too. But I have heard of increasing poverty and increasing inequality as if it were natural disasters, as if there were no political responsibilities in determining this framework and this increase in inequality. I think that political responsibilities must be appointed, because they are also in this House, they are of the grand coalition between the popular and socialists who have a majority in this Parliament, who govern the Commission, which govern in many Member States. I believe that there are absolutely viable solutions: the reduction of hours to equal wages, full equal wage between women and men, the minimum guaranteed income, as already provided for by one resolution of this European Parliament, and a European minimum wage. If we did not prepend the Fiscal Compact and the defense of profits to the defence of labor, we could do them in Europe as well.

name: Geoffroy Didier (PPE).
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Nelson Mandela said that, as long as injustice persisted, no one could rest. Obviously, from rest, we are not ready to take any. Yes, inequality is getting worse with a poverty risk rate that now affects one quarter of the European population. The first victims of this phenomenon are obviously the peoples themselves, but do not deceive ourselves, it is also the image of Europe that is now at stake, because inequality is the main cause of distrust in European integration. And it is in this House more than elsewhere that we must not only be aware of the fractures, but also find ways to address them. Today I propose one very concrete one: let us deepen Europe where it is most useful. As you know, the Youth Employment Initiative, which helps all those in the new generation who do not attend education or training, already applies to regions where youth unemployment is over 25%. In concrete terms, I propose that this European policy can in future be extended to regions where the youth unemployment rate is higher, not 25%, but 20%. This would mean, for example, that in my country, in France, where, unfortunately, everyone is experiencing widening inequalities as a result of a particularly unfair government policy, the European aid programme would apply no longer to seven but to twelve regions. Ladies and gentlemen, in conclusion, we believe fundamentally in Europe, because it is union that is the strength, but if we want to legitimize it in the hearts of the peoples, let us very quickly give it a much more social vocation and a... (The President withdrew the floor)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: — Speaking from this tribune today about growing economic and social inequalities, first and foremost, the attention of everyone — both the Commissioner and the Presidency and my colleagues — I want to draw to our small citizens, our children. Let us answer the question: are we able to provide them with normal living conditions, do they receive proper nutrition, quality education, healthcare, or do we invest enough in our children to eradicate their poverty and inequality? The answer is unequivocal — of course, not. I therefore appeal once again, Madam Commissioner, to you and the Member States to promptly draw up and approve the Child Guarantee, which allows us to apply concrete financially sound measures to combat child poverty. Listen, over 20 million children are in poverty in the European Union. Therefore, it is no longer possible to delay. And especially now that we are discussing and preparing the Multiannual Financial Perspective, let us foresee financial investments in the children of the European Union. And this will be our greatest achievement. And secondly, what I want to pay attention to is a huge inequality between men and women. To date, the salaries of men and women for the same work vary by 16 percent, and pensions vary at the same time. We get them as much as 40% smaller. And here it is necessary to work and effort.

name: La Présidente. –
text: Merci Madame. On and will probablement.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Dear ladies! Commissioner! Inequalities in Europe are on the rise, but not between states. Inequalities between states are dwindling, and only inside states are steadily increasing. The top 10% of households in Europe earn 30% of all family income and own 50% of all goods owned by a family. And these inequalities are escalating, and with them health, social and economic problems, because inequalities are not conducive to economic development. And from these data, one can clearly derive such a thesis that if we want to reduce poverty, we should reduce inequality. Studies also show that the strongest instrument for reducing inequality is education and increasing women's employment. I am pleased that Commissioner Thyssen is here with us, because I believe that this package of role reconciliation, particularly the non-legislative part on kindergartens, will have a positive impact on women's inclusion in the labour market. It is also important in the context of reducing inequalities stable forms of employment, but above all increased participation of workers in the economy, for example by holding shares of companies, by the presence of representatives of workers on boards, but also by social cooperatives or action cooperatives. But the main thing — and this is the last sentence — is that we avoid such a trap of going towards developing the welfare state.
