I believe that one should move towards subjectivity, increasing citizens' subjectivity and increasing social participation, because only betting on subjectivity will make us constantly creative and competitive in the global market.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: Madam President, economic growth is not a synonym or guarantee of equality. Those who take care of macroeconomic data and at the same time puts a blindfold on their eyes and is not able to see how this is affecting people's lives does the European social model a weak favor. Because growth should be converted and translated into decent wages, workers' rights, fair pensions. And today that's not happening. And the representatives of the Council and the Commission are here, and I would like to recall one thing. Just over a month ago, priorities were set for next year and one issue was not taken into account: today, in Europe, inequality has a woman's face. We are half the European population, and the priorities set by the European institutions do not talk about reconciling family and work life, we do not talk about the wage gap we are suffering so much, there is no mention of gender-based violence. If you don't remember it, within a month, on March 8, hundreds of thousands of men and women will come out, we will take to the streets to remind you.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Madam President, inequality is nothing new. But what must be unsettling us is that in times of economic growth, inequality does not decrease. Digitization, for example, creates new opportunities, can't do without investment and new skills. Then the gap between those who seize the new options, take advantage of them, and those who simply can't make it without help. That's why we need to talk about inclusion, about quality education for all. It is trickier for young people to find application in the labour market if they do not have a practice. New, non-standard forms of work such as crowdworking thanks to flexibility allow work for those who might not otherwise work, it also creates a category of second-class workers without social protection. The solution to inequalities is not to introduce a so-called guaranteed income. That, among other things, lacks an element of motivation. Programmes that address the availability of education help at the level of the European Union. Reducing inequality means primarily increasing opportunity. And we have the opportunity to strengthen Erasmus+, it is still exclusive, still few young people reach for involvement in this program. So if we want to reduce inequality, then we also need to increase the budget for Erasmus+, which enables funding projects to modernise education, emphasizes apprenticeships and practice, and entrepreneurial skills.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, our economies, the world of work and our societies are changing. Some changes, such as automation and digitalisation, may increase the skills premium for high—skilled workers and inequalities may increase, but the answer to these challenges is not to reject the benefits that technology can bring. Instead we must strengthen the European workforce and step forward with more effective employment and social policy, with education, with skilling, with upskilling and with training systems. We must shape the future, and let us indeed continue to foster equal opportunities for under-represented groups, including in our own institutions. I have said it before and I’ll say it again: there is no trade—off between having more equality on one hand and having more growth on the other. Well—designed reforms can – and should – achieve both. We too have said in our Annual Growth Survey, in the euro area Council recommendation and in some country—specific recommendations that promoting wage growth under certain conditions would be a good thing. As the economic recovery continues in Europe, it is essential to make sure no one is left behind. Combating inequalities is – and will remain – a priority for the Commission, and we address it through a mix of policy levers: good jobs, fair taxation and adequate social protection. The Commission cannot – and will not – do this alone. This requires a collective effort, first of all at European level, but also at national level and at local level. Indeed, let us cherish and support grassroots social projects as we do with the European Social Fund. We have also to work together with social partners and other stakeholders. Let us not forget that reducing inequality does not happen just like that. But I am confident that we can move further in the right direction. What we have to do everywhere – all of us – is to roll up our sleeves and get to work. Thank you for this debate.

name: Monika Panayotova
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, inequality is a cross—cutting issue so the Council has already taken steps on the various aspects of this issue. This year, the Council will continue to work on the implementation of the Social Pillar and together with the Commission we will monitor the social situation in individual Member States. As Commissioner Thyssen just said, the Council, Parliament and the Commission all have a role to play.  Thank you once again for the opportunity to discuss this far—reaching topic. It has shown the wide—ranging nature of the challenges ahead of us. It also outlined possible ways towards building a Union which is based on sustainable growth and which promotes economic prosperity, social development and equal opportunities for all.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the S&D Group we have a long and solid track record in the fight against inequalities, the most recent example is the report adopted by the European Parliament on 'Combating inequalities to boost job creation and growth', rapporteur Javi López was rapporteur. Not only do inequalities question us in ethical or social terms, but today they also undermine our democracies and European integration itself, damaging our potential growth. We are clear that cuts in wages, pensions and public services contribute to increasing inequality and the wage gap and the deterioration of citizen welfare. That is why we call on the EU legislative and financial measures to ensure the quality of employment and the welfare state, and the redistribution of the benefits generated by international trade, and the coordination of fiscal policies. What made this continent unique in the last century was its social market economy, that is, reconciling progress, democracy and sustainable growth. In this regard, we are convinced that the European pillar of social rights must be our tool to bring back body to the soul of Europe.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — Thank you Mr President, According to the NGO Oxfam (22/01/2018), 82% of the wealth generated in 2017 benefited the richest 1% of the population. This must temperate any triumphalism over the return of growth in Europe, since this widening of inequality bears the ferments of a future economic crisis. Worse, these undermined our long-term prospects by striking first and foremost young workers, whose risk of social exclusion increased between 2008 and 2016, as the International Monetary Fund pointed out on 24 January 2018. This situation, the result of an economic model advocating mobility of capital and labour which benefits only a minority, is caused by higher housing costs, whose share of household budgets increased from 20.3% to 24.4% between 2000 and 2016 (OECD), which, together with the stagnation of income from work, is not unrelated to the mass immigration suffered by Europe. The Commission's declarations of good intentions will have no effect without questioning the foundations of its economic model, the ultimate consequence of which will be the definitive disappearance of the middle classes.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. — As evidenced in the most recent data, poverty and social exclusion still affect almost a quarter of Europe's population, albeit to varying degrees in the different areas of the Member States, and lead to increasing inequalities which mainly penalise young people who come from families without advanced education and women who continue to be disadvantaged in education, employment and in entrepreneurial activities. There are many causes that lead to too many situations of socio-economic disparities between European citizens and it is therefore necessary to take appropriate measures to remove them. I am thinking, for example, of interventions aimed at improving the education system, which must be addressed to all citizens and especially children and young people who belong to families at risk of marginalization, and further to initiatives aimed at improving the training system, which must be more focused on the real needs of the labour market and aimed at the employment of different professionalism in specific production areas. At the same time, however, appropriate measures must be taken to support and encourage investment by companies, especially in the most deprived areas, also in order to limit their relocation of activities to third countries.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. — European socialists have a long and solid track record in the fight against inequalities, the most recent example is the report adopted by Parliament Europe on 'Combating inequalities to boost job creation and growth', of which Javi López was rapporteur. they are questioning in ethical or social terms, but today they also undermine our democracies and European integration itself, damaging our potential growth. We are clear that cuts in wages, pensions and public services contribute to increasing inequality and wage gap and deteriorating citizen welfare. That is why we call on the EU legislative and financial measures to ensure the quality of employment and the welfare state, and the redistribution of the benefits generated by international trade, and the coordination of fiscal policies. What made this continent unique in the last century was its social market economy, that is, reconciling progress, democracy and sustainable growth. In this regard, we are convinced that the European Pillar of Social Rights must be our tool to bring back body to the soul of Europe.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: in writing. — I don't think any of us have any doubt that the growing economic and social inequalities in the European Union should be tackled. Of course, differences in income or the level of affluence of individual social groups will always occur. This is a natural consequence of a market economy. However, there are phenomena that such a state of affairs deepens, and this process needs to be stopped. In the public debate, of course, there are differing opinions on how to fight against overstretched economical-social stratification. From my point of view, 2 phenomena are especially dangerous, and they should be given special attention. The first consequence of inequality is “the transfer of poverty and exclusion from generation to generation. There is a group of young people who don't believe in a better tomorrow for themselves and their children. A closed wheel is formed, which is difficult to interrupt. Another extremely important consequence is the increase in support for populist movements and the growing fear of “alien”. How do you fight these phenomena? Of course, a strategy based on many actions is needed. However, in my opinion, the basic answer is education. If we want to stop the adverse trend, we must ensure equal access to quality education for all EU citizens. This is the basic condition.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. - Instead of pursuing austerity and GDP based growth, it is time to take a new approach. Therefore, the latest research of the Swiss independent World Economic Forum investigated how inclusive the economic growth of a given country was, and a whole new kind of ranking was published, the Inclusive Development Index (IDI) application. This essentially shows whether the vast majority of society has been able to take a step forward, or whether only a narrow elite has benefacted from economic growth. According to this, Hungary is in second place among the emerging countries, making it the top twenty percent among 74 countries in terms of GDP per capita, labour productivity and life expectancy in health. Moreover, it is among the top five of the 74 countries in net income inequality, poverty rate, wealth inequalities and median income. And if we look at the values related to poverty, then the Hungarian GINI coefficient in 2016 was 28.2 percent. At European level, this puts Hungary among more equal societies, far from the countries of the region. We see more than 40 percent improvement in the proportion of people living in severe financial deprivation between 2012 and 2016, falling below the pre-2010 crisis. The higher minimum wage, which will take effect from 2018, can further improve this trend.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. — Social inequalities are intensifying in the Old Continent. This is due both to the very structure of the euro area and to the policy pursued, based on mercelic austerity and violent fiscal adjustment, which resulted in armies of the unemployed and millions of poor. Social inequalities in the European Union are therefore articulated both within each Member State and between the hard-core Member States and the periphery of the EU, with particular emphasis on the European South. The continuing divergence between hardcore and periphery of the EU can be seen if you look at unemployment rates, especially youth unemployment rates. Greece, Spain and Italy are champions in youth unemployment, while the corresponding figures are particularly low in Germany, Austria, Luxembourg, etc. That is why the structure of the euro area must be radically changed, the policy of austerity should be abandoned and a Europe with a triple social A. In this context, measures must be taken to establish - at the first stage - a European minimum social income, a European minimum wage and a European unemployment allowance.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: in writing. - Social inequality has risen dramatically in the Member States of the European Union in recent decades. Today, almost 120 million people in Europe, including millions of children, live in poverty, at risk of poverty. The number of working poor people, that is, the number of citizens who work but cannot make a living from their earnings, is growing. However, social inequality, poverty, is not simply a material issue, but it is synonymous with freedom, lack of opportunities, exclusion, loss of human dignity, fear of the future. It is synonymous with the extreme and fatal splitting of society. We also know that inequalities in today's world cannot simply be remedied by wage increases or social benefits. The main cause of inequality is access to knowledge and the difference in the possibilities of acquiring knowledge. Those who cannot acquire the competences and skills required by today's knowledge-based society, the changed world of work, will necessarily be on the periphery of society. And if social inequalities are growing more and more, it is also a serious threat to democracy. It is for this reason that one cannot continue to think in the usual categories. Above all, we need an inclusive economy and society, digital education, a strong and effective social network. It is not only necessary to distribute social aid, but also to build paths that will create opportunities for people living in poverty to erupt.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – The consequences of socio-economic inequalities for European citizens are serious as they are diverse. They generate significant economic and social costs in terms of low demand, which in turn diminish growth, but they also stoke the fire of populist discourse. Figures show that almost one person in four experiences poverty or social exclusion, with an even more worrying percentage for young people, and inequalities are only getting bigger, even if we have theoretically put the economic crisis behind us. This situation is unacceptable for the 21st century Europe and requires immediate action, reasons for which I welcome the debate initiated by the S&D Group. We need a new approach for equitable and sustainable well-being - in all Member States - and the European Pillar for Social Rights or the Youth Guarantee are great examples of how we can bring real change. My view is that we need to put extra effort into helping young generations, particularly as regard training and acquiring skills. As lack of education is responsible for the passing of poverty between generations, I support creating more programmes focused on education and professional qualifications, including for the tourism sector, one of the engines of EU economic growth.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the S&D Group we have a long and solid track record in the fight against inequalities, the most recent example is the report adopted by the European Parliament on 'Combating inequalities to boost job creation and growth', rapporteur Javi López was rapporteur. Not only do inequalities question us in ethical or social terms, but today they also undermine our democracies and European integration itself, damaging our potential growth. We are clear that cuts in wages, pensions and public services contribute to increasing inequality and the wage gap and the deterioration of citizen welfare. That is why we call on the EU legislative and financial measures to ensure the quality of employment and the welfare state, and the redistribution of the benefits generated by international trade, and the coordination of fiscal policies. What made this continent unique in the last century was its social market economy, that is, reconciling progress, democracy and sustainable growth. In this regard, we are convinced that the European pillar of social rights must be our tool to bring back body to the soul of Europe.

name: Gabriela Zoană (S&D)
text: in writing. — We live in a European Union where socio-economic inequalities between citizens are easily observed. You do not have to be an expert in economics, culture or politics to perceive the welfare of a country's citizens. We know that Danish citizens are the happiest or that in Finland we will find the best education system. The degree of happiness, education, culture and economic well-being of the citizens of a country are benchmarks by which we can always guide ourselves to identify the socio-economic conditions that a country offers to its inhabitants. We live in a European Union and we should have a common goal: to all be equally happy, to have access to high performance education systems and to all know the standard of living enjoyed by the citizens of the most developed European countries. When we talk about the consequences of socio-economic inequality between European citizens, we are not just talking about the existence in the EU of distinct categories, unemployment, massive labour migration, we are not just talking about depopulation or ageing of the population of certain areas and the crowding of others, but also the lack of access to a high-performance education system and the uncertainty of tomorrow for many European citizens.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the item with a request for an oral reply to the Council on the reform of the European Union electoral law by Danuta Maria Hübner, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (O-000099/2017 - B8-0002/2018) (2017/3019 (RSP)).

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: author. – Madam President, since this morning, a lot has been said in this House on elections as the main instrument of democratic participation. Democratic participation is the raison d’être for any parliament. This European Parliament was for the first time elected based on direct universal suffrage in 1979. The legal basis was provided by the Electoral Act of 1976. It was a European Parliament of 410 directly-elected representatives. It was a European Parliament for a European Union of 9 Member States. Today we live in a completely different world. The European Union comprises 28 Member States. The Parliament is composed of 751 Members, its role as co-legislator has skyrocketed, and still the rules governing the conduct of European elections are those established 42 years ago. It is our fundamental duty as the European Parliament to enable participatory democracy to facilitate the building of a bottom-up Europe and connect citizens with Europe. Connecting Europe with citizens starts with the European elections, and we need to update the Electoral Act of 1976. This is what we did in November 2015, by adopting and transmitting to the Council a proposal for amendment of the ʼ76 Electoral Act. According to the Treaty – Article 223 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union – it is not only the duty but also the right of the European Parliament to draw up a proposal to lay down the provisions on its electoral law. Our utmost goal is to enhance the democratic dimension of the European elections, to reinforce Union citizenship, to improve the functioning of the Parliament and the governance of the European Union, to make the work of the Parliament more legitimate and efficient, to enhance effectiveness of the election’s conduct, and to provide for more electoral equality of Union citizens. More than two years have passed, six Council Presidencies have worked, the next European elections of 2019 are around the corner. So here is our question: Dear Council, dear Commission, we would like to know what is the intention of the two other institutions, especially of the Council, regarding the reform of the EU electoral law?

name: Jo Leinen
text: author. — Mr President. The Bulgarian Presidency is now the sixth Presidency to deal with the European Parliament's request of November 2015 — six unsuccessful presidencies. We have had informal contacts, but there is no official position of the Council, and we are approacing huge strides towards the next European elections in May 2019. So, if you can't make it in the Bulgarian Presidency, then this is a lost dossier. As Mrs Hübner has already said, the European elections need improvements. They are firmly in the electoral act of 1976, with some renewals in 2002, but they no longer correspond to the importance of these elections in the EU today. We have made 16 proposals, and I have the impression that every single proposal in the Council is being petty and pushed aside with any arguments. For example, we have proposed that we prepare the European elections more seriously — more democratic and transparent. It cannot be that in some countries candidates only know that they are candidates two weeks before the election. It really takes more time to campaign. We have also proposed that citizens identify which of their national parties belong to European parties in order to have a clearer view of what they are choosing and in which direction Europe is moving. We wanted gender equality on the electoral lists. We have put forward bold proposals to reduce the voting age to 16 years and to examine whether it is also possible to vote electronically in the European elections, whether the millions of citizens who do not live in their country also have the right to vote in the European elections, which is currently ruled out in many Member States; on the other hand, that Citizens do not choose twice. So, a lot of innovations and improvements, and that Dossier is just stuck in the Council. I have the impression that the Council is violating its duty to provide this directly elected Chamber of Citizens with appropriate information and thus to promote an important dossier. We ask you: Where is it, and when can we expect an answer?

name: Monika Panayotova
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, Ms Hübner, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Hübner, for her oral question. I welcome this opportunity to update Parliament on the state of play on this important issue.  Let me recall that on 19 November 2015, the two rapporteurs, Ms Hübner and Mr Leinen, presented Parliament’s proposal to the Council at an informal Committee of Permanent Representatives (Coreper) meeting. Since then, discussions took place in the relevant working party and five successive Presidencies conducted intensive technical work on this file.  In November 2016 and December 2017, Coreper was involved and held an in—depth discussion on these very sensitive issues. After these two meetings the Presidencies met with the two co—rapporteurs in order to give them a comprehensive overview and a clear state of play of the discussions. The first meeting took place in January 2017 and the last one in December 2017.  Minister Maasikas for the Estonian Presidency came before the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) where he presented orally to the rapporteurs the general state of play on the discussions, as of November 2017, after a detailed mapping exercise. So contacts have been ongoing. Today I am really happy to have the opportunity to give you some feedback.  Let me first stress that the Member States are very much supportive of the general aim of the proposal to enhance public interest and voter turnout in the European Parliament elections. They also share the view that there is a need for increased transparency and awareness—raising regarding the European character of the European Parliament elections.  But the Member States also stressed the importance of respecting their constitutional and electoral traditions, as well as the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. The proposal has indeed raised some concerns in this regard. Member States have also been pointing to the autonomy of the political parties and the divergences in national systems in this respect. In their view, harmonisation should only be pursued in case of strict necessity and after a rigorous examination of the added value it will bring.  On a more positive note, let me underline that after several months of discussions in the Working Party we were able to identify, in a preliminary way, a package of provisions on which an agreement in the Council would seem currently the most likely. We need to pursue our work on this to explore the possibility of a compromise that might be acceptable for all. I can assure you that our Presidency has put this file high on the agenda. Let me also recall that this file will require unanimity in the Council.  Finally, you should also know that we share the concerns about the deadlines for the approval of the amendments to the electoral law, in accordance with the Member States’ constitutional requirements, and about adopting the necessary domestic measures in time for the 2019 elections.  To sum up: despite these difficulties, we are determined to continue the hard work on this important file in the Council. We are also happy to continue working closely with the European Parliament in a very constructive spirit to try to overcome the difficulties and seek solutions that are acceptable to all.

name: Paulo Rangel
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, first I’d like to acknowledge and to underline that both Danuta Hübner and Jo Leinen have really been fighters for the improvement of the electoral law of the European Union and the European elections, and so we follow this effort and this clear aim. I understand that our concern is that we have to modernise electoral law, we have to carry out a lot of improvements. Today we have taken a major step by giving electoral law the final kick-off for its reform, because the issue of those national lists was very divisive, and a lot of states had them as a red line. With the vote here, that was quite clear. Now I think that we have a way forward for carrying out other reforms because, in one way, we were captured and imprisoned by the issue of transnational lists. I’m not here pleading against or in favour: I’m saying that it was an obstacle to changing other electoral-law issues. Now we are in a position to carry out the improvements that we really need, and so the Council will probably be in a better position to consider the different proposals and to see if they can reach a consensus on improving our electoral rules.

name: Mercedes Bresso
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, I believe that it is right to recall the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity, but here we talk about European electoral law. It must be sufficiently homogeneous to make it clear to citizens of all European countries voting for a single Parliament and not national elections. So I believe that in particular some of the rules we are calling for are updated, a set of clarification simplification rules, but also those relating to the membership of political families Europeans, are indispensable because this makes clear the political battle that must be done at European level, otherwise no one knows what we are talking about. I don't agree with my colleague Rangel. Unfortunately, today's vote has still increased divisions and will also increase them within the Council, because we know that there are many countries that on transnational lists make an important point of their political action. So I also ask you to take account of the fact that not only did this Parliament split more or less in half — given that those who leave in fact had no title to speak — and just as will happen in the Council. A reasonable composition must therefore be found.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Radicalism is the enemy of good. I, like Mr Rangel, am pleased that we have avoided radicalism and the adoption of a transnational constituency — because, from the point of view of the legitimacy of the European Parliament, it is much better to elect Members in the Member States — and this should be avoided in the course of the work on electoral law. There are quite a few good proposals in the recommendations of Mrs Hübner and Mr Leinen, among others, those that address the transparency of the electoral process, timing. But there are and proposals that the ECR group cannot agree with. This is primarily about the centralisation of elections, the obligation to place the logo of affiliation at European level in elections for the European Parliament. This stifles new policy initiatives. In our view, it should be a right, not an obligation. I'm happy with the Minister's speech, because it allows you to set out a possible field of arrangements. Yes, there is a chance to pass a new law, but one that will follow the constitutional traditions of member states and ensure political freedom.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (PT) Mr President, Minister, there is an urgent need for an electoral reform in the European Union to bring elected Members closer to the electoral citizens, which reverses the growing sense of electoral abstention, which, in short, makes this parliamentary institution credited to those who we represent. The European Union has begun to build itself on the smoking debris of the Second World War, and since then this construction has been taking place step by step, sometimes faster, sometimes slower. Unfortunately, this Parliament has today missed a rare opportunity to take a decisive step towards greater European integration. By refusing the possibility of a European constituency, this Parliament has postponed, for who knows how long, a reform that would bring new blood to this parliamentary institution and give it enhanced legitimacy. The construction of Europe will therefore continue to take place at the pace of possible compromises between the selfish interests of the various Member States, rather than opening up to the political commitments made directly to European citizens. Unfortunately, we will continue to have elections to this Parliament whose election campaigns will be around the internal issues of the Member States and not the real problems of Europe. Today, Europe has lagging behind in its historic process. For a moment, it seems that the Euro-ectics who have been hiding behind a speech, a Europeanist rhetoric, have allied themselves with the most radically anti-European sectors of this Parliament.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. I thank the Council for attempting to make a political statement on the matter. However, let me make a preliminary comment: from the point of view of the democratic constitution of the European Union, it is almost a gloomy sign that between the six-monthly statements of the Council — forthcoming and going presidencies — the Council must be explicitly quoted here to this House in order to understand what it is in this House. of the matter just somewhere behind closed doors. This is not simply about information, but about the institutional cooperation of the European Parliament and the Council, to which, according to Article 13 of the Treaty, the Council is also obliged to do so in the electoral reform, which has been burning there for two years, as well as our right of inquiry. Politically, I can understand that there are many contradictions there, national views that if one wants to go one way, the other in the other direction, you have to somehow find a compromise. But probably tired of the attempt and the search for compensation, you change the rules of the game internally, which makes the centrifuge jump on and no longer only provokes contradiction, but also organizes the resistance. Even today in the house we heard about it. Obviously, the Council is no longer being tied up on this knot, and it has become too tangled in a wide variety of political interests. That is why the question arises for me today — and I quote from my speech on 27 October 2015 on the right to vote: does it help to strengthen Europe's public space to overcome the long-standing speechlessness between citizens and politics in Europe? And does it provide more active and passive political participation to this day for excluded and also to gender parity? To do this, the Council must deliver and finally Give information on where the electoral reform stands.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, time goes by and we have not had any news from the Council on the reform of the European electoral law. If nothing happens in the next 15 months, the European elections will have to take place under the rules of 1976. Europe has changed a lot during the past 42 years. Minister, the members of the Council should not appeal to the principle of subsidiarity, since we are dealing with European elections, not with local, regional or national elections. We, the Greens/EFA, consider that the Parliament’s electoral law resolution has been very shy, without showing a true ambition to update the electoral system according to the new social and political demands for greater participation, accountability and equality. It has been a disappointing text: indeed, not the new electoral law our group desired and expected. We understand the urgency of producing a new law on the important subject of the European elections. However, it is not enough to produce a text. It is essential to produce the best possible text: one that is in line with the needs of the time and brings institutions a bit closer to citizens, to restore confidence and to reinforce the European project. In any case, what is now important is that Parliament be kept informed about the debate in the Council on this very important issue.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it was 11 November 2015 when we voted as the European Parliament on a proposal to amend the European Electoral Law, exercising that power of An initiative that the Treaty allocates to us exceptionally. Since then we have been waiting for the Council's decision at the helm of which five different Presidencies have been succeeded. It seems, in short, that the Council has forgotten the second paragraph of Article 13 TEU and we would therefore like to remind its members that it establishes the duty of fair cooperation between the institutions , a duty also reaffirmed by the Interinstitutional Agreement of April 2016. So we ask ourselves what major impediments are blocking the co-legislator and when we can finally move forward on the dossier. In fact, I remember that, in order for it to be applied in the 2019 elections, reform should be finalised very quickly. In some Member States, amendments to the electoral law must come into force 12 months before the election itself. We have proposed concrete improvements and absolute common sense. How much will we have to and will still have to wait for citizens to see them finally become a reality?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: — Mr President, the attempt being made to replace the current electoral law on the election of Members of the European Parliament with another, which will provide for the integration of national parties into European parties, is another attempt to remove important powers from the States, to marginalize the nation states and, in the end, to end up a confederation of the European Union. At the same time, the will of voters who will no longer have the right to elect MEPs of their choice but those imposed by a small leading group of the European Union is being violated. In the new way, the rights of small countries in favour of large and small parties in favour of large parties are being violated, because both countries and parties will lose seats given to the large countries. This will alienate the voter from the MEP's representative, will not be able to influence the situation, and this will lead him to indifference to European issues and will make him not participate in European elections and, at the last stage, ask his country to leave the European Union. In order to avoid all this, the proposal to change the current electoral law of the European Union must be voted against. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question pursuant to Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: — Question about the 'blue card' procedure. — ('My colleague, do you allow a request? I am listening to you, but I do not know what you are trying to tell us, because what you are saying has absolutely nothing to do with Parliament's proposal to reform the European elections. We are not talking about small countries, large countries at all; we are talking about more transparency and more democracy and equality. That's the topic! What you're talking about has nothing to do with the item. I don't know what you say about this.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: 'Blue card'. — (EL) Mr President, transparency is something everyone wants, but what lies behind what we call transparency is an attempt to take over and influence the decision of the voters. The voter will not have the right to choose who will represent him because he will, in fact, be determined by the major European parties.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the Minister, representing the Council and other colleagues. I personally believe that a change in suffrage is certainly necessary, but we should say the main philosophy of the need for that change. If I look at how elections to the European Parliament are going, for example, in the Czech Republic or other Visegrad states, then the main problem is very low turnout. It reached 18% in the Czech Republic, and so if we make any changes, we should try to increase the interest of citizens in European elections, increase the legitimacy of elections in the eyes of individual citizens of these states. And that is why I am personally pleased that today, for example, Parliament has made clear that we are not going to enforce multinational constituencies at this time. That idea of multinational circuits going forward, many years from now may be good. But when, in short, the European Union is 28 states, citizens want to be able to identify with their particular politician, a particular MEP who represents and represents them their interests on the floor of the European Parliament. And that's why it's a good thing that we don't address such idea concepts at the moment. Fifty years from now maybe, but certainly not at the moment. I believe that at this time, and given the proximity of the elections, some positive points from the material processed by the European Parliament can still be pushed through, removing some technical Problems like the fact that some citizens of the European Union who hold dual citizenship might vote twice. These are certainly concrete things that we could still work out. But probably a major change in suffrage, fundamental electoral reform is not going to pass at the moment. So please see in the debates in the Council that we should increase the interest of citizens in the European Parliament, the European elections, and not by some utopian considerations to give it away to the people.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Mr President! Madam Minister! We have listened here to the intervention of Mrs Hübner and Mr Jo Leinen, which is basically a request: listen, more than two years ago you got our proposal, a position as Council. And what have we heard from the Minister? That the Council depends on citizens taking an interest in elections, so that elections are transparent, so that as many people go to elections as possible. But tell me what method it is. The fifth presidency — or perhaps the sixth even — from states different, new, less new, and there is always the same answer. Work is underway. Technical factors. We want to keep in touch. We'll be in touch. We will inform. And what next? And nothing. At this point, even I would not want any individual aspects to contribute, I would just like to say this: the Council is not interested, regardless of the Presidency, so that in the electoral act, the most important, people know who they choose, why, what is he to do here . The council just doesn't care about it. And I will confess sincerely, Mrs. Panayotova. I don't believe anything will change.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Exactly 100 years ago, the Prussian three-class electoral law came to an end in Germany: it was abolished. The Prussian three-class electoral law was a relic from a pre-democratic era, a right to vote where citizens did not have the same right to vote where they could not vote in the same election. Today, 100 years later, we are in this Parliament discussing electoral law reform without addressing the problem that we still have the same unequal right to vote in Europe. There are six Members from Malta in this Parliament. If we had the same right to vote, then 1 000 Members from Germany would have to sit in this Parliament. There are only 96 members from Germany sitting here. There are 900 German MEPs missing. Hundreds of French MEPs are missing, hundreds of British MEPs are missing, hundreds of MEPs are missing from Spain, Poland, Hungary and virtually all the major EU Member States. That is why, Mr Leinen, it is certainly a question of small states and large states that we need to discuss here. This Parliament will not have more democratic legitimacy unless we change the right to vote here than any other Parliament elected more than 100 years ago under the Prussian three-class electoral law. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Elmar Brok (PPE)
text: Ask about the procedure of the “blue card”. — Professor Lucke! You should look at the history of federal two-chamber systems. This is always a mixture between the rights of the small and the large. In the European Union, the large countries have much more power in the Council than the federal states in Germany have in the Bundesrat. That is why the balance has been restored through the European Parliament. In the US Senate, each state, no matter how tall, has only two senators. Please be knowledgeable about federal systems and do not clutter in Prussian suffrage — probably because you are better fit there.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — Mr Brok, I certainly missed your question. But if I may point out to you, in a two-chamber system, there is always a chamber that represents the government or something similar in a state, and then there is a Parliament. And in any modern society, this Parliament is elected as the representative of citizens at the same choice. Only in Europe is this not the case, and you would have to explain to me why this is not the case.

name: Presidente. –
text: I remember that “blue cards” can be used an ad speaker, no more naturally.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. It is really time for us to get an answer from the Council, and I have to say that I have not become quite clever from your speech, because, unfortunately, you have not told us at what points you are now specifically hoping that we will actually get changes. Could you please tell us exactly what points you are hoping to reach a consensus now? I just want to say one more thing: what we as Greens clearly do not share is that the attempt to gain more democracy and transparency in the European elections has been linked by the majority groups here in Parliament to curtail the rights of small parties in the corresponding elections in Spain and Germany. Success to compete here. Given the many smaller parties in this house, this is not legitimate circumcision. And just now, Mr Leinen, actually from the tradition of Social Democracy, did not find this the greatest degree of fairness that was trying to reintroduce the failed five-percent hurdle in the European elections here over this legal act. This was not a fair move vis-à-vis the smaller parties in Spain and Germany. We wouldn't have needed that here. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure. — Dear colleague, did I not understand from your intervention whether you agree to transnational lists or not? If it is feasible for the 2019 elections to switch to this electoral system, if the citizens are ready and if you think it is good for us to have two floors in Parliament? That is, a floor of transnationally elected MEPs and others elected at national level: how will this work?

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question. Actually I didn’t say anything about this, because this was not the core of our proposal. We lost, unfortunately, an important vote. I am still quite sad at the negative outcome of the former vote which we lost, and it will mean for 20 years no transnational list, no big move forward for transnational democracy in Europe with elections. But here we have a lot of practical proposals on how to improve transparency and democracy, and for this we still deserve a proper and constructive answer from the Council.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: — Mr President, dear colleagues and honourable members of the Council, the 2019 European elections are coming fast. Meanwhile, it has been two years since the European Parliament referred the Council to the need to amend the electoral law. Today, we raise this question again, because Parliament is genuinely concerned about the way the European elections take place, which is the most important expression of democracy. The current legislative framework needs modernisation and improvement in line with the existing realities at European level. We want to introduce the possibility of electronic and mail voting in all Member States. Another example would be the drawing up of electoral lists taking into account the principles of gender equality, which would ensure a better representation of the female electorate. We want to come up with proposals for an inclusive and progressive electoral system, allowing all European citizens to participate in the vote. With regard to transnational lists I have a reserved position. The question is: how do we guarantee that the introduction of such an instrument will not reduce the correct representation of all citizens, regardless of nationality, and smaller states do not remain underrepresented? In conclusion, our priority at the moment is to assure citizens that we prepare responsibly for the next vote and do not launch fireworks guaranteeing someone's place on the lists.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: — Mr. President, discussions on how to make the Union more democratic and closer to citizens are needed and that is why I am pleased to discuss the reform of electoral law. But one thing at first we must recognise, whatever formula you apply, it is impossible to achieve within the given framework that the European Parliament becomes, in the full sense of the word, the legislative body of the Union. One of the reasons is that every vote in European elections is not worth equal. Otherwise, Germany would give almost two hundred times as many MEPs than Malta. That is why this body cannot draw its democratic legitimacy only from immediate elections but also from direct cooperation with the Council. Personally, I would also like better cooperation with national parliaments through which the legitimacy of the European Parliament could also be strengthened. Transnational lists, which have been frequently mentioned lately, would only move the Union away from citizens because turnout in those elections, due to the large number of citizens unknown candidates, would be lower than ever before.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to express the meaning of this procedure, Madam Minister, to remind you that what we are talking about is a dialogue which Parliament has been asking the Council for three years now. We just want to dialogue so that we can negotiate the European electoral law. The argument you put forward is true. There are national realities, there are political peculiarities that we have to respect. I share it. It is very difficult to harmonize the same electoral system for the whole European Union. But I would remind you, Your Honor, that the law adopted by the European Parliament is very modest. It only aims to unify minimum elements: election day, date, common age, ballot, logo, thresholds. Because we want the law of forty years ago to be updated. We just want that. With this procedure, ladies and gentlemen, what the Council is asked is a response in order to discuss a necessary negotiation for a necessary European law.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President! As an electoral law geek, I am not very impressed by Parliament's proposals. I understand that the council has had a problem dealing with it. It centralizes a little too much as if centralization was itself an eigenvalue. I hope that the Council will reject the things that should be rejected, and remember that the Council will actually have to take decisions unanimously. One of the things that needs to be rejected is the proposal to impose thresholds that would shut out parties that have the votes of millions of citizens. We're not going to put up artificial thresholds to keep parties out. People even vote for small parties. Small parties are helping to make the European Parliament better — do not approve of such stupidity.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: — Mr President, we are discussing what the Council has not done but we should look at the proposal formulated by the European Parliament, a proposal that supposedly ensures greater equality for the citizens of the Union; but at the same time this proposal establishes entry limits, which means that a party in Greece, for example, in order to be elected to the European Parliament must have 3%, in another country 5%. That means undemocratic perception. That means stealing votes. This basically means that there will be a large number of European citizens who may vote for these small parties but in practice will not be represented. It's gonna be a kindergarding law. That is the point we need to discuss, because this excludes certain political forces. There is no possibility of pluralism. I think that this is where we need to stand and that the electoral limits of 3% or 5% must be reverted. This is what is in the national parliaments for governability, so that a stable government can be elected. Here we do not express or elect a government, so we do not need these limits.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, first I would like to underline my consent on the urgency given to the electoral law reform in order to make the future 2019 elections more transparent, democratic and truly European, especially considering that in some Member States, modifications to electoral law have to enter into force 12 months before the elections. I recognise that there are some shortcomings of the Electoral Act of 1976, and therefore I support the measures proposed in the reform, which are meant to strengthen the European dimension of the elections, providing also better electoral equality for our citizens and improve their voting turnout. I would like to draw your attention to one aspect, which is very important in my opinion: that the measures refer also to EU legitimacy and democratic quality and they come ahead of an increasing demand from our citizens for an adequate post-Brexit political, democratic representation.

name: Monika Panayotova
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, please let me respond to the remarks made by the honourable Members of the European Parliament. I would like to elaborate on several important topics and points. First of all, let me assure you that we all share the sense of urgency in view of the forthcoming EP elections in 2019. Any changes to the electoral law would need to be ratified by the national parliaments. The Presidency has consulted with Member States regarding the deadlines for having the changes approved in accordance with their constitutional requirements and for adopting the necessary domestic measures in time for the 2019 European Parliament elections. Secondly, at the same time we need to be aware that the issue at hand goes to the heart of the constitutional electoral traditions and the organisation of the political life in Member States, including the respective electoral laws and freedom of association. Thirdly, as foreseen in the Leaders Agenda, the European Council will have an informal meeting on institutional issues on 23 February. The agenda foresees the EP composition, transnational lists and appointments, including Spitzenkandidaten. This is part of the new method proposed by President Tusk in October 2017, allowing a frank, open and constructive discussion. For this reason, it is very important not to prejudge the forthcoming Leaders discussions. Fourthly, as regards our concrete steps and timetable, the Presidency has considered all available options. The Council has dedicated in-depth attention to the Parliament’s proposal and several successive Presidencies have been engaged, as you have already mentioned. These are not issues on which it is easy to find a compromise, and I recall that the Treaty requires unanimity. While Member States share the objective of increasing the interest of the voters and the European character of the elections, these realities also need to be taken into account. Therefore, we need to consider that we have two options: either focus our efforts on the topic with respect to which agreement seems most likely, or face the risk of not having any result for the forthcoming EP elections. Taking into consideration the willingness to achieve progress, the Presidency intends to continue with discussions focusing on the least controversial provisions. We will reflect on any further next steps as soon as we have a full view of the situation. The Presidency will continue to seek consensus wherever possible. To conclude, let me reaffirm the Council’s commitment to engage with the European Parliament. I totally agree that this is a question of cooperation. We remain available to exchange on our respective positions and to look for common solutions.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. — On 11 November 2015, the European Parliament (EP) adopted its proposal to amend the 1976 Act on the election of MEPs by direct universal suffrage, introducing a series of measures aimed at strengthening the European dimension of elections and ensuring greater electoral equality for the elections citizens of the Union. Unfortunately, since then five Council Presidencies (Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Malta and now Estonia) have worked on Parliament's proposal (exercised in accordance with Article 223 (1) TFEU), but none have forwarded to the EP any formal or informal results of the Council's deliberations. highlighting the unwillingness of Member States to harmonize the current rule dating back to 1976. That is why we once again call on the Council not to continue to block the improvement of the rules on the election of MEPs and, bearing in mind that the dossier must be completed by next spring at the latest, to submit a decision to the EP as soon as possible.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. — On 11 November 2015, the European Parliament (EP) adopted its proposal to amend the 1976 Act on the election of MEPs by direct universal suffrage, introducing a series of measures aimed at strengthening the European dimension of elections and ensuring greater electoral equality for the elections citizens of the Union. Unfortunately, since then five Council Presidencies (Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Malta and now Estonia) have worked on Parliament's proposal (exercised in accordance with Article 223 (1) TFEU), but none have forwarded to the EP any formal or informal results of the Council's deliberations. highlighting the unwillingness of Member States to harmonize the current rule dating back to 1976. That is why we once again call on the Council not to continue to block the improvement of the rules on the election of MEPs and, bearing in mind that the dossier must be completed by next spring at the latest, to submit a decision to the EP as soon as possible.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — The eurozone crisis, Brexit, the refugee crisis and other crises of recent years have highlighted the weaknesses of the EU and reduced the confidence of our citizens in the EU. This trust needs to be restored in a timely manner before serious irreversible damage is done. I believe that reform of electoral legislation should contribute to greater interest in choice, to greater participation. The proposed changes are aimed at greater transparency, at the possibility of greater identification with European electoral parties and its candidates. If we want to reduce the democratic deficit, then we need to strive for greater turnout and voter understanding for European elections. In the Czech Republic, for example, in the European Parliament elections in 2014, a turnout of just 19.5% of voters, which is more than two-thirds less than in the last elections for the Czech Parliamentarian of the House (60.84%). I'm sure other states are seeing a similar problem. I agree with the proposals for the visibility of the European parties, e.g. the proposal that the logos of the European parties should also be listed on the ballot papers. Awareness of European parties is very limited in the Member States and there is therefore a need for European parties to be seen more and penetrate the awareness of voters.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on statements by the Council and the Commission on the threats to the rule of law posed by the reform of the judicial system of Romania (2018/2512 (RSP)).

name: Dan Nica (S&D).
text: — I have a procedural problem that I want to bring to your attention. Today's debate takes place in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. Under this regulation, it is made very clear that, in the work of the debate we are having today, those who are members of the Council may participate. A decision was made that seemed strange. President Tajani was misled because the Romanian law was not brought to his attention. According to the Romanian law and the Constitution of Romania, the one present at the Council is the President of Romania, who, of course, could not be here today, and, in his absence, the Council participates, as is the case of the matter on justice, the Minister of Justice. The Minister of Justice of Romania is in the Chamber today and I think that, for a debate in which the necessary arguments can be brought, the opportunity should be given to the Minister of Justice, Tudorel Toader, member of the Venice Commission, to be able to give at least answers to questions. This would also give a note, which we all want, of seriousness, of discussing arguments that shed light on all the issues that will be clarified today in plenary and, at the same time, the temple of democracy for all Romanians would show that it is the European Parliament and that the presence of the Minister of Justice, who can give the necessary explanations, is something that we all respect and that all Romanians, I guarantee, will appreciate as such. So, I ask you, Mr President, to look at Article 123 (2) and I respectfully ask you to try to enable the Romanian Minister of Justice to at least answer the questions that are being asked or to bring the necessary clarifications.

name: Sophia in ’t Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, having listened to the proposal, I am of course very grateful that the Minister for Justice is here, and we are also very much looking forward to an exchange of views with the Minister for Justice in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, but so far we have a procedure in this plenary that for this kind of debate we invite the Prime Minister. An invitation was sent to the Prime Minister; the Prime Minister, for reasons of her own, could not be here today; but I don’t think that we should change the rules, or indeed the traditions, on the spot. There will be a debate in the Committee on Civil Liberties as well. It was agreed in the Conference of Presidents to invite the Prime Minister for today’s debate and to have the exchange of views with the Minister for Justice in the committee, and I suggest that we go ahead as was agreed in the Conference of Presidents.

name: Presidente. –
text: We have asked for the Council to be present in the House and the Council has sent its representative, and this is enough for us to be able to have the debate.

name: Monika Panayotova
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, Madam Commissioner, you have invited the Presidency to intervene in this debate. First, let me say that common values such as democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights are the cornerstone of the European Union. Each Member State must therefore respect, protect and promote them. Let me assure you that the rule of law and the separation of powers have always been at the heart of the Council’s attention. We believe that dialogue and cooperation are necessary to ensure the best standards and conditions for our citizens in all our Member States. The Council addressed the situation in Romania in its conclusions on the cooperation and verification mechanism adopted on 12 December 2017. The Council welcomed the fact that Romania has taken a number of positive steps and encouraged the country to renew momentum on the reforms, in particular those related to the independence of the judiciary and to the fight against corruption at all levels. The Council reiterated the importance for Romania to focus on further consolidating progress and to fully address the concerns and all the recommendations set out by the Commission in its report on progress achieved under the cooperation and verification mechanism. We hope that the ongoing communication between the Romanian authorities and the Commission will continue to prove efficient in assisting Romania to remedy some shortcomings.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the discussion in Romania over the last year about its justice laws has led to concerns being expressed by a wide range of stakeholders, both inside and outside the country, across the EU and beyond. Romanian citizens have taken to the streets to state their opposition to the proposed changes to Romanian law. They are concerned that this may undermine the long—standing efforts in the fight against corruption and the independence of the judiciary. The Commission has made no secret of the fact that it shares these concerns. So too does the Council of Europe’s anti—corruption watchdog, the Group of States against Corruption, which for the first time has decided to launch its own inquiry – with a report due in March.  The independence of the Romanian judiciary and its capacity to fight corruption are directly relevant to the progress made under the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism, which, as you know, was set up in 2007 to assist Romania and Bulgaria in the fields of judicial reform and corruption and (for Bulgaria) the fight against organised crime. After ten years of continued efforts, Romania has one of the best judiciaries in the region.  Back in January 2017, the Commission proposed a limited set of remaining recommendations which, if implemented fully and provided that there is no backtracking, would bring Romania out of the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism. One of the recommendations called on the Romanian leadership to ensure a consensual legislative process, to finalise reforms of the justice laws and the criminal codes, and also to respect judicial independence and court decisions.  On 15 November 2017, in our latest Cooperation and Verification Mechanism report, the Commission voiced concerns on the process and the content of the draft justice laws. As the debate on justice laws was evolving in the course of 2017, the Superior Council of the Magistracy – the constitutional guarantor of the independence of the judiciary – continued to voice concerns and issued a negative opinion citing detrimental impacts on judicial independence and on the effective functioning of the judicial system. These concerns need to be taken seriously in the legislative process. Therefore the question we put to the Romanian authorities in the November report remains valid, namely whether the process would take into account the legitimate interests of the judiciary and respect judicial independence. Unfortunately, we have continued to see open criticism of the judiciary and defiance of judicial decisions or integrity rules, which do not inspire a feeling of confidence in the process. Events since have done nothing to address these concerns.  On 21 December 2017, the parliament adopted amendments to the justice laws in a fast—track procedure and the laws were immediately challenged in the Constitutional Court through three referrals. The Constitutional Court proceedings are ongoing but, in its first hearings, it declared the unconstitutionality of some of the provisions. These are issues to be looked at carefully in relation to judicial independence and on which there are European standards.  The Council of Europe’s principle is that you cannot reform the judicial system against the judiciary. This common sense advice underpins the Commission’s recommendation to the Romanian authorities that they consult the Venice Commission before the justice laws are promulgated. The Commission considers that it is still possible for the justice laws to be improved and become good laws which will strengthen the independence and professionalisation of the Romanian judicial system to serve all Romanian citizens. This is a crucial moment, given that the first two draft laws are back in the Romanian Parliament following the rulings of the Constitutional Court. The debate on how to address the concerns expressed by the Constitutional Court should be used as an opportunity to have a good, frank dialogue and build a better shared understanding and trust among all parties concerned.  Therefore, I reiterate the call made by President Juncker and First Vice—President Timmermans to the Romanian Parliament to rethink the course of actions proposed, to open up debate in line with the Commission’s recommendations, to build consensus on the way forward, to safeguard the independence of the judicial system and further step up the fight against corruption. The President of Romania also has a key role in the process and, from his meeting with the College last week, I know he takes that very seriously. The Commission stands ready to continue its ongoing dialogue with the Romanian authorities and will contribute as best it can to help ensure that this process is taken forward constructively and in a way that builds trust.  We will look thoroughly at the final amendments to the justice law, the criminal codes and laws on conflicts of interest and corruption. As always, when dealing with these and similar matters, the Commission will remain objective, facts—based and law—based, politically colour—blind and clinical in our approach. Romania and Romanians have been running a marathon. The finish line is in sight. To step backwards now would be a major disappointment to Romania’s many friends, but most of all to Romanian citizens. The speed with which Romania will reach the finish line is up to Romania, but the Commission stands by to help Romania get there.

name: Presidente. –
text: We now open the debate by first of all listening to the views of the different political groups. I warn that at this stage of the statements of political groups we will not accept “blue cards.”

name: Roberta Metsola
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the situation in Romania remains of concern. We have seen attempts by the Government there to suppress the judiciary, to water down anticorruption legislation and to use its electoral majority as an excuse to do as it pleases. I know some people claim and will claim that the European Parliament and the Commission should not get involved, or try to spin the idea that this is somehow politically motivated. It is a justification that we are seeing used by unscrupulous politicians across the European Union who try to excuse the inexcusable. But they are wrong. The EU cannot look away and, for sure, the European People’s Party will not do so, because Romanians are not any less European than the rest of us. They deserve – as we all do – a country where the rule of law is respected, where corruption is fought, where the courts are protected and where laws are not changed on a whim to suit only those in power. Romanians have been on the street for more than a year: as temperatures plummeted and the snow fell, they stood up. They flew European Union flags because they believed in Europe – a Europe that is not only an economic bloc but also a guarantee of common values and shared promises. They believe still. This is not only about Romania. This is about all of us. Every Member State must understand that what happens in Bucharest affects people in Paris, just as what happens in Valetta affects people in Stockholm. We are distinct as nations but we are intertwined all the same, and if the rule of law is at stake in any one state, then every single other state is endangered, and that is why the Commission is right to act, as it must do everywhere there is a threat. I met with some of the people who are out on the streets in Romania: they are teachers and poets and students and pensioners. They are not politicians. They just want a country and a Union where justice is blind, where everyone is treated equally before the law, where corruption is eradicated and where winning an election does not mean you are entitled to divide up the country like your personal spoils of war. I will finish by saying thank you for standing up. Vă auzim pe stradă. We hear you. (Applause)

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group. We Socialists and Democrats welcome today's debate, and this is the right place for this, because we focus on the rule of law, democracy and human rights, and because the stability of Eastern Europe is important and because the economic recovery that is now beginning must be accompanied by a consolidation of democracy. Romania is an important country in this context, a country with great potential. Therefore, it does not matter if fundamental criticism is voiced. The willingness to take part in a discussion, however, also means the will to look for solutions, to discuss everything openly and transparently. We welcome the fact that the Romanian Minister of Justice was prepared to come here and regret that he is not allowed to take part in the debate. We want to know what progress has been made on judicial reform last year. We have clear criteria for assessing whether the reforms are in conformity with the Constitution, whether the reforms are in line with European legislation and whether European standards are being respected, in particular those of the Venice Commission. Only when we become concrete can we succeed, and only then can we solve the problems.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Dear Mr President! European institutions in recent years have a particular ease of interfering in the internal affairs of Member States, even if such interference is not justified from the point of view of treaty records. Once again, it is necessary to remind the Commission that the European Union is composed of sovereign, democratic states that have the right to shape their system in the area of judicial power as expected by the citizens. If some changes fail to win enough social support or have negative effects, then the public in democratic elections will be able to judge their authors accordingly. And you really look pathetic to Commissioner Jourová as a professor instructing Romania's democratically elected government. The Commission should not usurp itself the right to such an assessment because its mandate is not democratic. Mr Weidenholzer very much regrets that Romanians” Justice Minister cannot take part in this debate. Well, ladies, there was just a moment ago that the minister was here. It's enough to invite him. I would ask for temperance in ferring radical assessments of regulations that still haven't gotten final shape yet. And this is not only for Romania, but also for my country.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I am of the generation which has been marked by the events of the fall of the Berlin Wall and everything that happened afterwards. I can also remember the first time that we welcomed colleagues from Bulgaria and Romania in this Chamber, and I was very, very moved. I don’t cry very often, I can tell you, but there were tears running down my cheeks. For me, this was reuniting the family. But in a family we also talk about things that aren’t going well. Next year, Romania will be holding the Presidency of the European Union, and we’ll all be looking at the image that Romania presents. I know that Romania has a long and proud tradition of liberal democracy and civic engagement, and I hope that that is the past that Romania will choose because, unlike the previous speaker, I do think that values are a matter for the European Union. This is what we have laid down in the Treaties. Romania has made a great deal of effort, achieved a lot and made very good progress in recent years, but now it seems to be waivering. I would really encourage the Romanian Government to follow the recommendations of the European Commission and to invite the Venice Commission to judge the reform package – not just refer loosely to some recommendations but invite the Venice Commission. I also think it would be a good idea for a delegation from the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) to travel to Romania and talk to people and actually find out and understand what’s going on. On the reform of the judiciary, concerns have been expressed all around, and I really hope that the Romanian Government is going to take heed. Finally, I would like to refer briefly to the new legislation on civil society. I find it very worrying. This is happening not just in Romania or Hungary and Poland, but also in some other EU countries, and tonight we will be talking about the shrinking space for civil society. Civil society may be a pain in the neck, but it is essential for a robust and healthy democracy. A democracy organises its own critics. That’s what democracy is all about. So please reconsider. Finally – the last sentence – I would like to reiterate this: Parliament decided a year and a half ago not to focus on just one country and then another but to install a mechanism – and I’m counting on the Commission – that assesses all the Member States.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, corruption is an evil that unfortunately still we have not overcome, and I think every single Member State does have corruption. But the important thing is to recognise that and to work against it, tirelessly and relentlessly, because corruption actually undermines the very fabric of society. It makes people lose trust in state and a democracy; it also leads to big losses of public money – money that is urgently needed elsewhere. And in Romania, tens of thousands of people are on the streets, against a corrupt political elite – an elite which sees itself as running a state as a sort of self-service system and which misuses its power to protect itself from justice. And after significant progress that had been made by Romania leading up to EU accession and in the years afterwards, now what we actually see is steps backwards. The progress is being reversed, and this is bad for the Romanian Government, for the Romanian citizens, but also for the whole of the European Union – and Romanian citizens are EU citizens. With the new laws, prosecutors are deprived of indispensable instruments for investigation, courts are put under more political control, and corruption is even partly decriminalised. The new laws clearly have one objective: to weaken the legal system and to make it harder to prosecute high-level corruption. We expect the Romanian Government and the Romanian Parliament to follow the court ruling and to make the laws compatible with EU standards and EU rules. Corruption has a direct effect on citizens in Romania. We see this in the bad condition in many schools. We see this in hospitals, where you risk actually getting more infections.
