We see coal power plants that run without a permit for years and with the full knowledge of the authorities. And as Greens, we also came to Romania to speak with the authorities; we came to speak with the citizens on the street; we wrote to the European Commission; and we also asked for this debate to happen. I want to stress what I said before: Romanian citizens are European citizens. They have the same rights as every other European citizen. That’s why we as Greens cannot accept that Romanians are still being deprived of one of the most basic and fundamental freedoms of Europeans: that is, to be a member of the Schengen zone and to travel freely within the Union. We need to end the situation that Romanians are being stopped at borders that we thought we overcome. Romanians have the right to be free of corruption, to have a government that cares about public interest, and to enjoy their European freedoms.

name: Laurențiu Rebega
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, an open channel of communication with the Romanian Government will always be the most appropriate way to clarify the steps and procedures behind a sensitive legislative initiative, while fully respecting the rights and the obligations of the Member States. That is why I read the first two articles of the Romanian Constitution. Article 1: 'Romania is a national, sovereign and independent, unitary and indivisible state. (...) Romania is a rule of law, democratic and social, in which human dignity, rights and freedoms of citizens, free development of human personality, justice and political pluralism represent supreme values, in the spirit of the democratic traditions of the Romanian people and ideals Revolution of December 1989 and are guaranteed.” Article 2: “National sovereignty belongs to the Romanian people, who exercise it through their representative bodies, constituted by free, regular and fair elections, as well as by referendum. No group or person may exercise sovereignty on their own behalf.” Today we are witnessing the worrying politicisation of a political group of a debate that should have the reverse aim of eliminating the political factor and encouraging fact-based considerations. Today's debate has an example value. The rule of law is not a divine and inalterable creation, but a human construct that must be maintained and renovated permanently, not only in Romania, but throughout the European Union. But there is also a “but”. Discussions at the European Union cannot and must not be substituted for solutions. It was also said by President Juncker and President Iohannis: we, Romanians, must find solutions in Romania. Romania wants to comply with constitutional and European standards, but through a viable institutional dialogue. But the European Union must understand that Romania is not a second-rate country, with citizens of the Republic of Moldova two. There are still unresolved issues, but, nevertheless, Romania has shown political and civic responsibility, addressing these issues in an open and comprehensive way. We've run away from the Soviet Union too long to accept having anyone on top of us. The great examination that the political class must give is the extent to which it can generate good governance, ensuring stability, balance and prosperity to society. And the exam we have to take is not in front of Europe, it is in front of our children and descendants.

name: Presidente. –
text: We have listened to the views of political groups. Now we can use blue cards, of course an ad speaker.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE).
text: — Mr President, the Social Democratic Party claims that it is making justice reform, that it aligns justice with European norms, but who can trust the Social Democratic Party? Can you let a thief set prices in the store where he steals? No, because he'll declare everything for free. The European rules invoked by the PSD do not say that a government can change laws to be exempted from them. Let's recap: PSD won the election after promising money, prosperity, plus the sea with salt. But the first decision of the government was to amend the laws on crimes from the PSD leaders' files. Abuse of service has been erased, and the threshold from which embezzlement begins has been increased. Changes made by the PSD to the justice laws make investigative prosecutors at the hands of the chiefs and subject investigations to a new control body. The PSD changed two governments in one year because they were unable to exempt PSD leaders from the law. PSD lawmakers rejected prosecutors' requests for inquiry when they were concerned with PSD leaders. Now, criminal investigations are members of the Government. Asked why the PSD appoints people with file in the government, a leader of the party replied: “Because we can!”. He'd rather say, “Because we can escape them.” The European Parliament must communicate to the PSD that it can only be legal and that it has won the elections, not justice. The message should be transmitted only and only to the Romanian Government. The idea that the situation of the rule of law must be linked to European funds is wrong. It would punish voters who have exercised their right to vote and not a government exercising its ability to force the law. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue-card question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. —Thank you very much, Mr President, dear colleague. I leave the language aside, but I want to ask you a very concrete question: do you recognize the Constitution of Romania? Article 61 of the Romanian Constitution clearly states that “Parliament is the supreme representative body of the Romanian people and the only legislature authority of the country.” The laws of justice in Romania have now been passed through Parliament after a public debate for months or not?

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: Answer to a question asked in accordance with the “blue card” procedure. — Yes, of course they were passed through Parliament, but this does not solve the issues that the Romanian Government and the ruling party have to answer now. The question remains: Why the rush? Why from day one? And why with address for critical, criminal or pre-criminal situations in which members of the Government are located?

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Socialists and Democrats Group has always been at the forefront when it comes to defending the rule of law and democracy, and we fully stand by those principles today. Romania is one of the youngest democracies in Europe and there are still pending issues there. However, Bucharest showed its responsibility in addressing these issues in an open and inclusive way, which we strongly welcome. We trust Romania to resolve those issues fully, alone through its own independent constitutional mechanisms and procedures, and also by engaging in viable institutional dialogue, including with international institutions and the EU. We should be critical when criticism is needed, but we firmly reject the politicisation of facts without objective consideration of reality. We want clearly to dissociate ourselves from any such attempts in these debates today and to give room for dialogue. For us, the recent protests in Romania are signs of a healthy and democratic civic attitude and engagement as regards the accountability of their politicians.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time that I have raised the problems in Romania. For example, there was the attempt by the Socialist Government to thwart fraud investigations for its own political gain. I also explained why Romania is not yet able to join the Schengen area. Today I am standing in the breach for entrepreneurs and investors in Romania. The reform of company law is going in the wrong direction, because state-owned companies are now allowed to reinstate politicians on their board of directors. At the same time, these companies are fully exempted from the rules on transparency. Thus, the door is opened wide to corruption and self-service by friendly politicians, in line with previous nonsensical legislative changes, so that the elite can enrich themselves at the expense of those companies and Romanian society. This will deter foreign investors. I'm glad this can be discussed today. However, I am still waiting for a parliamentary debate on Spain's violation of European values and its aggression against the Catalan people and its elected leaders.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, the rule of law presupposes the existence of laws in force, ladies and gentlemen. In Bucharest, we intend to legislate, because the laws of organization of justice are not laws in force either. Nor have we had any discussion about amending the Criminal Code and the Criminal Procedure Code. Today's discussion is far from about the rule of law, it is a political discussion and your concern is meaningless only from the perspective of a political partisanship. I do not want to believe that, with this debate, you want to prevent a national parliament from exercising its main prerogative, that of legislating, because it would be undemocratic and incorrect. But about fairness and the rule of law I want to talk. Are the presumption of innocence, Commissioner, not the rights and freedoms in the criminal proceedings procedural safeguards that the European Union protects? You are the guarantor of the Treaties. What did you do, Commissioner, when hundreds of people were abusively sent to prison and acquitted? What did you do, Commissioner, when very, very many citizens were intercepted outside the law? When was the intelligence service, which has no duties in the criminal process, involved in carrying out it? What has been done, Commissioner, when Member States, which privilege their companies' right to bribe in Romania, have given bribes in Romania? The dossiers were closed because they did not suit the economic interests of some Member States. We are very sorry, Commissioner, but justice is done in good faith, honesty and fairness, and only such values you do not prove in today's debate.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, corruption literally kills. It also kills more insidiously by deepening inequalities, undermining citizens' confidence and shaking democracies, thus making the bed of extremes. Despite the courage of its anti-corruption prosecutor's office, Romania is in the process of regressing the fight against this scourge and defading the independence of its judiciary. The Romanian parliament must renounce it. The country is plagued by a handful of rulers driven by the sole desire to save their skin. The leader of the ruling Socialist Party has already been convicted of electoral fraud and is currently under criminal investigation for embezzlement of European funds. The European Union must respond and accompany this country, which will take the Presidency of the Union in 2019. Let us not abandon the thousands of Romanians and NGOs who shout their cry and express their thirst for justice and the European Union.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, Romania is not responsible for this debate, neither is the Romanians. It is about the action of a group of parliamentarians — a temporary majority — and of a constantly changing government, which, without responsibility and with a low dose of competence, tries to divert Romania from a normal rule of law and state responsible to the citizen. I understand that you have met the Minister of Justice and, after your speech, I see that he has not convinced you. He is dissatisfied that he is not speaking in the plenary of the European Parliament. His head, Prime Minister of Romania, was a Member here in the European Parliament. He knows the rules very well and has witnessed similar debates, in which the Prime Minister of the State participated and was able to make his point. The Romanian Prime Minister was supposed to be here today, not the image exercise of the Minister of Justice. The laws of justice must ensure the balance between independence and the responsibility of the magistrates, not to make them available to the political through administrative measures. In Romania, now, the views of the professional organizations of magistrates, the Superior Council of Magistrates, NGOs, citizens have no weight. I think the position of the Venice Commission would be extremely necessary. Commissioner, I repeat what I said: temporary structures, parliament or government, can deviate from European values and principles. The Union Treaty provides for measures in such cases. The Commission must apply them. Conditioning the implementation of the European budget to the state of the rule of law, not contained in the Treaty, is a measure that would negatively affect the citizens of that state, without effect on the government. This proposal must not be part of the future MFF.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Minister Panayotova, Commissioner Jourova, the Commission recently stated: 'We know the situation in Romania'. Commissioner Jourova, I regret to say, including in what you have said today in the Chamber, the Commission either does not know the situation in Romania or closes its eyes to certain aspects. As for the content of the changes, the solutions are in line with the recommendations of the Venice Commission, the Constitutional Court and are inspired by solutions existing in other EU Member States. I refuse to believe that solutions guaranteeing the independence of justice, fundamental rights and freedoms in Western Europe become simply unacceptable in Romania. I refuse to believe that my country is being treated as a second-rate country. In addition, the Commission mixes, hardly qualified, the assessment of the three laws that have already been adopted with what would happen in the future, not telling us a single reference element - article, paragraph or part of the law - that would pose the slightest issue of independence, neutrality or damage to the fight against corruption. (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you Victor. Sorry, I don't want to remove the floor, but now I'm forced, because if one has a minute and talks two, it means that you double the time of the whole debate. Everyone abused the weather, everyone, including even my friend Marinescu. The problem is the responsibility of each to stand in the time he has been assigned, that's the responsibility. It is not my responsibility to take the word out.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: — Mr. President, Romanians shouted in the street “We want justice, not corruption”. Romanians want to be in Europe and that's what we want: in Europe. PSD and ALDE want to get us out of Europe. They started the fight for corruption and against justice and against the rule of law. This coalition and the Minister of Justice, sent as a representative of the Romanian Government, who is around here somewhere, lie shamelessly, saying to the Commission and Parliament that these amendments will transpose European directives. It's not true. The 2014 Presumption of innocence Directive has not been transposed so far. Very bad. But I want to tell you that it provides far higher standards in Romanian laws than the directive provides. So here the presumption of innocence is much better protected than the directive provides for. As such, let's forget this lie. What do they want to do by changing the criminal codes? It is very important for Member States, because cross-border judicial cooperation for cross-border crimes will be affected, a crime committed in another state or committed in Romania, which will become the paradise of crime. For example, they want an investigation to begin only after a person is informed that they are being investigated. I mean, you get a complaint, you call X, and you say, “I got a corruption complaint.” Can you still do it blatantly? Can you still investigate? No, it's over. Another change: any evidence from computers of other crimes will be deleted and thrown to the basket. If you discover child pornography films, you'll have to throw them in the basket and destroy them. You won't be able to modify them. Also, cameras in public places will no longer be able to function, there will be no evidence. No, I had two minutes and I want to have exactly what Mr. Bostinaru had. I speak for my country, not for the party. (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: Renate Weber (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, I have heard many lies in my life, but I really believe that MEP Macovei has now crossed any line. When a society reacts to the important topics that are being debated, it is to be welcomed, because it is a good civic engagement, natural. When the European Commission is interested in what is happening in a Member State, it is natural, because in the EU we are all members of a large family. But it is equally natural to look at the institutional mechanisms that a country has to adopt legislation in accordance with the requirements of the rule of law. In Romania, such mechanisms exist and operate. We have a Constitutional Court that issues binding decisions for the Parliament, forcing it to put any law in line with the Constitution — a Constitutional Court that, despite some criticism expressed over time, is independent and has proven this through decisions taken under different governments. We have the President of Romania, who makes an opportunity check before promulgating a law, having the right to re-send it to the Parliament, explaining punctually which provisions could affect the independence of justice. They are democratic mechanisms and we must trust them, but this does not exclude the evaluation of legislation by the Venice Commission, which can make an objective analysis, because what is desirable is legislation and justice for the benefit of Romanian citizens.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I come from Ireland, which had great difficulty in adapting from being colonised and then becoming independent – in fact, we had a civil war. Romania is trying to come from a time when it was under the control of the USSR, so I can understand a certain amount of friction and ups and downs, etcetera, but nevertheless, it was deemed to be advanced enough to join the European Union, which has a very clear set of values. If we feel that those values have been breached in any way, it is only right, firstly, that we should discuss it here in the European Parliament, and secondly, that there should be some type of sanction if an independent analysis shows that that is the case. Certainly, there have been grave doubts expressed here – and rightly so – about the transparency, the failure to deal with corruption in Romania and especially the independence of the judiciary. These are things we cannot ignore.  It’s probably a bit simplistic to blame the Commission for not doing more. Maybe it should do more, but also I think we have to look at the tools in terms of: if there are certain breaches, what sanctions kick in? It is understandable to say that you shouldn’t blame the people or penalise the people, but how do you actually penalise the Government without penalising the people? Nobody has answered that. There is need for clarity on this. There is need for sanctions, as we go forward, and there is definitely a need to ensure that no country is allowed to have the lack of transparency, the corruption and the challenges to the independence of the judiciary that we are seeing in Romania.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we heard from a previous speaker about whether the EU institutions had been involved on Romania. My understanding is that Romania has been working to achieve the process of judicial reform since the accession treaty and that the institutions have been continually involved. We have a debate today; the Justice Minister will come before the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs shortly; and I agree with those colleagues who say it would be better if he were in a position to answer many of the detailed criticisms today, but I understand the rules. I broadly agree with what Ms Fajon and Ms in ’t Veld were saying, which is that we should acknowledge what progress has been made. We should acknowledge that this is not a black and white debate and we should acknowledge, of course, that are now clear and pending issues and criticisms. But there should be room now for dialogue and I think most sensible people in this debate would understand that. There are still the pending issues but self-criticism has been made and, with an independent constitutional mechanism in place, Romania can display, and has displayed, a willingness to have viable institutional dialogue.

name: Mircea Diaconu (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, first I have a remark: the Minister of Justice, who is here today, is even a member of the Venice Commission. It is true that I, too, am concerned about the rule of law in Romania. I think he's in trouble. About ten years ago, the laws of justice were amended, without any public debate, by taking responsibility, and gave the President the prerogative of discretionary rejecting the appointment of magistrates to leadership positions, that is exactly what Poland is reproached today. Romania has now become the state with the most convictions at the ECHR for abuses against its citizens and no one is responsible. So, the rule of law has problems in Romania. In these years, more and more listening warrants have been issued in Romania. I'm just giving an example: in 2015, 16 times more listening and tracking warrants were required than the FBI. Thousands of citizens were heard during the elections, the last parliamentary elections, on the grounds of national security — to translate more simply: terrorism. These were businessmen, officials, politicians, some even candidates. It's as if, exactly at elections, about a thousand terrorists appeared in Romania and disappeared afterwards just as suddenly, in a country where there is no terrorist and no act of terrorism, and after the elections, as I tell you, they disappeared. So, the rule of law has problems in Romania. According to our Constitution, it is Parliament that can fix these problems, in my opinion as a citizen, and it must not seek approval from anyone and can only be censored by the Constitutional Court, which works. I don't think there's anything else to talk about. I would put an end to it here, but if I have one more second, I want to tell you that I want the independence of justice, but especially of Romania.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: Mr President, the European Union is founded on values, the rule of law, for the benefit of all Europeans. Remembering this people's Europe is not a commonplace but an essential starting point when we discuss serious decisions by the governments of the Member States. Today, we debate and condemn the actions of the Romanian Government and not the Romanian citizens. On the contrary, it is important to make it clear that it is only in the defence of these citizens, and most importantly of all European citizens, that we call on the Romanian Government to respect the most fundamental values of its country and of this Union of ours. In no Member State can we allow the independence of the judiciary, which is essential to the proper functioning of a democratic society, to be called into question. In no Member State can we allow corruption not to be combated and sanctioned strongly. In no Member State can we allow criminal law to be modified for its own benefit. Mr. President, the line of action of the Romanian Government and its leaders is not acceptable. I therefore call on us to be clear in supporting the European Commission and what it has done to support the Romanian Government. But I conclude with the same clarity as I started: we can never compromise on what is fundamental and the European Union is a citizenship project based on the rule of law.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we, the members of the Socialist and Democratic family in this House, truly care about the rule of law, separation of powers and the independence of the judiciary, and of course we understand the legitimate concerns every time there is a risk of breach of the rule of law in relation to a judicial reform in a Member State. Having said that, it is fair to point out that each and every act in this package of reforms has been in answer to previous rulings of the Romanian Constitutional Court; that there has been a preventive exercise of constitutional review of those acts; and that the Romanian Government has shown readiness to comply with the rulings of the Constitutional Court. This reform aims to enhance the accountability of judges in a country which ranks first in terms of violations of Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights; it enhances the presumption of innocence with regard to its due observance by members of the public prosecution service; and, lastly, it is important to break the misuse or political abuse of the links between the judiciary and intelligence services. That is why many of us do not believe that this reform package poses a serious threat or represents a systemic breach of the rule of law in that Member State which is Romania. (Applause)

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Mr President, democracy requires transparency, separation of powers, an independent judiciary system and justice, which should never be bent to serve short-term political tactics or the vested interests of individual politicians. This is the only way to build public trust and encourage citizens’ participation: the fundament of democracy. I see thousands of Romanian people protesting in the streets. I see Romanian citizens full of concern about their country and their justice system. I know that there is no possibility to create trust where corruption is all around. I see some efforts made by the government to strengthen the independence of the judiciary system. It is not sufficient. I continue to see the government watering down anti-corruption laws in Romania and playing an unfair game with society and with all of us – the European family, a family which is based on the rule of law, fundamental values and politics free of corruption. Romanian citizens, please, be brave, be vigilant: don’t give up. Romanian politicians: be open to your society, be honest. Only this attitude can bring real political profits – true profits, not money. European Commission: be strict and, at the same time, open to dialogue. A European Union without values will lose its moral, political and real power. (The Speaker declined to answer a blue-card question from Claudia Ţapardel)

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, since 2005 Romania has a law system based on vague, subjective, interpretable and discretionary laws supported through secret protocols by the intelligence services – why secret if they are constitutional? – and services which were ousted from the judiciary process immediately after the revolution. Consequently, the anti—corruption struggle was easily abused, being transformed into an instrument directed against political adversaries and economic competitors transferring power from those elected to those appointed.  As a result, in the last two years the media is full of the abuses committed in the anti—corruption struggle and the courts have declared inadmissible an increasing number of cases submitted by anti—corruption prosecutors. And now, when the Romanian parliament is obliged to correct a number of articles declared unconstitutional by the Constitutional Court – eliminating their subjectivity – the sovereignty of the Romanian people is being questioned.  In the end, I would like to ask our critics: why should the Romanians feel more under surveillance now in democracy than during Ceausescu’s time?

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: — Mr. President, I confess that this is not the happiest day of my life, but the progress made by Romania since 2007 in the process of strengthening the rule of law, the independence of justice and the fight against corruption is undeniable. Unfortunately, the PSD-ALDE government shows us that this progress is not irreversible. The law-making process of the current parliamentary majority through which it was tried to subordinate justice to the political factor, but also a lack of transparency in debating such changes has put hundreds of thousands of people on the street, and this is not something you can challenge, dear colleagues. At the same time, it generated a harsh reaction of the entire corps of magistrates, who oppose these changes, but also serious and legitimate concerns of the European Commission. Nobody disputes Parliament's right to legislate, but the current PSD-ALDE government must understand one thing, namely that it cannot play with Romania's European path. The independence of the Romanian judiciary, its ability to effectively combat corruption, legislative predictability, as well as the existence of functional mechanisms guaranteeing the fundamental rights and freedoms of the citizen must become indestructible realities and be are the cornerstones of a strong Romania within the European Union. That is why I believe that at the moment it is necessary to start a broad public consultation process with magistrates' associations, civil society, while at the same time identifying functional models at the level of the Member States of the European Union, but also to consult Venice Commission on some basic aspects of justice reforms.

name: Dan Nica (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, unfortunately, so many untruths have been said today that we should also set up a new initiative: The lie kills. What can I tell you, we all wondered why the Minister of Justice in Romania is not allowed to speak. Why is it falsely argued that the Prime Minister should have come, who, nota bene, is not a member of the Council and who has not even received an invitation. The reasons are very simple: because it was not the truth that was interested in today, but political speeches and the lack of any argument. Those who criticize are unable to say, “Sir, this article is wrong”, because there is no such thing. They have colported today and, unfortunately, I want to tell you, some of my fellow Members lies and have misinformed you, Commissioner. Perhaps if you had accepted the meeting with the minister, I'm sure you would have had another speech today. How is it possible to tell about the independence of the judiciary when those laws were adopted by the Constitutional Court? Declared constitutional. How is it possible that you did not know or did not tell you that, out of the 350amendments, 270 were proposed by the Superior Council of Magistracy? There are elements that everyone needs to know, but unfortunately, it is not the truth that has been interested today, but a political debate, in the most unpleasant case.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Mr. President! I welcome the inclusion of the rule of law in Romania on the agenda. It is time for the European Commission to break up with the double standards and, with party political bias, prosecute not only against Hungary and Poland for violations of the rule of law, but also at last to address the socialist government of Romania. At a press conference with President Jean Claude Juncker in Brussels, State President Klaus Iohannis strongly advocated the independence of the Romanian judiciary. Previous at the inauguration of the new Romanian Prime Minister Viorica D, the Head of State also stated that “the violation of the independence of the judiciary is unacceptable and the message of hundreds of thousands of people who have demonstrated the rule of law on the streets for a year” should not be ignored. Justice should not be subordinated to politics, namely to the very core of a corrupt, successor communist socialist party! The cornerstone of the rule of law is that no one is above the law. Liviu Dragnea is not an oligarchic party leader with criminal record and criminal prosecution! In accordance with the requirements of European democracy, the Hungarian community in Romania stands for the restoration of the rule of law, together with the Romanian majority society.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: — Mr. President, Mr. Bostinaru said earlier that we have a second-rate country. No, we don't have a second-hand country. Instead, we have a seventh-rate government, because if it had not been so, we would have had here the Prime Minister of this Government, Mrs. Dancila, who, when it was sworn in, was presented as a key person within the institutions of the European Union. When he had a chance to defend the government, he stays at home, out of fear. Instead, I do not understand what Mr Toader is doing here, because he, as Mr Diaconu said, is indeed a member of the Venice Commission. But when Mr Juncker and Mr Timmermans asked the Romanian Government to consult the Venice Commission, who was the first to say, “We don't need it”? Even Mr. Toader, a member of this committee. In general, the attitude of the Romanian Government is of contempt towards the Commission. Members of the majority, persedists, ALDE members say that there is no information, that everything is a lie, while defending corruption, defending plagiarism, promoting illiterates. So there's a situation where I can only ask the following question: aren't you ashamed, Pesedists? (The speaker agrees to answer a blue-card question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Victor Boștinaru (S&D)
text: question under the 'blue card' procedure. — Mr President, I do not know whether or not my colleague Preda deserves the 'blue card'. However, I want to ask him, with a clear state of embarrassment: Mr. Preda, did you listen to the speech of your former political patron, Traian Basescu, regarding the laws of justice in Romania? He's the one who invented you and then abandoned you. What did Traian Basescu say about Romanian justice laws?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE)
text: Answer to a question asked according to the “blue card” procedure. — I'm used to attacks in person. But I am not used to the phase in which the PSD, who made Traian Basescu absolute evil, are now mobilizing him in their fight against the rule of law. This is, indeed, something new. I know that their limit does not exist, but I remain convinced that we must be honest and coherent. We can not say here one thing and at home the opposite. You defend the corrupt, you appear publicly with people who are convicted, people who are being prosecuted. You put in the government illiterate and people who have to answer for the robberies of billions. (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I was Minister of Justice in the Czech Republic for five years and was responsible for justice reform, so let me have some comments from a person who on this issue He knows a little something, albeit from the level of another country. To me, the reform that has been introduced in Romania at the moment strikes as completely unacceptable. It is quite obvious that this will lead to corruption being very difficult to investigate. We can mention those specific things here, the reduction of the deadline for reporting corruption, the method of interrogations for this crime, the need to notify someone that they are under investigation, etc. These are specific things, and I am very happy that we are addressing this here today, and I am a little sorry that our socialist colleagues are not willing to look at this thing objectively and that they only perceive it partisanally and politically. But there are some objective criteria for how serious crime is to be investigated, and these criteria are simply denied by the current Romanian government. And that's an objective fact, though someone can cheer on one side or another. So if the Commission addresses Poland today, it should also address Romania, where the situation is similar.

name: Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: — Mr President, as President Juncker said last week, there is no need to talk about non-observance of the rule of law in Romania. The package of justice laws comes as a necessity to correlate the internal legislation with the decisions of the Constitutional Court, the ECHR jurisprudence, the recommendations of the European Commission, as well as the proposals of the professional bodies and institutions serving justice in Romania. There has never been a question of the Romanian Parliament not taking into account the decisions of the Constitutional Court, and, as regards the law-making process, according to the Constitution, there is double control: on the one hand, the control exercised by the Constitutional Court and, on the other hand, the exercised by the President. What is happening today in Romania is the perfect proof of the exercise of democracy, involving both civil society and people's representatives in the legislative forum of the country. 2018 is the year of the centenary of the Great Union. Romania is in celebration. The 100th anniversary of the Great Union. I wish all of us to unite our efforts and energy to celebrate Romania. We are witnessing natural debates in a performing democracy, but internal debates must not be presented in the European Parliament as false subjects of political disputes, and there is a risk of creating emotion and social divide in the centenary year, a pre-election year.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, 600 000 people in the streets against the government: do you think the government is doing good things for people or bad things for people? The reality in Romania is as follows: there is a major discrepancy between what people want and what the ruling coalition wants. People want justice, justice, rule of law, rule of law. People want European values, and politicians in power want to weaken state institutions, want justice under their own control. Who are these politicians? At their top is the chairman of the Social Democratic Party, who is also the Speaker of Parliament, convicted of electoral fraud. Commissioner, do you think a proven criminal, doctoring the laws of justice, strengthens justice or weakens it? I think it weakens her. I do not trust that it strengthens it, and therefore I want to say the following thing. First of all, to the Romanians protesting we must convey the following message: what you do is seen, matters. Europe distinguishes between honest people and corrupt politicians. You, Commissioner, I ask you to stand by the people who want justice.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: — Mr President, I would like to thank, first of all, the representative of the Council, who had a fair, equidistant, objective and reserved position. Commissioner, you are the disappointment of my day today, because I am going to leave you this brochure, in which you will also find the charts of the public debate and how many amendments have been made by professional associations, whether we are talking about judges, magistrates and you may understand that the course, now, of amending the laws of justice is a necessity. Because I do not understand from the title, how do you mean to put a title that justice reform would affect the rule of law? I say the lack of reform would affect the rule of law. Mrs. Macovei, who applauds here when she shouldn't, has made a package of laws, through assumption, in which there were many unconstitutional articles left. What is now struggling with this government and the Minister, all due respect for its professionalism, is to correct these unconstitutional amendments. There were hundreds of people, thousands of people put in jail under the laws of Mrs. Macovei and now we pay to the ECHR from the budget of Romanian citizens.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr. President! The fight against corruption in Romania and strengthening the rule of law require constant efforts. However, criticisms and signals cannot be ignored: accusations of political engagement of the directors of the institutions, unjustified and unlawful interactions with secret services, serious excesses in specific cases, and disregard for fundamental rights. The necessary amendments to judicial laws must be made in the interests of the citizens, and it is important that politics do not weaken the tools of the institutional system of fighting against corruption, but completely exclude the amendments and see a political attack in each article in the judicial system against a huge mistake. The EU should not only monitor the judicial system in Romania from the point of view of the fight against corruption, but also call for the implementation of general rule of law principles, which is where the majority of citizens feel the justice system most shortcomings.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: — Mr President, dear colleagues, I regret that we are once again faced with a dirty campaign of misinformation about Romania and that we are in an extremely dangerous situation, in which legitimate actions of a national parliament are challenged. What you have not understood is that today we are talking about some laws of justice in Romania that aim to respect the civil rights and freedoms of Romanian citizens and respect the principle of innocence. Perhaps we should discuss here, in the forum of European democracy, about the hundreds, if not the thousands of lives destroyed in Romania by failing to comply with this principle enshrined in European legislation, namely the principle of innocence. Let's talk about televised justice, careers and public image destroyed as a result of cases based on inconclusive and little solid evidence, which, in the end, were resolved with the non-prosecution or even closed. When we talk about the laws of justice, we are talking about a package of laws that has been debated for months together with professional associations, as well as at the level of the national Parliament, and the amendments tabled are the emanation of this consultation process.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask Madam Commissioner, who today expressed so many concerns and objections about the three laws governing the justice system that were amended in January in the Romanian Parliament: why, Madam Commissioner, did you not express any concerns or any objections when, in 2016, the Cioloș Government – the so-called ‘expert’s government’ but in reality a right-wing government – issued an emergency ordinance to amend and supplement the penal code and the code of criminal procedures, amending 114 articles? In this way the codes were amended in a non-transparent manner and without debate or public consultation, without the competent authorities or any interested parties being able to propose amendments or formulate technical observations. Why, Madam Commissioner? Because the political correctness ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I went to Romania last November to speak about the Portuguese prohibition of bearer shares. I met with Romanian NGOs and journalists and was impressed with their high quality and commitment, and it pains me to hear that a draft law that was endorsed by the Romanian Senate in the meantime is actually closing the space for civil society. These NGOs and journalists work to expose and stop corruption. This debate should actually be about the fight against corruption in Romania because the justice system, despite the constraints, seems to be working, and so is the Romanian National Anti-Corruption Directorate, which, working together with OLAF, concluded that the leader of the ruling Social Democrat Party (PSD), Mr Liviu Dragnea, is responsible for serious fraud using EU funds, ‘creating an organised criminal group’ for that purpose, and ‘misusing his position for personal gain’. I am reading this from OLAF’s report: it is a press release of 13 November. So my question to Romanian colleagues and the Government – and I wish the Minister could speak – is how come this person has not been relieved of his position in the parliament and in the party? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, your colleagues, President Juncker and Commissioner Timmermans, have expressed concern and urged Romania's Parliament to amend the laws of justice adopted last year, without being promulgated, and without knowing the verdict of the Court The Constitutional Court of Romania. We are dealing here with serious interference in the constitutional and internal affairs of the Romanian state. You drew the short straw, Commissioner. Those concerns, not supported by them today, but by you, seem not shared by the European Parliament. Take a look around: there are twenty or fewer fellow Members from other Member States who are also worried, like you. I listened carefully to the speeches and I can only notice a simple string of slogans, especially on the right side. Such a debate has no place in this House, without the participation of representatives of the Romanian authorities, in order to explain and be transparent before you. I challenge all colleagues to think about what decisions they would make in their countries, if they had the same abuse of justice that Romania has had in recent years and which they are trying hard to remove. Romania and Bulgaria must be received into Schengen and the MCV must disappear. These are debates that must take place here in plenary.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: I would like to inform you that I decided during the Catch-the-Eye procedure not to give extra blue cards, because Mrs. Macovei often asks for blue cards. I have that right. As I was informed, Macovei was among the speakers. But we are very late, and I beg you for your understanding.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: — Mr. President, the fact that today we are talking about the situation in Romania, in our country — I mean those colleagues in Romania — in such apocalyptic terms, colleagues, shows, where appropriate, the limits of understanding or even the anti-Romanian agenda of some of you, especially because we are at key times when the post-2020 financial instruments are being reconfigured within the European Union and we already have the incorrect narrative of the conditionality of European money on the so-called degree of respect for the rule of law. We live in interesting times. I want to say one thing very clearly: Romanians are European citizens. We're good Europeans. We are in solidarity with the values of democracy of the European type and we want the true rule of law, without elements of unconstitutionality, without abuse, with internal system of checks and balances. Last word, Mr. Preda: you are only interested in protagonizing the individual. It's shameful what you're doing.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the European Parliament for having this debate. This debate is not about the Commission or the Parliament; it is about justice for Romanians who have legitimate expectations that there would be independent and efficient justice for them in Romania.  However, some of you mentioned or questioned the role of the Commission. Let me reiterate that the role of the Commission is to fulfil the obligation of the guardian of the Treaty. It is our duty to assess the situation of the rule of law in each Member State and to raise concerns when we see systemic problems.  The justice system is a sophisticated and complex structure, calibrated on the basis of legal traditions and fulfilling the principle of the balance of powers in the state. Such a system is built over decades and can be destroyed in a week or overnight. That is why we are so vigilant and that is why we have raised the concerns at this moment.  We are assessing objectively the Romanian system on the basis of evidence and facts. We are offering dialogue and support. This is what we do. What we do not do, because we must not do that, is interfere in individual cases – just to respond to the question of Ms Nicolai. The independence of Romania’s judicial system and its capacity to fight corruption effectively are essential cornerstones of a strong Romania in the European Union. After ten years of hard work, Romania has a professional judiciary and the population of Romania has been clear in its support for the fight against corruption. I am confident that all the Romanian authorities fully realise this and will do what is necessary to bring the draft laws into line with the constitution and send a strong signal that will help rebuild trust.  The Commission stands by to help Romania in this endeavour, however and whenever that is useful.

name: Monika Panayotova
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me assure you once again that the Bulgarian Presidency and the Council as a whole attach great importance to upholding the rule of law and fundamental values within the European Union. The Council will continue to follow this debate closely and the Presidency will pay particular attention to the views which were expressed here today.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Discussion is over. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. — The recent laws aimed at changes in the functioning of justice in the Romanian state have gained wide visibility at European level. Under the careful eyes of the European institutions and Member States, a part of the Romanian political environment risks taking a significant step back from the path towards the completion of European integration, trying to remove the Romanian state from the notable progress achieved under the Cooperation and Verification. This mechanism belongs to the European Commission, whose President, Jean-Claude Juncker, expressed his appreciation for the progress of the recent years of the Romanian judicial system, but also the fear of the irreversibility of the mistake that members of the Romanian Parliament are about to make. Secondly, these laws risk significantly removing the state from joining the Schengen area. Accession decision is taken through the agreement of the European Ministers of Justice and Interior, who I doubt would agree to put the security of people, the single market and European capital to any additional danger. As a Romanian politician, I trust that, after today's debate, my ruling colleagues will have the good judgment to adopt a package of fair, pro-Romanian and pro-European laws.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on: — the report by Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC, Euratom) . 480/2009 establishing a Guarantee Fund for external actions (COM (2016) 0582 — C8-0374/2016 — 2016/0274 (COD)) (A8-0132/2017) — the report by Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Decision No 360/86 466/2014/EU granting an EU guarantee to the European Investment Bank against losses arising from financing activities supporting projects outside the Union (COM (2016) 0583 — C8-0376/2016 — 2016/0275 (COD)) (A8-0135/2017)

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner Katainen, President Hoyer, in recent years there has been a strong criticism of the European Union for its inaction in the face of the refugee crisis and, indeed, in this House there have been many times that we have called on both the Council and the Commission to act urgently to find solutions on the table: short - term actions, but also longer - term actions, in order to address in a more structural way the migration phenomenon and the situation of the countries in our environment that are hosting refugees in a more structural manner. And just as we criticize that inaction, I think it is also fair to acknowledge that the European External Investment Plan, which the European Commission presented in June 2016, responds to some of those needs we have been pointing out. In July 2017, this plenary session already gave the green light to one of the components of that Plan, which was the European Fund for Sustainable Development, and today we are discussing another of its components, which is the modification of the EIB's external lending mandate, whose activities are guaranteed by the Union budget. After eight months of hard negotiations with the Maltese Presidency first and with the Estonian Presidency thereafter, we have succeeded in closing an agreement which I believe will substantially improve the current external lending mandate. I would like to begin by recalling that all the countries of the Union, and the Commission also, signed the Sustainable Development Goals and that all our actions must therefore be aimed at their implementation. By amending this Regulation, we will quantitatively and qualitatively improve the European Union's action through the EIB abroad and, above all, in the South and East neighbourhood countries. We improved quantitatively because we increase investment capacity to EUR 32.3 billion by 2020, with a very special effort in the countries of the Mediterranean and in the Balkans. As for the qualitative improvement of our investments, we have worked on a number of aspects. The first, and probably the most important one, is that we have added a new priority and cross-cutting objective so that all initiatives funded through this programme contribute to meeting the Sustainable Development Goals and thus eradicate the causes why people should leave their homes. Within this new objective, we have not wanted to forget the countries in our environment which, in a clear demonstration of solidarity, host millions of refugees and whose public services and infrastructure are completely overflowed. In addition, in order to comply with the Paris Agreements and our commitment to assist developing countries, we have increased the share to be spent on climate change-related investments from 25 to 35 per cent. Another area in which we have also worked and improved the Decision has been support for local private sector development, improving SMEs access to finance, encouraging the transition from an informal economy to the formal sector and by seeking special support to investment projects in rural areas, especially for the drinking water treatment, sanitation and renewable energies. Finally, as a qualitative improvement, I would like to highlight the inclusion of a gender perspective in all operations financed by the EIB. We adopt paragraphs 8a and b, and with this approval we ensure that the commitments of the equality strategy and its action plan are fulfilled, and we will also promote respect for the principles of pay transparency and equal remuneration. And, in conclusion, I would like to highlight two very important aspects of this legislation. On the one hand, we have introduced a whole new chapter that has to do with the evaluation of the programme; we have established a set of parameters and their corresponding indicators in order to assess the results of investments from a social, environmental and economic point of view. On the other hand, we have introduced much more restrictive legislation in the prevention of money-laundering, combating the financing of terrorism, taxation and non-cooperating territories. In this regard, the EIB will have to submit to us every year a report on the implementation of this policy, including a country-by-country report and a list of intermediaries with which it collaborates. As I said at the beginning of my speech, I believe that this agreement substantially improves the EIB's investment mandate and I hope that tomorrow it will be broadly supported by this House and that the EIB will be able to implement it as soon as possible.

name: Nirj Deva
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, a year ago the House backed my proposal to establish stronger ties with the private sector, marking a revolution in EU development financing, a new way of mobilising private capital, key to wealth creation and the fight against global poverty. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development on this proposal, I supported the overall increase in the EU guarantee from EUR 27 billion to EUR 32.2 billion in order to address the root causes of migration. As part of the external investment plan, together with the EIB, this Marshall Plan for Africa is of paramount importance in implementing the shift from global grants to loans, promoting investment rather than handouts.  International development is not just about eliminating poverty, it is also about delivering security, stability and economic opportunities to poor and fragile communities, thereby preventing citizens from having to flee their home country in search of a better life. For the West – eager to stem the flow of refugees and migrants from Africa and the Middle East – supporting development is a much more effective approach than building walls and razor-wire fences.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank the rapporteur, Ms Gardiazabal Rubial, and also Mr Siegfried Mureşan, who chaired the trilogues, for their very constructive work. Following fruitful cooperation among the three EU institutions, I believe we have finally agreed an excellent compromise. The Commission welcomes the agreement on the compromise package, which was approved successfully by the Committee of the Permanent Representatives (Coreper) on 1 December and by the Committee on Budgets on 4 December by a large majority. This compromise will allow the European Investment Bank to continue rapidly implementing its economic resilience initiative in support of the southern neighbourhood and the Western Balkans and to continue supporting EU external policy objectives in eligible countries. As soon as adopted, the text will enable the EIB to contribute rapidly to the new objectives by providing up to EUR 2.3 billion of additional financing to private sector beneficiaries. The increase of EUR 5.3 billion in the size of the EU Guarantee Fund over the period 2014-2020 will also reinforce substantially the EIB’s capacity to grant loans in the neighbourhood, as well as in Asia and Latin America. It will allow the EIB to act effectively in line with EU external policy priorities. The compromise will increase the flexibility for the EIB to switch amounts under the regional ceiling allocations from the current 10% between regions to 20%, but only in the direction of high priority regions for the Union, in particular, Ukraine and migration-response-related regions or any forthcoming challenges within the remaining part of the mandate 2014-2020. The climate-change dimension of the mandate is also reinforced. It includes an increase of the target from 25% to 35% of total EIB financing operations outside the EU by the year 2020. On taxation and non-cooperative jurisdictions, the compromise text will align with provisions agreed for the EFSI 2.0 and the European Fund for Sustainable Development legislative files. The outcome is very welcome and reflects successful negotiations. As regards asset management, following negotiations in Council and Parliament, a cross-file compromise was agreed. The EIB will continue to undertake the asset management of the Guarantee Fund while the Commission will do the asset management of the new European Fund for Sustainable Development Guarantee Fund. It was agreed to review the situation in 2019. Honourable Members, I want to thank you for your excellent cooperation. This is a big step forward and it enables us to be more efficient in order to achieve our external policy goals.

name: Werner Hoyer
text: President of the European Investment Bank. – Mr President, it is a great pleasure to be here today on the occasion of the formal adoption of the European Investment Bank’s revised external lending mandate (ELM), which is a key tool for the bank’s activities outside the European Union. I will take the opportunity to thank the members of the Committee on Budgets, in particular the rapporteur, Madam Gardiazabal, and Commission Vice-President Katainen for their excellent cooperation on this difficult matter. The mid-term review of the ELM began in 2016 and I’m pleased to say it once again recognised the ELM as a highly efficient instrument that allows the EIB to deliver external and development action with real impact on the ground and at a minimal cost to the EU budget. The increase in both scope and size of the revised mandate is, I hope, a sign that you as co-legislators believe in our ability to deliver EU foreign-policy goals under this mandate. I thank you for this endorsement and for your support in ensuring the ELM was adapted in such a way as to allow the bank to deliver in supporting new and continuing priorities outside the EU up until 2020. Some key changes have been made to the ELM to allow us to address better the latest EU external priorities. We have been called upon to give particular support to countries outside the Union affected by migration, whether host countries, countries of transit or countries of origin. Significantly, the scope of the guarantee has been extended to allow coverage for private-sector lending operations under our new Economic Resilience Initiative, allowing the bank to take more risk in this area. This is fundamental to the success of the Resilience Initiative in the southern neighbourhood and the Western Balkans. The overall increase in the ELM ceiling from EUR 27 billion to EUR 32.3 billion will also help us meet our objectives under the Economic Resilience Initiative while at the same time ensuring that we continue to meet ambitious lending levels across all regions covered by the mandate. We have demonstrated our ability to react to evolving EU priorities, not only with the Resilience Initiative but also when we increased our lending to Ukraine to EUR 3 billion over three years as part of the Union’s special support package to Ukraine. And we have stepped up considerably our support for climate action. Having committed to providing a minimum of 25% climate action financing (and, by the way, we did 27-point-something in 2017), at 33% for external lending we are already almost reaching the objective of getting to 35% by 2020. So we are on a very good track in this respect. We’ve also supported additional requirements for the bank in terms of transparency and accountability, and I know how important this is to the Members of the European Parliament. This is particularly the case in the fields of tax avoidance, fraud and evasion, non-compliant jurisdictions, the prevention of money laundering and the fight against terrorism. I want to assure you that we take these requirements seriously and I will speak more about them later in the debate on the EIB’s annual report.  No sooner have we finalised the revision of the ELM that will take us to the end of the current Multiannual Financial Framework than we now have to prepare the landscape for EU spending post 2020. I look forward to exchanges with you on this in the coming months. I can already say with confidence that, given the success of the ELM to date and its ability to leverage investments to an order of 30-40 times the budget provisioning required, I’ve no doubt that it will continue to be a key tool for the EU post 2020.

name: Eduard Kukan
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, my congratulations to Ms Gardiazabal for finalising this report. It is becoming increasingly important to steer our external investments and activities, especially when it comes to our neighbourhood. In this respect, external lending could be a powerful instrument to achieve our policy objectives. However, it needs strategic focus and clear direction. I hope that the European Investment Bank will be a strong partner in executing our policy objectives. The EU is not immune to instability behind our borders. Mounting crises mixed with worsening socio-economic situations in many countries in our neighbourhood exposed us to unprecedented waves of migration. However, we have been able to react and mobilise resources in order to respond to root cases of migration. I’m glad that the renewed lending mandate will contribute to stepping up our investment activities to strengthen resilience, tackle root cases of migration and promote new forms of private sector participation, especially in neighbourhood countries.

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, firstly I would like to thank Eider Gardiazabal Rubial who was our rapporteur on this file for the final agreement which she managed to negotiate. I think this reflects the view of the vast majority of the Members of the House and of the political groups, and it is with great pleasure that we are going to support this. I would also like to thank Vice—President Jyrki Katainen for the very helpful role that the Commission has played throughout the nine trialogues which we held together with two Presidencies, the Maltese and the Estonian, before we managed to agree on this important file. And President Hoyer, to you and to the staff of the EIB, I also thank you for always having been by our side with the adequate expertise.  We have always said from the beginning that we were going to review the External Lending Mandate based on the needs on the ground; we have seen that since the beginning of the External Lending Mandate.  Politically, we have decided to take a more active role in the eastern neighbourhood of the Union to support countries which have embarked on a pro-European path there and also to engage more actively in the southern neighbourhood of the Union to help tackle, of course, the migration and refugee crises.  What we have done with these changes to the External Lending Mandate was to use the flexibility to increase and enlarge it where possible, and also to make use of the reduced exposure in Turkey due to the fact that less financeable projects could be found there; to make use of all of this flexibility to enable us to put resources where they are needed and to respect the political commitments which we have made.  We are of course as a Parliament disappointed that the Council, the Member States, did not agree to increase the overall level of ceilings. It would have meant only increasing the burden on the budget of the Union in a very small manner – by EUR 34 million – and it would have enabled even more predictability in terms of the EIB’s engagement in the long term. But I believe that the compromise, the solution found is a good one. And I am looking forward to the vote and a large majority tomorrow in plenary.

name: Isabelle Thomas
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, who, with patience and determination, was able to build a solid majority in Parliament and put this position forward during the trialogue. It is a long term work that is bearing fruit today, and I would like to congratulate him on it. These reports represent major progress towards transparency and the course ahead for the future of the European Union. They will be intended to inspire future Union policies and already inspire Parliament's proposals for the next multiannual financial framework. In the first place, of course, there is the fight against fraud and tax evasion. It is unacceptable that public money can contribute to tax evasion structures and aggressive tax planning. They are not only profound injustices, but also contribute to the destabilization of States and are obstacles in our fight against crime and terrorism. With these relations, the European Investment Bank will be preserved from any relationship with countries that do not cooperate with the Union in tax matters. Today's reports will serve as examples in this area. These texts also provide an opportunity to set a new course, a new horizon for the overall external development strategy of the European Union. With the Paris agreement, with the UN Sustainable Development Goals, the European Union and the Member States have made historic and major climate and civilization commitments. We are now guarantors of these commitments and that these commitments do not turn into pious vows, announcements or false pretenses. They must quickly translate into concrete and tangible developments, as these reports have succeeded in putting these commitments into the objectives of the external policy of the Union. But we need to look further, ensure that these objectives are compasses to European policies and, first and foremost, to the future multiannual financial framework. Finally, let us be careful — and these reports succeed — not to fall into a trap of instrumentalising development policy for the benefit of other objectives. No, it is not a policy of border control, nor the management of migration flows or readmission agreements. No, it's not a blackmail tool to fund corrupt regimes. On the contrary, development is a long-term policy towards our neighbours, our partners. These reports are a clear reminder of this, and we will have to make it a tough line for the programmes of the future multiannual financial framework.

name: Stanisław Ożóg
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Dear ladies! The EKR supports the overall direction of the changes contained in the reports. Addressing the causes of immigration is one of the most important elements of the European Union's current action strategy. Extending the EIB's authorisation to lend to third countries, raising the European Union guarantee level to €32.3 billion is an essential element to achieve this. However, it is incomprehensible to transfer this scope from the EIB, as proposed, to the Commission. Having analysed the costs and benefits of this solution, I believe personally that this change should not take place before 2021. I also point out that in terms of changes to the external mandate of the EIB and raising the ceilings, the needs of the Eastern dimension should be particularly taken into account, which strategically accelerate the process of economic integration and political partnership between the European Union and those countries, particularly I mean Belarus and Ukraine.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, congratulations first of all to our excellent colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial on the quality of his work and his tenacity in the negotiations. Clearly, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the migratory pressure on the countries of the Union is a major challenge for our future. Everyone is aware of the tensions that this already entails between the countries of the Union and the political risks to the future of our democracies, which are already emerging here and there during the elections. The management of migration flows is therefore a political priority, and for the construction of Europe itself and for the health of our democracy. It is from this main point of view that I want to lend my support and that of my group to the proposal for a decision which aims to enable the EIB to expand quantitatively and qualitatively its external lending mandate. In concrete terms, this means several advances that I want to welcome. First, a fourth broad horizontal objective of addressing the root causes of migration is integrated into the EIB's external lending mandate. Secondly, the maximum ceiling for financing operations is increased to $32.3 billion on the understanding that $1.4 billion could be allocated to public-sector projects aimed at refugees and host communities and that $2.3 billion under a private sector lending mandate could be allocated to projects addressing the root causes of migration. Of course, these amounts are modest, even if they are part of the broader framework of an external investment strategy. But at a time when demography explodes in Africa, at a time when the effects of global warming are being felt, at a time when China is grabbing for its benefit part of Africa's wealth, we cannot resign ourselves to the fact that the left behind in this continent do not have no choice other than that of European exile. The democratic future of Europe and the stability of our continent are playing a large part in Africa. We must be aware of this and take the necessary action.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, you want to present these funds as a generous and humanitarian contribution by the European Union to development cooperation. And nothing further. This brings together the whole unsupportive strategy towards which the European Union is directed. These guarantee funds convert development cooperation into a business and a financial instrument whose profits are pocketed by private companies and whose losses, if any, are covered by public resources. Both the foreign shares guarantee fund and the foreign operations loss fund are both the financial arms to make cooperation policy a migration retention policy and a private business. And someone has to say it, Mr. Hoyer. The European Investment Bank is today a criminal organisation. The EIB promotes financial benefits and crimes against human rights and the environment. Yesterday you approved EUR 1.5 billion for the TAP, a gas pipeline without a climate impact report and which is obvious to human rights violations in Azerbaijan, Turkey and repression in southern Italy. In the Canary Islands, 125 million for gas infrastructure rather than renewable. You give large sums to destructive projects, such as eucalyptus monoculture in Brazil and Uruguay or mining in Madagascar, which displaces the population and pollutes water. What the EIB is doing is turning development finance into public aid to increase the profits of private companies and private capital, and this is something that cannot be tolerated. We therefore urge the EIB not to invest more public funds in unnecessary, unfair, unsustainable and, at least, financially reckless projects.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, owing to the efforts of the European Parliament and its very competent rapporteur, Ms Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, we have seen improvements through this decision. In particular, the improvements with regard to transparency, to tax justice and climate spending are very positive outcomes. Now we need to monitor to make sure that these requirements are effectively implemented.  It is very important that now it is mentioned explicitly that the aim is, above all, to address the root causes of migration. Let’s be honest: this means good, sound development policy, eradication of poverty, combating other global challenges and the EU and Agenda 2030 sustainable development goals really need to be internalised and understood properly by the European Investment Bank (EIB), especially if it wishes to have a more prominent role in EU development policy.  I would also like to see the energy lending criteria be very much taken care of. We need to make sure that the Paris Climate Agreement is implemented. We are very happy – it could have been better but it is already very good – that we have the 35% climate-proofing mentioned in that decision.  The World Bank has announced that it will not finance upstream oil and gas projects after 2019. I think this is something that the EIB also should consider.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the external investment plan was set up with the aim of tackling the root cause of migration by helping to achieve development goals in third countries through loans and grants, financing projects to create jobs. This is another version of the idiotic Juncker Plan which is economically daft. It is a plan to pump-prime businesses with government money. When will the EU learn that this does not work? Governments do not create jobs. Businesses create jobs, and those sort of false jobs are unsustainable. Give these Third World countries trade deals not handouts. We need to give these people trade deals so that they can create businesses themselves. As for today’s ludicrous inclusion of Tunisia on the financial blacklist, Mr President, for money laundering or something of that ilk: they have done a lot to stop it but they have been included on this list and it is going to damage Tunisian businesses and send waves of migrants to Europe. What can be more ridiculous? Over the past 10 months the European Investment Bank (EIB) has given 136 loans, worth seven billion, to finance projects in non-EU countries, making trade much easier than throwing away money. At the same time, the European Investment Bank owes Britain GBP 35 billion and refuses to pay this bill in 2019. We want our money back.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: President. –
text: Mr Coburn, I am not able to give you your money back, but you have a blue card.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Coburn, you are always very loud, you come from a very civilised country and I had supposed that you were a very civilised person, especially in this very important institution of the European Union. I think that you should have to apologise because you were using the term ‘idiotic’ when referring to the Junker plan. I don't think it is appropriate in such a room to use these words. As you are leaving the European Union, you shouldn't have to use these words because the future of the United Kingdom, Mr Coburn, will always be linked with European Union. Remember this.

name: President. –
text: That was not a question. It was something else, a comment. But you could answer.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – I think I can manage, I am big enough and ugly enough to manage it. Well, thank you for your question. Well, ‘idiotic’ – perhaps I was being very naughty. Perhaps I shouldn’t have said ‘idiotic’. Perhaps ‘economically illiterate’ might have been better, so I hope you'll excuse me, I should use the word ‘economically illiterate’, but the Juncker plan was economically illiterate, as illiterate as these plans that you're trying to put forward at the moment. Thanks again for your question.

name: Stanisław Żółtek
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Mr President! The European Investment Bank lends huge amounts to exotic states where nothing can be checked. The programs the bank gives loans to have beautiful names: “fighting unemployment,” “climate warming,” “women's equality.” Some of the money is embezzled and loans are not given back, but the European Union returns these losses to the bank. To obfuscate the case, the European Union repays the bank tens of billions of euros in wholesale a year, calling the account a guarantee fund. The bank covers from this fund its losses. To work in a bank like this is a wonderful thing. Today, the European Commission recognised that it too has its people. They also have to live off something and she wants to manage that fund herself.
