That means that if something goes wrong, the Member States have liability here. The United Kingdom has a contingent liability of EUR 36 billion (or EUR 35 point something billion), and that will remain. It is not so that we pay out to the United Kingdom – they have never paid in, and if something goes wrong, they have a contingent liability. So these are the facts. Unfortunately, Mr Coburn has already left, because that additional information would probably have been too much.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, we have been discussing the European Investment Bank for almost three hours, its activities, its consistency with the Union's policies, and I think it is time to conclude. I simply wanted to make a small summary of what the purpose of this report was because what we have tried to do is, of course, to analyze what the European Investment Bank is like, how it is doing its activities, and above all we have put a lot of duties on it for the future, because in the end we ask it to do more for the small and medium-sized enterprises, improve geographical balance in their investments, do more in its climate change policy by modifying it, doing more in equality policy, more in social infrastructure, more transparency, more accountability, more indicators, etc. In the end we have put a number of duties on it for the future, and since these are annual reports, I simply invite the European Investment Bank to implement all these amendments, to continue to work on what has already begun, as we mentioned earlier in the debate. And, well, we'll see each other in a year before we can evaluate once again how these changes are going within the European Investment Bank, and I hope that we will continue to improve the work of the Bank and also the work of the European Union. Because, as we have said in this and in the previous debate, the Bank is ultimately a fundamental tool for implementing the policies we decided in this Chamber. So let's hope we all keep moving on this good road.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 8 February 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. - The issue of financial management of the Guarantee Fund is very important in the context of the European Union's financial interests. The report rightly points out that the financial management of the Guarantee Fund should be taken over by the Commission from the EIB. The Commission has long-term practice in managing similar investments. Management should be carried out in accordance with the highest standards of transparency and democratic accountability. In taking over the management of the Assets of the Guarantee Fund, the Commission should continue to rationalise and consolidate the Fund's asset management activities and further improve its results. The transfer of management should contribute to savings in the general budget of the Union and enable the Commission to provide better and more accurate information on the management and situation of the Guarantee Fund to the European Parliament. In addition, the report should include detailed information on the use of the Fund and on the progress made by the funded projects in the beneficiary countries. This will promote transparency in the EU institutions.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the reduction of spaces for civil society (2017/2529 (RSP)).

name: Monika Panayotova
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the Treaties stress the need for the Union to have an open, transparent and regular dialogue with civil society organisations, and they recognise civil society’s role in the good governance of the European Union. We share the view of the European Parliament on this topic, that a healthy democracy requires an active and well—developed civil society. The active engagement of citizens is the cornerstone of our open and free societies. Only recently, in October 2017, in its conclusions on the application of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights in 2016, the Council stated that civil society organisations serve as a watchdog and play an important role in promoting and implementing fundamental rights on the ground. They are irreplaceable in raising awareness of fundamental rights among rights-holders and in supporting their efforts to exercise and defend their rights. To fulfil their task civil society organisations must be enabled to carry out their work. As for external relations, the Council reaffirmed that civil society organisations are both actors of governance and development actors in their own right. As such, they are key partners for the successful implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the EU Global Strategy. There are many examples of policy fields where civil society is regularly consulted and integrated by the Union in the decision—making process. This is, for example, the case in the work of the European Union High Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance, the EU Forum on the rights of the child, the EU Forum on migration and integration, and many others. Capacity-building of civil society’s national human rights bodies is supported through EU funding in areas such as anti—racism, anti—discrimination, access to justice, rights of the child, women’s rights, the elderly, disability, etc. As for the Council’s work, for several years already there has been a tradition of regular contact and dialogue between the presidencies and civil society. In the programme of the Bulgarian Presidency we have committed to realising a presidency which is open to citizens. Both in the process of preparation and conducting the Presidency, we strongly rely on cooperation with civil society and the non-governmental sector, as their intellectual imagination, expert contribution and creative, innovative approach have a very important added value for us. As recently as December 2017, Council working parties discussed how to ensure and enhance coherence and possible synergies between the internal and external aspects of civil society policies. The Fundamental Rights Agency participated in that debate. The agency is closely cooperating with civil society and has initiated work on a better understanding of the challenges and positive experiences of civil society organisations in the European Union. This work was recently concluded with a report. It stresses that the decision makers need to ensure that the important work of civil society is not undermined through policy and legal changes and funding cuts. The report also contains good practices that are being used to address these challenges. I would like to conclude by stressing that civil society brings forward citizens’ concerns. It represents and supports democracy, human rights, the rule of law, social justice and pluralism. It contributes to the effective and inclusive policies and engages in initiatives to further social inclusion, participatory democracy and governance, both in the European Union and also in third countries. Therefore it is our legal and political responsibility to guarantee good conditions for a strong civil society in our countries and in the Union.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I cannot stress enough the importance the Commission attaches to the existence of a vibrant civil society, and to a regular and transparent engagement with civil society actors – both as allies and as critical minds. As we can see in several States, elections are not the only sufficient proof of a democracy. A strong civil society is heavily needed. The importance of preserving and protecting the civil society space has become more evident in our time, where fundamental rights and values are under high pressure. Indeed, civil society is unfortunately facing pressures in many parts of the EU.  I am aware and deeply concerned by these worrying trends, or – as this debate is called – the shrinking space for civil society. It includes funding cuts, stringent regulatory frameworks, lack of involvement in policymaking, or smear campaigns affecting public perceptions of the credibility and legitimacy of civil society organisations and those that fund them.  We are monitoring such developments at national level, touching upon the role and functions of civil society organisations. We take very seriously actions by public institutions aimed at deliberately shrinking the capacity and position of action of civil society organisations or attempting to control, delegitimise or stigmatise their work.  We will not hesitate to take action when measures are taken in violation of Member States’ obligations under the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, as we have already done in the case of Hungary. In December 2017, the Commission referred Hungary to the Court of Justice concerning its law on foreign-funded NGOs.  We also continue to provide concrete support, including capacity-building and funding, to raise awareness, encourage advocacy and foster the enforcement of fundamental rights, and we are currently mapping gaps and needs to identify how to further empower civil society and other independent human rights actors, such as national human rights institutions. This takes up a specific request from the European Parliament, on the basis of which we are about to launch a feasibility study.  This is also a timely moment for the new ideas to feed ongoing reflections on the future EU Multiannual Financial Framework. We are in contact with civil society partners, with the Council of Europe and with the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights to reflect on how to build on and complement existing research-surveying experiences on how the space for civil society is evolving. All actors have a role to play, be it at national, European or international level, and we are fully committed to playing ours. Keeping our civil society strong, independent and pluralistic requires these joint efforts, and we welcome the continued engagement of the European Parliament on this matter.

name: Roberta Metsola
text: f'isem il-grupp PPE. — IR-rwol tas-soèjetà ivili hu krućjali f'democrasia. Fuq naħa nqisuhom bħala l-kuxjenza tas-soðjetà tagħna, u fuq in-naħa l-oħra jgħassu biex jassiguraw li l-poteri tal-istat jiġu użati b'mod sew, kif għandu jkun, b'responsabilità. Is-sójetà źivili dejjem kienet protagonista fl-iżvilupp in t-tibdil li sar FL-unjoni Ewropea. abet il-bidla in bidlet l-istatus quo. Fil-Polonja in FIR-Rumanija, is-soźjetà źivili wasslet għall-kollass tal-komuniżmu. Fi Franza, is-soèjetà ivili kellha sehem mill-aktar importanti fl-istorja reenti. F'Malta għandna wkoll soèjetà ivili ħajja, organizzazzjonijiet differenti li qed jaħdmu favur il-protezzjoni tal-libertà tal-midja, favur l-ambjent in l-għajta qawwija għall-ġustizzja fost l-oħrajn. Dawn ukoll, bħall-midja indipendenti, jaffajaw glazakli, theddid in intimidazzjoni. Hemm min jista' jqishom bħala xkiel għall-politići, imma r-raġuni għalfejn is-soźjetà źivili teżisti hi proprju biex tixpruna u tniggeż lill-politići. Soźjetà źivili b'saħħitha hi bżonjuża u essenzjali. Mingħajrhom, id-democrasia tkun ifqar. Huma essenzjali biex min hu fil-poter jagħti kont ta' għemilu, jgħid il-verità in jimxi bi standards mill-aktar għolja. Għalhekk meta ma jkunux jistgħu jaħdmu bil-libertà kollha għandna għalxiex nitħassbu, in din hi s-sitwazzjoni. Jinsabu taħt theddida kif wera r-rapport tal-aġenzia Tad-drittijiet Fundamentali. Irridu nindirizzaw l-isfidi li qed iħabbtu wiðhom magħhom. Ma nistgħux inkunu siekta quddiem sitwazzjonijiet li qatt ma għandhom ikunu aċettabbli. Ma nistgħux inkunu siekta meta naraw li l-aċess għall-fondi għal ertu organizzazzjonijiet qiegħed jiġi fgat minħabba li jingħata lill-oħrajn li jappoġġġjaw lill-gvern. Ma nistgħux nibqgħu fil-muta quddiem it-theddid b'azzjonijiet legali, b'intimidazzjoni, bi vjolenza, b'burokrazija biex jaqtgħulhom qalbhom jew inkella b'liġijiet li jimminaw il-ħidma taghom. L-Istati membri jridu joqogħdu għall-istandards internazzjonali li jippromwovu l-parteźipazzjoni fl-iżvilupp tal-politics. Dawn huma l-prinðipji... (Il-President waqqaf lill-kelliema minħabba raġunijiet ta' ħin allokat.)

name: Péter Niedermüller
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, without a strong and well-functioning civil society, there is no democracy. NGOs are very effective in helping to tackle social problems while giving citizens the opportunity to act politically. Recently, we have witnessed the brutal efforts of governments in illiberal democracies, especially in Hungary and Poland, to prevent NGOs from functioning. Yes, they are branded as agents of foreign powers, imposing special taxes on them to make their work financially impossible, they adopt laws targeted against them, and even try to intimidate them by using secret service tools. I am convinced that the European Parliament has a fundamental political and moral responsibility to speak strongly against this dictatorial political practice. Anyone who turns against NGOs, who tries to obstruct their work consciously opposes the European Union's fundamental values, democracy and the rule of law. But not only words are needed, but also deeds. Therefore, I propose that the European Union immediately create a democracy fund to which NGOs operating in the Member States of the European Union can apply directly for financial support, not only to projects, but also to ensure the conditions for long-term operation. If we do not support NGOs, the rule of law and democracy itself will be at risk.

name: Marek Jurek
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Without an active society, no civic spirit, no social responsibility there is no democracy. All the more so because we live in a time when it is so easy to fabricate in the media the will of the general, when virtual reality so easily replaces active, authentically shaped grassroots public opinion. And we have to do whatever it takes to protect our democracies to protect our freedom from the rule of money. We know this very well in Central Europe. Anyway, I wonder that a colleague who comes from a close country does not understand that today the main task of our societies is to rebuild an active society after a time when communism not only restricted political freedom but discouraged people from any activity. Indeed, today civil equality is hugely compromised by money and it is very good that governments in central Europe are taking action to ensure the real equality of organisations operating in the public forum.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, today we are finally discussing the shrinking space for civil society, but what we are really discussing is the shrinking space for democracy because, despite the passionate plea of my colleague just now for civil society, we also know that his government party is trying to shut up NGOs that do not echo the views of the government. This is actually what presents a threat to democracy: it is not NGOs that we disagree with but actually silencing parties that we disagree with. The Commissioner rightly said that democracy is not about elections, but democracy is about checks and balances. That means that we should even have the courage to fund our own opposition if necessary. This is not just about shrinking space for civil society but also for media, opposition parties and so on. I have a couple of questions for the Commission and the Council. First of all, there have been proposals, as mentioned by colleague Niedermüller, and I know Mr Boni is also arguing for it, that setting up EU funding for not just European NGOs but also local NGOs – what initiatives will the Commission take? Secondly, regarding the litigation fund that was adopted in the budget by Parliament last year, I would really like to hear the Commissioner confirm that it will be set up quickly and that it will actually be a litigation fund and not watered down to a kind of general NGO fund, as some people would like. Thirdly, you started infringement procedures against Hungary for laws that unduly restrict the space for civil society, but we know that the same problems exist in Poland and that in other countries such laws are being considered. Will you also start infringement procedures against Poland? To the Council: I very much welcome your words but they are of a very general nature. I would like to hear what the Council will actually do to ensure – and I am coming to a conclusion – to put this on the agenda and discuss it. Will you put on the agenda the situation in Hungary, the situation in Poland, the situation in Romania? (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by raising a blue card. — To face charges easily, document them a little harder. That's why I would ask for this documentation. What did you mean, specifically about the limitations of NGO activities in Poland and Hungary?

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – That is a bit difficult in 30 seconds because of the wide range of measures that have been taken to harass and intimidate NGOs, restrict their freedom of manoeuvre and registration requirements: the government, for example, giving priority to events organised by organisations that are friendly to the government at the expense of other NGOs. Need I go on? I think it is clear to everybody. I understand there are organisations – even organisations funded by this House – that are supportive of your views, and I very much disagree with them, but I prefer to argue with them and to debate with them rather than cutting off their funds as you are doing.

name: Tania González Peñas
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, social movements, activists and organisations fighting for social justice are facing an increasingly repressive environment in many European countries. We are seeing it every day in Hungary, in Poland, in Bulgaria or in France. In Spain, the Government of the Popular Party approved in 2015 the gag law, a law that violates the rights of peaceful assembly and protest, a law that scares us all citizens who defend a plural system. Can you imagine a country where tweiters are tried and imprisoned by the National High Court? It's not Saudi Arabia. This is Spain, and Amnesty International has been denouncing it for a long time. Political participation and freedom of expression are signs of democratic health. That civil society can intervene in political decisions through its proposals, but also through protest, builds a political system of greater democratic quality. Because in democracy the more voices are heard, the better the decisions are.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, dear Colleagues, four years ago there were astonishing images in the Hungarian and international press. NGO offices occupied by police raids, led civilian leaders in an EU Member State. The Hungarian government's war against NGOs has been going on for four years. It continued last year with the civil law, which is now debated at the European Court of Justice. But the Hungarian government is unable to stop. Just recently, a new bill has been tabled which is no longer trying to preserve the appearance of rule of law standards and raises the stigma of NGOs, legal and practical retaliation against NGOs to an even higher level. The intimidation of the civil sector is, of course, not a Hungarian invention. This is what we see from Budapest to Moscow and from Ankara to Warsaw. But it's not just a Hungarian matter. Europe will be disintegrated if we cannot prevent autocratic efforts and systematic threats to repress NGOs within the borders of the European Union.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: — Democracy, it's not just the electoral act itself, it's more than that. It's citizens' awareness and rules that protect their rights. Populisms in today's world in the name of election results undermine the foundations of democracy and de facto build a new authoritarianism, backed by an electoral majority blindly going behind the chiefs. There is no democracy today without civil society. In many countries, parties don't so much serve the state as they appropriate it. This destroys the democratic nature of the state and restricts civic organizations' access to resources for the development of a living democracy. And the day-to-day practice of democracy is central to its permanence. It gives it a lifespan. Activities of citizens, their participation in debates, consultations, protests, decision-making processes are essential everywhere: in small towns and villages, in metropolises and regions. A key actor of living democracy is civil society. However, it needs freedom to function. The independence of the business must be guaranteed by the availability of financial resources, unlimited by governments, as seen in the legal changes of recent days in Hungary, and this threatens Poland too. A way must therefore be found for citizens' organisations working locally to support European. We need a European Instrument of Values. A separate line in the European budget is necessary for such purposes. This decision requires the cooperation of Parliament, the Commission and the Council to place these objectives and actions in the new Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President! An important basis for good coexistence is that the state, the economy and society are in a balanced relationship. If the social element is missing, then there is a risk that there will be no voluntary commitment of individuals. In the times of communism we were able to observe this. The state, which was dominated by the party, stifled the commitment of free people until the time resistance formed. Against this background, a civil society movement emerged that eventually turned to a peaceful velvet revolution — in Hungary, the Czech Republic, Poland and many other countries. For a long time this connection was clear, NGOs were considered as an important pillar of the new order. Tadeusz Mazowiecki once expressed this in such a way that everything depends on the strength of society — its spiritual values, its wisdom in asserting human rights and the rights of the nation. It is worrying that the social space for NGOs is now systematically and with great pressure in these countries. This means a return to a past that we all do not want, and that is why we must tackle all relevant trends with determination.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, active civil society is vital to the functioning of any healthy democracy. NGOs, human rights organisations, critical media and trade unions all work to hold governments to account, to protect people’s rights and to protect transparency.  But we are increasingly witnessing a shrinking civil society – not just in third countries, but within the EU itself. I was an eyewitness to the police brutality that was meted out on Catalans as they attempted to exercise their right to vote, not to mention the arrest and imprisonment of civil activists or the shutting—down of their websites. Other EU countries are using government—funded smear campaigns and restrictive legislation to shut down organisations campaigning for fundamental rights. In my own country, peaceful protesters were consistently demonised by the Government and, in one case, criminalised for their actions. Civil society needs our protection. We cannot tolerate its shrinkage within the EU, but nor can we continue to provide funding to countries with oppressive regimes that shut down any form of civil society just because they are carrying out the dirty work of Fortress Europe.

name: Асим Адемов (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, the benefits of civil organisation are undoubtedly many and varied, and it is therefore important to support and promote organisations that advocate fundamental human rights. Civil society organisations in some countries, which promote and defend the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights to equality and tolerance, are increasingly difficult to gain publicity and form legal structures. These problems also highlights the latest report of the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights in January 2018. Just as human rights need civil society, civil society needs human rights protection in order to fulfil its mission. The challenges faced by NGOs in some of the countries of the European Union are related to the narrowing of the area for dialogue between civil society and authorities. This problem should be voicedness. The European Union must support and protect civil society within the Union, but also in candidate third countries. We must support these countries to stabilise their laws and put the rule of fundamental human rights on the agenda, which facilitate the formation and functioning of civil structures. Democracy is the heart of our society. Let us not hurt her by suppressing the voice of the citizens! The problems of our complex society must be put on display and solutions in the hands of voters.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: Mr President, this morning in this Parliament we have been discussing how to improve the electoral processes so that citizens' consent is better expressed through the election of their representatives, and we have also strengthened the democratic link between these representatives and those exercising the government. A few weeks ago, in this Parliament we adopted a report on reducing the space of civil society in some of the countries with which we cooperate in development policies. But we have that same problem within the Union. The truth is that democracy is electoral processes, it is strengthening the link between elected and rulers, but it is also vitality of civil society, which feeds these processes of political participation. Democracy is participation, it is deliberation, and we need a vibrant civil society that activates both social mechanisms.

name: Francis Zammit Dimech (PPE).
text: — Jidher li qed naqblu hawnhekk li s-sowherejetà envelavili gandha verament rwol krujali f'pajjiż democratiku galiex il-vuihei tagЂha fil-fatt hija l-vushort-term i li hi strumentali biex ikollok so- jetà b'sathe ikuitha u biex n hemm l-iskrutinju fuq il-gvernijiet u l-awtoritajiet, u anki l-operat tag-hom. Galhekk f'dan is-sens — u anki aennat qabli l-kollega Roberta Metsola — huwa rumażin li jkollok FL-Istat Membri, anki f'Malta, fejn l-appelli tas-so- jetà projekivili jiu injorati, inkluż appelli rigward sistema ta' governanza serja, u mhux biss jito u injorati imma jkollok każijiet fejn ikollok anki tentattiv biex dawn jito u skreditati b'mod sistematiku, anki permezz he' tattii qarrieqa. Is-sothe jetà entailed ivili jrid ikollha d-dritt tal-opinjoni, dritt anki li tirievi l-informazzjon kollha, id-dritt li hi tkun verament parte-ipi f'dak kollu li jkun qiegthe ed isir, u allura ma jista' jkun qatt ato altat li nlis-so- jetà attenuate ivili tiaui soxentaetta gtinal tatti- i anki li jistgu jitqiesu biss bЂ‹вЂ‹a tattiЂ‹ta' intimidazzjon. Irrid niepari u din l-opportunità, galhekk, biex minn hawnhekk insellem lis-sojetà ivili bЂala l-vuta' min m'gЂandux forma othe ta' rappreżentazzjoni. Insellem b'mod partikulari l-idma li, pereżempju f'Malta, qed titwettaq Mis-Civil Society Network, preto iżament biex iressqu 'l quddiem ilmenti li jirriflettu dak li qed ithe oss il-poplu Malti b'mod to the occuenerali.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a state which restricts the political area in which civil society organisations operate is not a rule of law. A state that does not recognise this force alive within its society, which seeks to limit its field of action, imposes constraints and burdens of a financial nature and that represses activists deserves our most absolute condemnation. The behaviour of some states is reprehensible, and here I speak of Hungary, which with devious laws criminalise solidarity with refugees, migrants and marginalised groups, hitting the heart of the action carried out from civil society in providing those social services that the state in question is incapable of providing. That is why I support the creation of a European Democracy Fund. We are talking about rights and democracy, good governance and transparency. I therefore call on the Commission to make more of its voice heard in defending these principles and to take immediate action on restrictive laws and practices against organisations of civil society and its members well before their adoption.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I have listened carefully to your performance and it is good that the Commission is paying attention to the development of civil society in the States of the European Union. No one here doubts that civil society is extremely important to the functioning of the democratic rule of law. If it is strong, then it can hinder the strengthening of extremist tendencies, extremist views and contributes to the fact that people are resistant to national and extreme tendencies, that is, is in our self-interest in having strong civil societies in the event that extremist national anti-European political movements begin to strengthen significantly in some countries. I see a very important role in this, if we are entertaining here on the floor of a political body like the European Parliament. On the other hand, I am clearly saying that under the principle of subsidiarity, the European Union as such should not interfere with the functioning of civil societies in individual Member States. Rather, we should approach this positively and possibly financially and otherwise support civil movements and other civil society institutions in those countries where, for example, they are not so fully unfolded. And I feel, in the former post-communist states, as well as in my country or in the Visegrad countries, the need for the European Union to support those civil movements that disseminate information on the European integration, information about European identity, about what recently is often fashionable to deny and relativise.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: Mr President, in the different languages of the Union we are here recalling a principle which cannot be underestimated, and that is that democracy — of course! — requires a vote, but it is not just about voting, let alone vote anything, at any time and in any way. Democracy required the protection of the rights of minorities and the role of the opposition and civil society itself, while respecting the individual rights of natural and legal persons. And we have the right to suspect a government, whatever it is in the European Union, when it legislates to repress or persecute its political adversaries with laws that become known even by the name of the person you have identified as your adversary, or even worse, as your enemy. This is the case of Hungary with the law which reduces the room for manoeuvre of non-governmental organizations and which is part of a xenophobic and ultra-nationalist strategy to identify immigration with national security. That is why the European Union, the Commission have every right and duty to react to these initiatives and to those laws and to forcefully curb that authoritarian drift.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, shrinking space is a trend that can be observed globally. For instance, in Israel, the situation of human rights defenders and civil society organisations has severely deteriorated in the past few years. In addition to systematic human rights violations by the State of Israel in the occupied Palestinian territory, the Israeli Government has now launched a violent crackdown against civil society.  The recent ban on BDS-supporting organisations from entering the country is an additional attack on freedom of expression in Israel, and although I am not in favour of a total boycott of everything Israeli, I find it very important that the organisations that do support it are able to say it. I have been personally targeted by some of these right-wing attacks on freedom of expression. NGO Monitor has targeted me and my staff because I called them out and exposed their far-right anti-human rights agenda. Under the pretence of transparency concerns, they have managed successfully to attack organisations that work to end human rights violations in the occupied territories – and that includes representatives from Breaking the Silence, the organisation that gathers testimonies from ex—IDF soldiers against the occupation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, civil society does indeed contribute to deepening democracy. It contributes to the ability of citizens to gain an even stronger voice. And we have civil society organisations, such as trade unions, which really play a very important role. On the other hand, we must ensure that civil society, especially non-governmental organisations, is not transformed into lobbying groups. This is very important and we must take this into account. Finally, I must mention that, in Greece, non-governmental organisations in relation to the issues of appeals have taken a great deal of money and there is literally a party. Opacity has prevailed, Mrs Jourová. They have taken a lot of money and while this money should have been given to support refugees in many areas, such as Lesvos, the results are lamentable, because there is a party. I have said this in this Chamber: there must be control of funding and OLAF must come into play to check where the money is going. They do not go for the refugees, when they have been given for them.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, this has been a very interesting debate and also very encouraging for me, because we have to focus more on the support of civil society and NGOs, not only in the Member States, which have been mentioned here, but in the whole of Europe. In real democracy, people are encouraged and invited to participate in decision-making. A healthy, self-confident society welcomes people to have a say. In a fake democracy, people are invited once every four years to come and cast their vote, to elect, and to be silent in between. This is the real threat to democracy, and I think that it is our role to – fight against it is maybe too activist – but to be very vigilant, to monitor the situation and to give support where it is needed, because silencing and shrinking civil society is one of the parameters of populism. Populists hate civil society because they love a strong state and, unfortunately, in part of our society there is now the demand for an ever-stronger state, because there are people who promise they will do everything to facilitate things for you, to guarantee you a happy life. They want everything but critical thinking from the people. Unfortunately, online and digital development is not helping. We should analyse this phenomenon more, and what it means, because when I speak to the courageous people of the NGOs, they say hate speech online is something which is censoring and silencing them. It is not only journalists, but also a large number of people working for NGOs, publicly-known people, who are affected by hatred online. It is a factor which we should think about and maybe do something about. There is also the factor of societal changes, which we see in relation to the development of the digital area. I have nothing against digital development. There are many positive things in this respect, but what we see is that the populists like this sphere because they have an easily manipulated crowd. Again, this is something which goes directly against civil society, and I think that we should analyse the reasons for shrinking space for civil society, react appropriately and find remedies. I do not think that the only possible remedy we have in hand is infringement against a state where we see that the law is deviating from how the legislation should look. Of course, we are monitoring the situation in Hungary and in Poland. Today we discussed Romania. We are monitoring some other Member States where there are worrying developments – not only in the east of the EU; I must make this clear. Maybe the approach of the Commission might be seen as pretty legalistic, that we wait for a bad law to be enacted before we act, but we have to be very careful here and maybe trust more the people in Europe that there are enough democrats who will not be silenced so easily. We have to be careful and we have to support civil society by means other than infringements directed against the laws in some Member States. How can we do it? The fund – I am very much for creating such a fund. We are now launching a feasibility study where we want to map the various funding instruments in the Member States, to fill the gap and not to duplicate or do something which would not be systemic and transparent enough. I also have an expert meeting, and I invite those who are interested in this issue to participate in this debate, because I think that it should be our common work. Let me conclude by speaking about big money, which is also now in debates such as the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) after 2020. Here we have a great chance to open better and easier possibilities for the NGOs to get funding. I am not so sure about opening the special chapter in MFF which was, I think, the proposal of Mr Boni. I think that we should deliberately and thoroughly analyse the possibility of opening the space for NGOs, who in many cases substitute the tasks of the state while being miserably paid. We have to change this situation. We see one year of financing, so the NGOs invest 90% of their initiatives in collecting or seeking money, instead of doing the core thing. We also have to look into the rules for financing. We will hear more and more about the need to simplify the rules for the new MFF. Whenever I hear politicians, including myself, speaking about simplification, I start to fear we will complicate it more. Now we have to manage to simplify the rules, especially for the small-scale projects, not to allow again a system where you have to invest as much effort into getting EUR 100 000 as EUR 5 million. The system and the rules must be proportionate. EU funding is my hobby. I could continue, but I will spare you. Thank you very much, and let us work together to stop the shrinking of space for civil society. It is vital for Europe and it is vital for all democrats in Europe.

name: Monika Panayotova
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, first of all I would like to respond to the question from Ms Sophia in ‘t Veld. I would like to underline that I speak on behalf of the Presidency of the Council and therefore in the name of all its members, and for this reason it is not for the Presidency to comment on particular subjects related to the Member States. But what I can underline is that the Council shares the view of the European Parliament that civil society plays a vital role in our societies, and – as you said – it is an essential part of the system of the checks and balances. In 2017, the Council encouraged the Member States to promote EU citizenship and the values and rights attached to it, involving as far as possible civil society – it was underlined. Secondly, I would like also to conclude by saying that an empowered and resilient civil society in all its diversity is a crucial component and voice, as mentioned by some of you, of any democracy. Ensuring that civil society has sufficient space to operate in support and protection of fundamental rights in the European Union remains a common endeavour for the European institutions and the Member States.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. — (PT) In many parts of the globe - and not only in developing countries - we are today witnessing authoritarian phenomena against democracy and human rights, which are often manifested by reducing the space for civil society to intervene. Certain groups such as women, young people, LGBTI people and minorities, Roma communities, indigenous peoples, people with disabilities, the press or human rights defenders are preferential targets of repression, limitation of rights to freedom of expression, assembly and association. The EU and its Member States have a duty to lead by example by scrupulously respecting the fundamental rights of civil society and tackling any negative trends in this area. But the EU also has a duty to act when these fundamental rights are not respected in third countries with which it maintains trade or diplomatic relations, using its foreign policy instruments, such as human rights and development instruments and agreements bilateral with third countries.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — NGOs are highly respected in Hungary, since these voluntary organisations of citizens are important components of socio-cultural life, which, through their activities, contribute to the effective management of social problems and community needs to satisfy you. In Hungary, more than 60,000 NGOs operate without problems, but only less than 1 percent of organisations strive for political influence. They do this without having any democratic accountability, so the outrage of these organisations that are telecaming Europe can only be interpreted as a dream problem. NGOs play an important role in public opinion formation, and therefore there is a fundamental public interest in making society as a whole clear of the interests they represent. Transparency of NGOs supported from abroad is an extremely important rule of law that applies to everyone. Transparency NGOs can be expected to meet the transparency requirement for themselves and publish their financial support. This is a completely legitimate expectation of NGOs and is not unprecedented in the world. The letters of complaint that flooded the European Parliament have been distributed by the same few NGOs supporting migration that have been openly or covertly attacking the Hungarian government for years.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. – Regarding the fact that independent and well-functioning civil society is a fundament of the country’s democracy, stability and prosperity and one of the most important actors in overseeing the situation of human rights, social justice and citizens participation, a spread of limitations and closing down of civil society in developing democracies across the world is a deeply worrying phenomenon. In order to fight this negative trend, the representatives of the EU institutions and Member States should give a strong signal and support the threaten human rights defenders and NGOs, by holding meetings, publically expressing support to individual cases or by providing consultations and guidance in their activities. At the same time the EU actors should be more vocal in defending the international legal instruments promoting democracy and human rights on the level of international organisations, such as United Nations, African Union and others. Furthermore, I believe a clearer structure should be given to the framework of cooperation with civil societies in problematic regions consisting of regular in-depth consultations, establishing an alert system notifying about introducing restrictive pieces of legislation and continuously monitoring potential threats to NGOs and human rights defenders.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — Civil society, i.e. the activity and participation of citizens in policymaking, represent the basis of democracy, and the pressure over it is constantly increasing within and outside the EU borders. Particularly worrying is the spread of the trend of narrowing the space of civil society and among developed democratic states. Civil society organizations, as well as individual activists dealing with social, environmental and other important issues, encounter a multitude of obstacles - from legal and administrative, to intimidation, detention and arrest. Such a negative trend did not bypass Croatia, where civil society organizations restrict freedom of speech and action through political pressures and cutting funds. Civil society is extremely important for Europe, so solving this problem requires its action - providing strong legal protection for the CSOs, as well as creating concrete political mechanisms and instruments with the aim of enabling those who fight for human rights and democratisation the conditions for work.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on  – the question for oral answer (O-000102/2017) by Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz, Barbara Matera, Dubravka Šuica, Elissavet Vozemberg-Vrionidi, Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio and Rosa Estaràs Ferragut, on behalf of the PPE Group, Iratxe García Pérez and Soraya Post, on behalf of the S&D Group, Arne Gericke, on behalf of the ECR Group, Malin Björk, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group, Terry Reintke and Ernest Urtasun Domènech, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group, Angelika Mlinar, Izaskun Bilbao Barandica and Hilde Vautmans, on behalf of the ALDE Group, to the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy: Situation of women human rights defenders and their support by the EU (2017/2531(RSP)) (B8-0004/2018),  – the question for oral answer (O-000101/2017) by Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz, Barbara Matera, Dubravka Šuica, Elissavet Vozemberg-Vrionidi, Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio and Rosa Estaràs Ferragut, on behalf of the PPE Group, Iratxe García Pérez and Soraya Post, on behalf of the S&D Group, Malin Björk, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group, Arne Gericke, on behalf of the ECR Group, Terry Reintke and Ernest Urtasun Domènech, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group, Angelika Mlinar, Izaskun Bilbao Barandica and Hilde Vautmans, on behalf of the ALDE Group, to the Commission: Situation of women human rights defenders and their support by the EU (2017/2531(RSP)) (B8-0003/2018).

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz
text: author. — Women defenders of human rights, especially those operating in remote, poorer, developing areas of the world experience numerous obstacles to their work. Their position and legitimacy to engage in human rights is disputed. The importance of their work, their positions, and their themselves are diminishes. They are attacked not only verbally, but physically. Even members of their families and their children are being attacked. Their activities are seen as being aimed at family and in religion. Sometimes they are accused of spying for the benefit of the West. Despite their officially held positions, human rights defenders experience a lack of confidence, including from representatives of state authorities. They can't always count on police protection, protection from the state. On the contrary — because their activities are perceived as anti-system, and therefore hostile to the state, even on this side may come an attack. We should see the difficult role of human rights defenders and understand the scale and type of difficulty they face in soliciting human rights, including women's rights, and understand that part of these difficulties arise from the fact that they are women. Supporting human rights defenders has long been an element, one of the priorities, of the European Union's external policy. This is especially needed today when, as we have presented in many reports and just in the debate, the space in which civil society can operate, the space of freedom and pluralism, professed values and religions. I would like to ask, what mechanisms and practices do the European Commission apply to support the human rights defender, and what role do the European Union delegation play in this? What is the Commission doing to empower women's human rights defenders and increase the value and recognition of their positions? Finally, does these actions aimed at supporting female human rights defenders take sufficient account of the local cultural context?

name: Liliana Rodrigues
text: Author. — (PT) Mr President, Commissioner, in 2016 at least 281 activists were killed. So many others are reported missing. The risks faced by activists are increasing and the space for human rights defenders to carry out their activities has been decreasing worldwide. Freedom in the world reached the worst level in 2017 in 12 years. We know that freedom and democracy are in fact under threat. More dangerous is activism when it is practiced by women. Women who are dedicated to defending others face increased problems. There are activists who have been illegally detained, activists who are raped, defamed, even attacked with acid, women of causes who see their children, family members and friends threatened. The European Union has a policy on gender equality and the defence of human rights in its external relations. Its delegations carry out activities and we finance programmes for this purpose. How many women human rights defenders are supported by the European Union? What cross-data assessment is there on the impact these measures have on countries receiving European funding? What is the correspondence between the European Union's commitments to support human rights defenders and what is really happening on the ground? Are there concrete results? What monitoring and evaluation mechanisms are in place and are being used to ensure that all these objectives are met? How are we ensuring that all delegations effectively comply with the guidelines on this matter? Who protects those who are dedicated to protecting others? Plus, how are we supposed to protect them?

name: Arne Gericke
text: author. — Mr President, Commissioner Jourová. Everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion. It has the freedom to profess its religion or belief, individually or together with others, in public or private, through worship, instruction, customs and rites. This is what is set out in Article 10 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. I would now like to focus precisely on these sore spots, on many human rights activists around the world who stand for and are persecuted for the fundamental right of religious freedom: missionaries, nuns and religious, women of priests, believers. All of them fight millions of times worldwide for religious freedom and the right to live the faith. I would like to ask you, Commissioner: do we also have these women, the persecuted Christians, who incidentally just in the monthly focus of the ecclesiastical aid organisation Open Doors, in mind when we talk about human rights activists today? I think we should keep an eye on it, especially because their number is so shockingly high. 200 million Christians are persecuted worldwide because they are fighting for the human right to faith. More than half of them are women. Let us keep an eye on them when we talk today about more support for human rights activists.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: author. — Mr President, here I bring you some of the cases of women I want to pay tribute: Berta Cáceres, indigenous leader killed in Honduras in March 2016; Aminatu Haidar, a proSaharawi activist who was on hunger strike for thirty-two days; Ahed Tamimi, symbol of Palestinian resistance, again detained by Israel; and Milagro Sala, Argentine activist arbitrarily detained for political reasons. Women. Examples of the struggle of hundreds of women around the world who are at the foot of conflict and who, in addition to being murdered, tortured, abused and even raped, are often invisible. The Commission, the European External Action Service and the States have an obligation under the Treaties, Commissioner. That obligation must lead the European Union to strengthen its role as a promoter of human rights around the world, protecting human rights defenders, especially women, but not at any cost. Financing human rights defenders does not mean using these funds as another tool to overthrow governments that are not aligned with the Union's commercial interests. We have also seen it here in many resolutions against countries that were imposed sanctions while others have been ignored and left out of the political agenda. I therefore ask him what are you doing to protect all and all human rights activists and, more importantly, Commissioner, what criteria are there for funding NGOs and activists? How are these funds mobilized? With regard to the EUR 1.3 billion allocated to the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, who are the recipients of such aid? We need a foreign policy that promotes human rights and be world leaders. But here, more than ever, we need transparency, figures, data and know what is being done and if it is is doing on fair and non-opportunistic criteria.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: author. — Mr President, Commissioner, around the world we see a worrying increase in violence and political repression against human rights defenders, activists and civil society organisations. And the situation is even more worrying when we talk about women human rights defenders, because they must also face multiple risks added by being women: they must face rape, sexual violence, defamation and slander campaigns, acid attacks, threats and harm to their families. Lolita Chavez, a finalist for the Sakharov Prize in this Parliament, has been facing this discrimination and violence for years. Last week we received news about the possible issuance of a warrant for the arrest of Lolita by the Guatemalan prosecutor's office. I think today is a day to call for the European institutions to stand firm with Guatemala about the need to protect and defend Lolita. I would also like to remember, for example, fighters like Berta Cáceres, murdered in the early hours of March 3, 2016. I think that a case like Berta makes clear the limitations of existing strategies for protecting activists and their organisations and the urgency of rethinking our approach as European institutions for better protection from the risks and violence faced by thousands of women working for justice and equality . I would therefore like to point out that the European Union's guidelines in this area recognize the importance of applying the gender perspective in this issue, but, however, we do not have data on how the specific challenges faced by women defenders are taken into account when implementing, for example, programming of the different funds available. Therefore, today we would like the Commissioner to be able to clarify how these specific needs of women human rights defenders are taken into account. in the field of the action of the European External Action Service and in the area of the use of such funds.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: author. — Mr President, Commissioner, I would also like to look at this initiative as my colleagues have done. And in this case, they are those of Lolita Chávez, threatened with death in Guatemala, persecuted and with a new arrest warrant, prosecuted for defending indigenous communities and their natural environment in Guatemala. Founder of the K'iche' Peoples' Council, she welcomed a programme for the temporary protection of human rights defenders of the Basque Government, and became, during the eight months she resided in the Basque Country, a reference and inspiration, in the end of being a finalist of the Sakharov Prize. A few weeks ago, he received the Ignacio Ellacuría Award for cooperation in the Basque Country. Before leaving Lolita remembered that, without the support received, she would now be underground. “I was not born to be killed, I was born to remain alive and I call on all peoples to weave bonds of mutual solidarity.” This message, first, certifies that these types of protection programmes are useful, that it provides, resolves, but it also calls on us because it encourages us to better organize, coordinate and provide more means to the solidarity we owe to those who play their lives around the world in order to defend fundamental rights. When, moreover, they are women, when they overcome stereotypes and cultural patterns to come to the fore and become leaders of a community, we have a triple obligation because they are more at risk, because they are more difficult and because in many countries women are the great hope. That is the point of the questions we are presenting today, Commissioner. What would we be able to do if we coordinate all available wills and resources, if we add them, if we are able to generate synergy that makes today's efforts much more effective? Do you think that new, more comprehensive initiatives and programmes would be generated? Are we aware of the special situation of women and the double difficulties they face in order to lead these human rights movements? There is a lot of knowledge available, many wills to add, and a good subject for the Union to deepen its vocation as an agent of peace and defender of freedoms in the world.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, support for women defenders of human rights is a priority for our external action on human rights. Human rights defenders, both men and women, are our natural and indispensable allies in the promotion of human rights and democracy. We know that many of them are constantly risking their life and their freedom, but women defenders are suffering very specific threats and obstacles on account of their gender as much as their fight for human rights. Yet women defenders play an increasingly prominent role in many partner countries. They are, of course, particularly active in advocating for progress on gender equality. However, it is important to recall that women defenders are not working exclusively on gender equality. They also make an essential contribution in promoting human rights and fundamental freedoms for all. Women defenders are targeted, in particular, when they challenge traditional patterns and perceptions of gender roles and other social stereotypes. We have seen attacks against women defenders working on sexual and reproductive health and rights, promoting gender equality in schools or advocating for the rights of women victims of sexual and gender-based violence, including domestic violence, and the most harmful practices. Our external action has always focused strongly on the protection of women’s rights and of women defenders. Let me just mention, inter alia, the Foreign Affairs Council conclusions of June 2014. They clearly identify women defenders of human rights as a priority and confirm the EU’s commitment to improving its support. The commitment is turning into practice on a daily basis and, in recent times, we have stepped up our engagement in order to react to growing threats against women defenders. I would like to mention, in particular, our mechanism to protect defenders. This is a unique mechanism that can be used to provide targeted assistance to human rights defenders. In 2017, more than 200 women defenders were supported by this mechanism. Our support measures include not only funding to cover attorney fees and physical protection but also, in the most serious cases, temporary relocation to a safer destination. Another example of such targeted financial support is the Emergency Grants Fund for human rights defenders at risk, provided by the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights. Our contacts with human rights defenders on the ground have also become more constant. The embassies of EU Member States and EU delegations are at the forefront of this work. Staff in EU delegations around the world regularly meet with women defenders and consult with them both on human rights and on the conditions of their daily work. Furthermore, our bilateral dialogues with partner countries are a powerful tool for raising women’s rights issues and for exchanges on individual cases involving women defenders of human rights. The EU strongly encourages governments to engage with women defenders and ensure their active, free and meaningful participation. Gender equality and women’s empowerment, including support for women defenders, are identified among the main priorities in the EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy. The plan recognises and supports the critical role of human rights defenders and women’s organisations in relation to achieving fair and inclusive societies. When women, including young women, are empowered the benefits are perceived by their entire community. When they have access to good education and good jobs, social and economic inequality is easier to overcome. When women are recognised as full and equal citizens the whole society is more stable and democracies get stronger. Our work for women and women defenders is for them and it is for all of us, women and men alike.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: for the PPE Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, when it comes to human rights advocates, men and women deserve our support. The gender gap is none when it relates to their bravery, effort or suffering to which they are often subjected. I want to talk about women defending human rights because they are naturally more physically and mentally vulnerable. And they're also more sensitive to some topics. Not coincidentally do we know Pakistan's first Nobel laureate, who was young Malala in 2014, who nearly lost her life defending, at the age of 15, girls' right to education. In education, she saw the possibility of defending against radical ideas. In 2013, it was the European Parliament that awarded her the Sakharov Prize. Although we don't need to look for women activists and human rights campaigners only in third countries, after all, it is much more serious problems that women outside the EU solve. I would cite Saudi Arabia as a successful example of their struggle. Thanks to the efforts of women here, there is a softening of laws, such as in guardianship. Women, when they go to see a doctor, no longer need to ask for their husband's entourage and male consent. Even from this June, women will be able to drive themselves. They fought it out on their own. I see the challenge towards civil society as essential. The latter may also be instrumental in monitoring and supporting specific examples of human rights advocates. Mr President, let me mention one human rights advocate that we must not leave out, and that is Mother Teresa. She didn't talk about human rights, but she sacrificed her whole life to them.

name: Pina Picierno
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when defending human rights we do so, it has been said, always in very risky conditions. When women do it, for the simple fact of being a woman, as has been said, this fact greatly increases the risk factor. Then the institutions, European policy, must continue to increase the support they already give, it has been said, in the context of external human rights policy, particularly now, because now we We are about to negotiate the new Multiannual Financial Framework. But I think that it is even more necessary to pay the utmost attention when talking about women, as we are saying, because women continue to suffer further threats, they continue to suffer further humiliations to even get to physical attacks, rapes, precisely because they symbolize, if you think about it for a moment, everything that oppressor dictators do not want. They represent independence, freedom, autonomy, and these women are for real in every corner of our planet. From Guatemala, where Maria Magdalena Cuc Choc Choc was arrested a few days ago, to Mexico, where Graciela Rodríguez deals with searching for missing persons, up to Asia, Africa and even in Europe. In short, colleagues, Commissioners, we can and should do more to protect these women and to protect human rights activists.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, the European Parliament is fighting a real struggle to support activists; those who defend human rights around the world. We have discussed these issues many times and have adopted resolutions. From that point on, it is obvious that women who are fighting for human rights must have the support of the European Union, precisely because they are much more vulnerable. First of all, stereotypes in the family itself often do not allow women to show their leadership role. At the same time, we have attacks on women fighting for human rights, rape and defamation of sexual content. Also, in some religions, especially in Muslim countries, women have very limited rights. So we really need important policies to support women who are fighting for human rights.

name: Eleonora Forenza
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank my colleagues for this oral question which I felt the need and I think it is useful that Parliament discusses. I personally committed myself to the issue of recognising women's rights as human rights in the reports in which I was rapporteur, in the report on human rights as women's rights in treaties of trade and also women's rights in international trade. I think that the discussion we are having today lacks an important piece, which is the denial of human rights and women's rights, the imprisonment to which many activists are forced, what is happening in Afrin: the denial of human rights supported by many activists by Erdogan's regime. I think the EU should do more on this.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the Union's external human rights policy is a support for many human rights defenders. We all know the challenges faced in some countries by those who take action in order to protect human rights and, where appropriate, against the excesses of the authorities. There are countries where rights defenders play with their lives when they identify violations and provide protection for victims. All this activity becomes more dangerous when the rights defenders themselves come from a socially vulnerable group and unfortunately belonging to the female sex is such a vulnerability in some places. On the other hand, it is the women's human rights defenders who stand up with the utmost determination and engagement for people or groups who are injured in human rights, and therefore the impossibility of their work can in many cases result in the paralysis of entire organizations. One of the easiest ways to attack women's human rights defenders against opponents of the activities of rights defenders is to exploit social prejudices about women. This is a real problem in many countries and requires serious responses from international organisations supporting rights protection activities.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we need the European Union to be an advocate for women defenders. And we have long been seeing with great concern how human rights NGOs are also beginning to be identified as suspicious, both here, in the fight to prevent more deaths in the Mediterranean Sea, as in Latin America or in other regions and territories, where, in addition, the women defenders who are members of them and who are the weaker component also need our support in an increasingly visible, stronger and more obvious way, since they are those who, as leaders of their communities, work day by day for their disappeared persons, families, fight violence against them and their children, also in the defense of their communities, the environment and their children. natural resources. And it is therefore increasingly urgent to be able to ensure security in their work, since it is essential for our democracy, for democracy in general and for human rights. Also for peace and stability for which we work so hard. And I would like to name Amal Habani, Nahid Yabralah in Sudan, Atena Daemi, Golrockh Irae and Mansura Behkish of Iran, who are also suffering abuses and very dangerous situations in prisons. But also Maru Villalpando, in the United States, who defends migrants, and Helena Maleno, who in southern Spain also defends migrants and is now before Moroccan courts because the Government of Spain has not communicated the closure of her case. It is therefore necessary to help you as soon as possible, Commissioner.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Berta Cáceres, Helena Maleno or the Sakharov Prize finalist Lolita Chavez are just three examples of brave women who stepped forward in defence of something as fundamental as human rights. Defending human rights is a right, but it is also a right that, in exercising it, demonstrates the current and unjust global order in which the dignity of individuals and peoples is worth much less than business benefit. Berta, like so many other women, reporting this abuse cost her life. Lolita costs exile and family separation. Women defenders face a double threat. They are confronted with corporate powers, corrupt governments and judicial systems, partial media and so on. But, moreover, because of being women, they are fighting the violent gap of inequality that we all suffer. Defenders represent what the elites fear most. They are the symbol of life and care in the face of destruction, against which they fight. For those they are attacked, silenced, killed. On the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the Union should be clear who the heroines of our time are and protect them, not only on paper, but with specific programmes. Thank you all very much.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, women human rights defenders face gender—specific threats and obstacles and need to be protected accordingly. The multiplication of feminicides against women human rights defenders in the last few years has been a devastating example of the need for safety measures to protect them. In Iran, the women human rights defender Atena Daemi has been in prison for years for her work on women and children’s rights. On 24 January, she and her colleague Golrokh Iraee were beaten in prison and transferred. They are now on hunger strike to protest their treatment. The woman’s right defender Mansoureh Behkish could spend 11.5 years in prison for her work with mothers of imprisoned or executed people. After years of harassment and imprisonment, she now faces a heavier sentence. So the EU and all Member States must push for all these women to be set free. And one last word about taking into account the obstacles faced by trans and queer human rights defenders: they often face the same threats as women, but they are not visible in our policies or our discourse, and their safety in general is an issue that is not addressed.

name: President. –
text: Before proceeding with catch-the-eye, I must say that I am glad to chair the session on this item, although I regret that I could not be in the Chamber – and, indeed, take the floor – because I think that the defence of human rights among women is something special, as it is so very difficult. Also, as Vice-President responsible for human rights, I would love to speak on the item and pay tribute not just to those whose names have been mentioned but also to many, many others. Catch—the—eye procedure

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, like the previous colleagues, I express my deep concern about the increasing number of attacks against members of the organizations in defence of human rights around the world, aimed in particular against women, activists who fight against gender stereotypes, sometimes challenging social norms and values patriarchal to defend rights and democracy, and for this they face discrimination and intimidating acts and truly incredible gender threats, such as rape, acid attacks, violence against children or sexual smear campaigns. Often these women are victims of real disparaging campaigns, such as in Salvador where reproductive rights activists have been accused in the press of being traitors unpatriotic who throw discredit on the country. It is therefore necessary that the European Commission, in the context of the review of the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, invest efforts and resources to support women fighting for defence of human rights all over the world.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange, and I thank the honourable Members for their interventions. From this debate, I conclude that we all recognise the vital importance of women human rights defenders and share common commitments to help protect them and promote their work.  We are living in extremely difficult times for civil society and human rights defenders all around the world. We are collectively facing a situation where the space for civil society is shrinking. However, let me be clear that the European Union will never leave human rights defenders alone, and we will continue to work together with you and civil society to defend human rights defenders around the world.  May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the agenda.

name: President. –
text: Commissioner, thank you for staying with us until this late hour. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - There are still a number of countries in different regions of the world where women who are actively involved in civil or political activities and actively defend human rights are subject to discrimination, threats or even violence. One of these countries is Belarus, located in the neighbourhood of Lithuania and the EU, where socially and politically active women, contributing to the creation of a democratic society in Belarus, are experiencing persecution or repression. Moreover, the Belarusian authorities apply different repressive measures to women who defend human rights than men. Men who defend human rights are usually punished by a fine or imprisoned. Meanwhile, women who defend human rights can face a whole variety of repressive measures, including closure to mental health care facilities, deprivation of maternity rights, dismissal, humiliation of dignity, forced divorce or seizure of property. They experience a wide variety of forms of persecution, all of which aim to humiliate women and destroy their personalities. Thus, the situation is very difficult and I support the call on the Commission to start taking into account the gender dimension of working with human rights defenders in the world, because, as we see from specific examples of a particular country, support must be targeted and protection must be provided for particularly risky groups. such as women. Now is a very good time to raise this issue, and I hope that the Commission will give priority to identifying adequate funding for the activities of human rights defenders, especially women who defend human rights.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – In 2015, Oxfam recorded that at least 31 women activists were murdered because they were standing up for human rights. Women’s rights defenders not only face violence from state actors, but also from within their own movements, their communities and members of their own families. This is because women defenders are defying what it means to be a woman in society, simply by stepping into the public space. Even though, in theory, the EU guidelines on this issue refer to gender perspectives, it is deeply disappointing that the European Commission is still not providing any information as to whether it consults women human rights defenders, and therefore whether they take into account the gender factors to any great extent and whether they are addressing any gender specific needs. At the moment, the majority of funding programmes put in place to support human rights defenders are not aimed specifically at supporting women human rights defenders. We need to make sure this changes.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: in writing. When I walk into Parliament to vote, I realise that I can exercise my democratic right here thanks to Aletta Jacobs, Emmeline Pankhurst and others. Thanks to their struggle, I'm standing here. This week, the UK has 100 years of women's suffrage; next year it will be the turn of the Netherlands. Women's suffrage wasn't about one night of ice. For example, married Dutch women became legal only in 1956 and the EU brought the Equal Treatment Act to the Netherlands in 1980. In this Parliament, only one third of parliamentarians are women. The battle continues unabated! Think of the women of the Womens March. Think of She Decides, a campaign initiated by my party colleague Ploumen for safe abortions, education and maternity care in poor countries. Think of all the women who get up every day and shout: “I'm proud of myself, I can handle the whole world!” To them I say, “you're on top of your game! Keep fighting!” We must express our support for the fight for women's rights within the EU. This is partly why I call on women in the Netherlands to vote on 21 March. As Emmeline Pankhurst would say, “Deeds, not words”.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: in writing. — In Europe, we take human rights for the obvious. We enjoy a wide range of legally guaranteed freedoms, which also applies to women (by the way, I must point out that Poland, also for alleged violations of women's rights, was considered the sixth safest country for women in the latest New World Wealth study. world). Unfortunately in many places, women's situation is much worse; their rights are denied, they are considered second-category persons. Even today, the European Parliament strongly condemns one of the manifestations of such an approach, which is female genital circumcision. However, even in those countries where women's situation is bad, there are always brave defenders of women's rights, which they are often themselves. Their fate is not enviable — they struggle with hurtful stereotypes, incomprehension from authorities and large parts of the population, and are often outright intimidated, beaten and belittled. They themselves and their families are often threatened with physical danger, including the threat of life. It is good that the European Union is working to sensitize its diplomacy to the needs of those brave women who need our support. I strongly support this approach and ask the High Representative for Foreign Policy to ensure that all EU delegations follow this approach regardless of where they operate.
